BREAK.XREF: PUBLIC EMPLOYMENT (CONSEQUENTIAL AND TRANSITIONAL) AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 18 November.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Public Service Bill 1997 and opposition amendments Nos 36, 37 and 38 moved by Senator Faulkner. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night you might recall, Madam Chair, I did ask the minister a question. I think he indicated to me that, given the late hour, he might respond to me this morning. This question—I am sure the minister would recall—went to the issue of the application of the unfair dismissal provisions of the Workplace Relations Act. Without wanting to put words into the minister's mouth, I think he indicated that he might respond on that issue this morning. I think the committee would benefit from hearing his advice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understood Senator Faulkner's query yesterday, it related to the unfair dismissal provisions of the Workplace Relations Act and how that related to the SES officers of the APS.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation here in clause 38 is that the SES officers are treated differently on this aspect. We have tried to align as much as possible the Australian Public Service with the private sector. In the private sector, senior executives are excluded from the termination provisions because they are not covered by a federal award or agreement, and they also earn more than $66,200 a year.

In relation to the SES officers, they earn more than that amount. However, they are covered by an award, so their exclusion from division 3 of the Workplace Relations Act can only be achieved by expressly excluding them. That is what is being done here: they are being looked upon as executives would be in the private sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —When you say that the senior executive service will be treated on the same basis as the private sector, does that mean that from time to time we may expect substantial payouts when senior executive service people leave in the same way as there are very substantial payouts to people in the private sector when they leave?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think clause 37 deals with that; there is an incentive to retire aspect there. There is a convention as to how much will be paid that states that the agency head can given notice in writing to an SES employee in the agency stating that that employee will become entitled to a payment of a specified sum if the employee retires within a period specified in the notice. It then goes on to deal with that. That, I think, covers the question of any payments that can be made to SES officers.

—When you say `specified sum', that would seem to indicate that a specific decision is going to be made by someone within a formula; whereas, with the private sector the amount paid depends upon the decision, I suppose, of the board—in other words, there is great flexibility. Can we expect the same flexibility here and, if we cannot, how can you say it is like the private sector?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the agreements between the agency heads and the officers concerned will specify that. That is fairly typical, I believe, of the private sector and those agreements would cover that aspect of the specified amounts.
—There appears to me to be very little difference between opposition amendment No. 36 and the clause as printed. What is the difference?

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —What I am asking the minister to clarify is whether, in accordance with the workplace relations act, those provisions of the Workplace Relations Act apply to SES officers in the Australian Public Service. At this stage there is no entirely clear answer to that question.
—I seek clarification. Are we dealing at the moment with opposition amendment No. 36, which is an amendment to clause 35?
—We are dealing that opposition amendments 36, 37 and 38 which are amendments to clauses 35, 36 and 38—three amendments moved together, by leave, last night.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night I asked Senator Ellison a question about the application of the Workplace Relations Act. If these provisions do not apply to SES officers, put another way, the question is: why have clause 38 in the bill? That is the nub of it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 38 excludes them. If you do not exclude them, as I mentioned, then division 3 puts them in. So clause 38 in the bill is what makes the situation different. It is what excludes the SES officers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 38 would completely exclude access for such officers under all circumstances. Clearly, that is the case. That is why the opposition has proposed amendment 38 in those terms. I suspect what we have come down to is the fact that we have a fundamentally different view on this particular matter.

—I can see the point. With respect to clause 38, I propose to support the opposition amendment. But with respect to clause 36, what is the difference between amendment No. 36 of the opposition and clause 35 as printed?

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition amendment 36 is moved in an attempt to counter fragmentation of the Australian Public Service. It is also moved with the objective in mind to retain the SES as a mobile leadership group. That is how the SES was originally conceived and it is the view of the opposition that it is appropriate that this ought to be reflected in this legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes the three amendments. In relation to clause 35, the government can see no benefit arising from the words which are inserted in the opposition amendment. It really does not take it anywhere.
—I ask that amendment 36 be taken separately from the other two amendments.
—The question is that amendment 36 be agreed to.
—The question is that amendments 37 and 38 be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (39) Clause 41, page 20 (line 14), after "incorporate", insert "and uphold".
(40) Clause 41, page 20 (lines 25 and 26), omit paragraph (f), substitute:

TAB.TAB: (f) to inquire into, report to the Prime Minister on and, where appropriate, make recommendations on sanctions regarding alleged breaches of the Code of Conduct by Agency Heads;

SPEECH.PARA: (41) Clause 41, page 21 (lines 3 and 4), omit paragraph (i), substitute:

TAB.TAB: (i) to coordinate and support APS‐wide career development opportunities, recruitment and training in the APS;

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments go to clause 41, part 5 of the bill and relate to the Public Service Commissioner's functions. Amendment No. 39 seeks to add the words `and uphold'. In our view, it is more important that the commissioner evaluates the extent to which the values are upheld rather than simply incorporated.

In relation to amendment No. 40, we take the view that agency heads should be subject to sanctions for breaches in the same way that APS employees are. Of course, we say that the commissioner should have the role of recommending the appropriate sanction. Amendment No. 41 includes a slight drafting change. The addition of `recruitment' reflects the amendment proposed to clause 22(1A).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes these amendments. I think we have traversed this ground before. The bill quite clearly sets out what the commissioner's functions are—to uphold the ethos of the Public Service and maintain good practice. These amendments are seen as being consequential upon earlier amendments to the bill and, again, go to that aspect of more prescription. The government does not see a need for these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Clause 41, page 21 (after line 7), after paragraph (k), insert:

TAB.TAB: (ka) to monitor, and report to the Public Service Minister on, the extent to which Agencies develop and implement workplace diversity programs required under section 18.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 6 ties in with the opposition amendments relating to workplace diversity and requires the Public Service Commissioner to monitor and report to the minister on progress which agencies are making towards implementing their workplace diversity programs. We think this is a very fair and important obligation to place upon the commissioner.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports this amendment. It is consistent with our approach to the bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment is opposed by the government as being unnecessary. It provides unnecessary detail and process for inclusion in primary legislation. In accordance with JCPA recommendation No. 12, at paragraph 5.25, the commissioner's direction was amended in paragraph 2.4 to make it clear that the Public Service Commissioner would monitor and report on the effectiveness and outcomes of the workplace diversity programs in each agency. The government believes it has picked up the recommendation made by the committee and has accordingly incorporated it in the commissioner's directions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand what the minister has said. Whilst I am on my feet, I make the observation that one got very little support from the report of the committee. I note that the opposition was represented on that committee. I rely considerably on committee reports and the information provided to committees, but in this case there was no minority report to the report to which Senator Ellison adverted.

SPEECH.PARA: None of the amendments that have come forward were based on any minority report of the committee. They came out of left field. I have an inclination to vote against the lot, but obviously there must have been some reason—perhaps Senator Faulkner will give us a reason—why there was no minority report. There were quite a number of recommendations from that committee. Some of them were substantial recommendations. All of them—with maybe one or two exceptions, but I think all of them—have been taken up by the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to respond to Senator Harradine on this important matter. I was a little surprised by Senator Harradine's comment. He may have been in the same position in which I found myself in relation to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, because I was not aware, until I became a member of that committee for the purposes of this inquiry, that the committee has had a very long tradition of not having minority reports. I made it very clear to the committee—even though there were fundamental differences between the opposition and the government in having that committee examine this legislation—that I did not feel it was appropriate for me, on behalf of the opposition, to up‐end that convention and tradition. I hope Senator Harradine will appreciate that that is the case. That meant, during the committee's examination of the Public Service Bill and related bills, that there were a number of issues on which the committee was silent. Again, this was something that committee members well understood.

SPEECH.PARA: There were a range of issues where government and opposition members could not find agreement and that meant at times—I suspect not only from an opposition perspective but also from a government perspective—that compromises had to be made. The opposition has always been very clear in its approach to the work of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts.

Then Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters, Mr Reith, was responsible for making a decision to refer this legislation to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. There would be arguments about the appropriateness or otherwise of that particular committee dealing with legislation in detail. I know it did present difficulties for a number of senators—I am sure you would have been in that category Senator Harradine. I know the Australian Democrats, for example, did not have representation on that committee and subsequently that meant that the selection of bills process in the Senate was used to ensure that there was a further hearing of the Senate Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee into this bill.

I indicated at that time that for its part the opposition would not be engaging in that particular process because we took very seriously both the hearings and the development of the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. You raise an important issue Senator Harradine and I am glad I have had an opportunity to explain to you that this is a long held tradition of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, and one I was not aware of—I do not know whether you were—until my short and illustrious career on the committee.

It was in that spirit that the opposition approached its task. I think that was a spirit that was accepted and reflected by government members of the committee too. We did try to develop a committee report that opposition and government members could sign up to, which is what we achieved. It did mean that there would be no minority report. It did mean that the committee would not be able to canvass a range of issues that would be subject to amendment in the committee stage process. But I want to assure you, Senator Harradine, that members of the public accounts committee and at all stages the government were well aware of this approach and well aware of the issues that the opposition thought were significant for this committee stage debate.

I never want to up‐end these sorts of traditions and conventions and I certainly thought for the purposes of the committee's important work, albeit limited to one package of legislation, that ought not occur. It did not occur, nevertheless the opposition certainly took very seriously the work of the committee in examining the bills exhaustively.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Since we are on the subject of process, I remind Senator Harradine that the one day inquiry conducted by the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee did produce a dissenting report, which was ours. We drew attention to the problems, as we saw them, of the very short time frame in which this legislation was discussed in the legislation committee. I think it is a problem. We have said so in our report and we still think that is the case. That is partly because we were not represented on the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I think I agree with Senator Harradine's remarks that it would have been a more fulsome inquiry and report that would have been available to us at this point in time had that been a later inquiry, one where the regulations were available and one which was conducted, with the full support of the ALP, as a Senate inquiry. Nevertheless, I draw Senator Harradine's attention to our report in relation to this amendment, in particular our reference to Dr Sawer's submission and her evidence. That is the basis on which we put forward this recommendation.
Amendment not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (42) Clause 44, page 22 (after line 19), at the end of the clause, add:

PARA.TAB: (4) The report must be prepared in accordance with guidelines approved by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit on behalf of the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: (48) Clause 51, page 25 (lines 19 and 20), omit subclause (2), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (2) The report is to be prepared in accordance with guidelines approved by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on behalf of the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: (58) Clause 63, page 30 (after line 19), at the end of the clause, add:

PARA.TAB: (2) The report is to be prepared in accordance with guidelines approved by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit on behalf of the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: (68) Clause 70, page 34 (after line 8), at the end of the clause; add:

PARA.TAB: (2) The report is to be prepared in accordance with guidelines approved by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit on behalf of the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment 42 to clause 44 is one that Senator Harradine will find is completely consistent with the first recommendation of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. I do hope that the government will see fit to support this amendment. Dr Kemp, the new Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service, indicated general acceptance for this principle in his second reading speech in the House of Representatives. Because of that, I would be hoping that the government would find no objection to this important principle being included in the legislation itself.

Opposition amendment 48, again relating to the annual report, replaces the words `the Merit Protection Commissioner's report to be included in the Public Service Commissioner's report' with a proposal that the report should be prepared in accordance with guide lines approved by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on behalf of the parliament. The opposition believes it would not be appropriate for the Merit Protection Commissioner to report through the Public Service Commissioner, who could vet the report. We believe the report should go to the parliament and should be provided to the parliament by the minister who is responsible for Public Service matters.

Opposition amendment 58, again relating to the annual report, also picks up the first recommendation of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts report and is consistent with it. Opposition amendment 68 is also consistent with the JCPA's recommendations. I commend these four amendments to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this is consistent with the responsibility to report to the parliament. As it was a unanimous decision of the joint committee, I cannot actually see why the government is not accepting it. I am sure the government, on reflection, might well accept the proposals. They enhance the integrity of the reporting process to the parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes these amendments. I believe the sentiments expressed by Dr Kemp in the other place were that the government thought that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts would be involved in consultation but not actually in a formal reporting sense, the committee dealing more with the parliament rather than statutory authorities. I think we dealt with this sort of debate previously in relation to the Merit Protection Commissioner's annual report and the government's policy on that. In the circumstances, the government cannot agree to the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Clause 44, page 22 (after line 16), after subclause (2), insert:

PARA.TAB: (2A) The report must include an assessment of the effectiveness of workplace diversity programs and the promotion of employment equity both within Agencies and across the APS, including an evaluation of relevant statistics and related information.
(2B) The report must include a statement of the aggregate remuneration of each Agency Head, the Commissioner and the Merit Protection Commissioner.

SPEECH.PARA: Our amendment No. 7 requires the Public Service Commissioner to include within his or her annual report a statement assessing the effectiveness of workplace diversity programs and the promotion of employment equity within the APS. The Democrats believe the parliament and the public should have access to this information and should be able to scrutinise the progress being made by the APS in this area. It also requires the Commissioner to publish details of the remuneration of agency heads, the Commissioner and the Merit Protection Commissioner. The Democrats believe that remuneration of these persons should be open to proper public scrutiny.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will support this amendment from the Australian Democrats. Proposed new subclause 44(2A) is consistent with the spirit of the amendments the opposition has proposed on workplace diversity programs. We find no serious fault with proposed new subclause 44(2B) of the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes this amendment. As outlined previously, the government believes it has picked up the recommendation contained at paragraph 5.25 of the JCPA report, which deals with diversity. We have included that in paragraph 2.4 of our Commissioner's directions. We believe we have adequately covered the position.

—I am not sure why proposed new subclause 44(2B) should be included. I think the point that was made by Senator Ellison is valid. It has been dealt with. I believe that they did pick up the committee's report.

BREAK.PARA: Amendment not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (43) Clause 46, page 23 (line 10), at the end of the clause, add "on the advice of the Remuneration Tribunal and are to be published in the Gazette ".
(50) Clause 53, page 26 (line 11), at the end of the clause, add "on the advice of the Remuneration Tribunal and are to be published in the Gazette ".
(57) Clause 61, page 29 (line 26), at the end of the clause, add "on the advice of the Remuneration Tribunal and are to be published in the Gazette ".
(67) Clause 68, page 33 (line 18), at the end of the clause, add "on the advice of the Remuneration Tribunal and are to be published in the Gazette ".

Opposition amendment 43 adds to the end of the clause 46 in the bill the words `on the advice of the Remuneration Tribunal and are to be published in the Gazette '. I think it is an important amendment. The agency minister should be obliged to consult the Remuneration Tribunal, and the Commissioner's remuneration should continue in the view of the opposition to be subject to public scrutiny, which is the case with other public office holders.

I think publication in the Gazette is preferable to the minister's proposal that we have publication in the annual report. I acknowledge that the minister indicated in his second reading speech that that was the preferred approach of the government. I think there is an issue of timing in relation to this. That is why I think publication in the Gazette would indeed be a much improved process.

Mr Temporary Chairman, in relation to opposition amendment 50, this is a matter that effectively we have canvassed previously. I think the arguments speak for themselves. The conditions of appointment of the Merit Protection Commissioner, again, ought to be determined on the advice of the Remuneration Tribunal and published in the Gazette. That is consistent for opposition amendment 57, and in the case of opposition amendment 67 it is appropriate. Clause 68 of the bill applies the same conditions to the head of an executive agency.

These are important amendments in terms of transparency. I do accept that the government has acknowledged the need for transparency. We are talking about the best vehicle to achieve that within an appropriate time frame. I am concerned about the time lag if the government depends only on publication in the annual report. It is for those reasons that the opposition proposes these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will support these opposition amendments. However, that will be a fallback position for us since my amendments 8, 9 and 16 deal with this question. I want to give notice of that and remind the Senate that our amendments 8, 9 and 16 will actually see the continuation of the Remuneration Tribunal setting remuneration and conditions for departmental secretaries, the Public Service Commissioner, and the Merit Protection Commissioner, but I will speak to those when they come up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government's position is that we believe that the government, as employer of agency heads and other senior executives, and in common with employers in the wider community, should be responsible for determining the remuneration to apply to each appointment and decide on the appropriateness of changes in remuneration for each of these groups. The government will be assisted in this by consulting with the Remuneration Tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: As I see it, the opposition is saying that the advice of the Remuneration Tribunal will be obtained, and the Democrat amendments which are foreshadowed actually make it stronger, so it will be set by the Remuneration Tribunal. The government does not see that such detail should be included in the legislation. The matter will be contained in annual reports. There will be the transparency there. The government believes that this brings the APS more in line with the wider community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, this is simply a matter of when and how the information is to be made available. Obviously, thinking of our audit and control functions as a parliament, and particularly as the Senate, one thinks about the estimates committees and what can be done in those estimates committees to oversight what is taking place in the agencies and what is taking place in government thinking on how agency heads, for example, should be remunerated. If that is in the annual report, then clearly that is an appropriate subject for the estimates committees to pursue.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, what Senator Faulkner is putting is that these should be notified in the Gazette. If that is the only difference then I tend to agree with what Senator Ellison says, but we are dealing also with opposition amendment No. 53, aren't we?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.
—Not at this time. We are dealing with 43, 50, 57 and 67.
—I am sorry. I thought we may have been. I was waiting to hear from Senator Faulkner an explanation of the purpose of 53. I am opposing the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, you are partly right, but the very important aspect of these amendments goes to the fact that the opposition is arguing that seeking the advice of the Remuneration Tribunal is obligatory; that is, Senator Harradine, I think the key element of these amendments. If I can take you to the explanatory memorandum on clause 46, you will see in paragraph 5.23 the words:

SPEECH.PARA: As a matter of practice, the Agency Minister would normally only make such a determination after consultation with the Remuneration Tribunal.
We say absolutely clearly, Senator, that this should be an obligation on government and I think that is the key element of the amendments before the chamber.

The issue of the publication—in other words, the transparency issue—is of importance but I believe of primary importance is the issue of the government being obliged to seek the advice of the Remuneration Tribunal. This really is an important amendment, Senator. The opposition would ask you to give very serious consideration to the obligatory nature of the government's advice from the Remuneration Tribunal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Faulkner. I apologise—I had not focused on that. I should have because of what Senator Allison said concerning her amendments. So far as amendment No. 43 is concerned, I am not happy about these matters being published in the Gazette . Why can't you just leave it to the annual report? I can understand the point you are making in respect of the advice of the Remuneration Tribunal being sought. After all, the minister has said to the chamber that this is how it will be done. You have read from the explanatory memorandum what has been indicated, and I have seen that as well. But I cannot see why these matters should be published in the Gazette . If that is a problem for you and it is difficult to split the amendment, it will only be a waste of time and I will support the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be possible to change the amendment, Senator, if your concern was such that you would vote against what I think is the primary principle of obligation of advice from the Remuneration Tribunal. I suspect I should listen to the remainder of the debate on these four amendments.

—Can I suggest that one difference might be timing. We would have to wait some time before this was published in the annual report and the Gazette would come along much sooner. It seems to me to be a fairly compelling argument.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has stated very clearly that it will be consulting with the Remuneration Tribunal. It does not see the need to have this contained within the bill itself. As well as that, the Remuneration Tribunal, through consequential amendments and consequential legislation that we will be dealing with, will be determining classifications. We do see the question of the Gazette as being unnecessary. The report does contain it. It is subject to that scrutiny which Senator Harradine mentions. Again, it is a question of the bill overstepping the mark if it were to include these provisions, which are adequately catered for otherwise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, Minister, what you have informed the committee of is not correct. There is no obligation on the minister—on the government—to seek advice from the Remuneration Tribunal. I do not believe that you can justify the statement that you have made. I have put no spin on the government's words, which are full of qualifiers; they are weasel words, Minister. As a matter of practice, the agency minister would normally only make such a determination after consultation with the Remuneration Tribunal. You should have no problem, Minister, with this amendment, none at all, if in fact it were to be a matter of practice in all circumstances an obligation to consult the Remuneration Tribunal. But that is not what the government is saying. I think the committee needs to be clear about that.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (8) Clause 46, page 23 (lines 9 and 10), omit "Agency Minister", substitute "Remuneration Tribunal and are to be published in the Gazette ".
(9) Clause 53, page 26 (line 11), omit "Public Service Minister", substitute "Remuneration Tribunal and are to be published in the Gazette ".
(16) Clause 61, page 29 (line 26), omit "by the Prime Minister", substitute "by the Remuneration Tribunal and are to be published in the Gazette ".

As I said earlier, the Democrats believe the Remuneration Tribunal should continue to set the remuneration and conditions of departmental secretaries, the Public Service Commissioner and the Merit Protection Commissioner. We believe the process of fixing the remuneration of these persons should be transparent and subject to public scrutiny. We do not want to see a situation develop where the Prime Minister or the Public Service minister can do some backdoor remuneration deal with these key people, with neither taxpayers nor the parliament having much of a capacity to examine the deal or raise questions about it. This also means that secretaries will know that their remuneration is not solely based on the whim of the Prime Minister.

These amendments also require the remuneration and conditions of secretaries, the Public Service Commissioner and the Merit Protection Commissioner to be published in the Gazette. In this respect, I draw the committee's attention to the concerns raised by the Australian National Audit Office in its submission to the JCPA. The ANAO's view was that it was important for any revised arrangements in this area to include mechanisms for the aggregate remuneration and benefits of such positions to be open to public scrutiny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will not be supporting Democrat amendments Nos 8, 9 and 16 because they would have the effect of requiring the Remuneration Tribunal to determine the remuneration and conditions of agency heads. Put simply, we are prepared to allow the Prime Minister and agency heads some degree of flexibility in setting salary and conditions provided that advice is sought from the Remuneration Tribunal and the final agreed package is made public. That means that the government would need to justify in the public domain any variation from the Remuneration Tribunal's advice. I am satisfied that in those circumstances these amendments are not necessary. It is for those reasons that the opposition will not support Senator Allison's amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (51) Page 27 (after line 17), after clause 55, insert:

TAB.TAB: The Merit Protection Commissioner, a member of a Review Committee established under subsection 33(2A) or a person acting under the direction or authority of the Merit Protection Commissioner is not liable to an action, suit or proceeding for or in relation to an act done or omitted to be done in good faith in exercise or purported exercise of any power or authority conferred by this Act.

PARA.TAB: (1) Civil proceedings do not lie against a person in respect of loss, damage or injury of any kind suffered by another person by reason of:

TAB.TAB: (a) the making of an application to the Merit Protection Commissioner under this Act; or
(b) the making of a statement to, or the furnishing of a document or information to, an officer for the purposes of this Act.

PARA.TAB: (2) In subsection (1), officer means:

TAB.TAB: (a) the Merit Protection Commissioner; or
(b) a member of a Review Committee established under subsection 33(2A); or
(c) an employee of the Statutory Agency established under subsection 49(3); or
(d) a person, not being a person referred to in paragraph (c), to whom the Merit Protection Commissioner has delegated any of his or her powers under section 78.

PARA.TAB: (1) In this section, officer means:

TAB.TAB: (a) the Merit Protection Commissioner; or
(b) a member of a Review Committee established under subsection 33(2A); or
(c) an employee of the Statutory Agency established under subsection 49(3); or
(d) a person, not being a person referred to in paragraph (c), to whom the Merit Protection Commissioner has delegated any of his or her powers under section 78.

PARA.TAB: (2) Subject to this section, an officer shall not, directly or indirectly, and either while he or she is, or after he ceases to be, an officer, make a record of, or divulge or communicate to any person, any information acquired by the officer by reason of his or her being an officer, being information that was disclosed or obtained under the provisions of sections 33.

TAB.TAB: Penalty: $1,000 or imprisonment for 6 months or both.

PARA.TAB: (3) Subsection (2) does not prevent an officer:

TAB.TAB: (a) from making a record of, or divulging or communicating to any person, information acquired by the officer in the performance of his or her duties as an officer for purposes connected with the exercise of the powers and with the performance of the functions of the Merit Protection Commissioner under this Act; or
(b) from divulging or communicating information to a person:

(i) if the information was furnished by an officer of an Agency or Commonwealth authority in the performance of his or her duties as such an employee—with the consent of the principal officer of the Agency or authority or of the responsible Minister; or
(ii) if the information was furnished by a person otherwise than as set out in subparagraph (i)—with the consent of the person who furnished the information.

PARA.TAB: (4) Subsection (2) does not prevent the Merit Protection Commissioner or a person to whom the Merit Protection Commissioner has delegated powers or functions under section 78 from disclosing, in a report made under this Act, such matters as, in his or her opinion, ought to be disclosed in the course of setting out the grounds for the conclusions and recommendations contained in the report.

(5) A person who is or has been an officer is not competent and may not be required, in any proceedings before a court (whether exercising federal jurisdiction or not) or before a person authorized by a law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory, or by consent of parties, to hear, receive or examine evidence or to disclose any information acquired by the person by reason of his or her being or having been an officer, being information that was disclosed or obtained under the provisions of sections 16 or 33.

(6) Subject to subsections (7) and (8), nothing in this Act is to be taken to preclude the Merit Protection Commissioner from disclosing information, or making a statement, to any person or to the public or a section of the public with respect to the performance of a function of the Merit Protection Commissioner under this Act if, in the opinion of the Merit Protection Commissioner, it is in the interests of any Agency, Commonwealth authority or person, or is otherwise in the public interest, so to disclose that information or to make that statement.

(7) The Merit Protection Commissioner must not disclose information or make a statement under subsection (6) with respect to a particular review where the disclosure of that information, or the making of that statement, is likely to interfere with the carrying out of that review or of any other review.

(8) The Merit Protection Commissioner must not, in disclosing information or making a statement under subsection (6) with respect to a particular review disclose the name of an applicant or any other matter that would enable an applicant to be identified unless it is fair and reasonable in all the circumstances to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: This is again an important issue for the committee to give consideration to. Obviously, it has very much exercised the minds of the Merit Protection Commission and the Merit Protection Commissioner. The current Merit Protection Commissioner regards immunity from suit and protection from civil actions as absolutely necessary to the effective conduct of external reviews. I suspect that the Merit Protection Commission is in a very strong position to be able to advise the parliament on these issues. I would be interested in knowing whether the government has sought the views of the Merit Protection Commissioner. If the government has not sought the views of the Merit Protection Commissioner, why not?

These protections are currently provided in sections 80 and 82 of the Merit Protection Act. Staff and agency members cannot be sued if they have acted in good faith. As far as the opposition understands, without this protection, it would be difficult to find people willing to investigate cases, particularly the more difficult ones that often have to be dealt with. There are also people, both those with grievances and witnesses, who say that they have been threatened with defamation and other legal and sometimes illegal action if they give the MPRA certain information. Even with these protections, there are alleged victims of bullying and witnesses who have information which the agency has not been able to act on because they are not prepared to be identified. These are important issues. They are of such significance that this amendment is required to provide immunity from suit and this level of protection.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that there was not any contact with the Merit Protection Commissioner on this matter and that the government views the position as being in a somewhat independent category. The question of immunity is provided for at common law. Someone fulfilling their duties in this occupation, which is a statutory office, would enjoy qualified privilege. Therefore, the government does not agree to the amendment and does not see its necessity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I think it would be appropriate if I now sought leave to move my amendments to the opposition amendment No. 51.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Subclause 55B(1), after "Civil", insert ", criminal or administrative".

PARA.TAB: Note: The heading to section 55B is altered by omitting "civil ".

SPEECH.PARA: (5) After subclause 55B(1), insert:

PARA.TAB: (1A) If a person who makes a disclosure under section 16 would, apart from this subsection, contravene an Act, oath, rule of law or practice, the person:

TAB.TAB: (a) does not contravene the Act, oath rule of law or practice; and
(b) is not liable to disciplinary action for making the disclosure;
if the disclosure was made in good faith.

SPEECH.PARA: (6) After clause 55C, insert:

PARA.TAB: (1) A person who intentionally causes detriment to an APS employee because of, or in the belief that, the APS employee has made or may make a disclosure under section 16 commits an unlawful reprisal and is guilty of an offence.

TAB.TAB: Penalty: 50 penalty units

PARA.TAB: (2) A person who attempts to cause detriment or who incites, or conspires with, another person to cause detriment to an APS employee because of, or in the belief that, the APS employee has made or may make a disclosure under section 16 commits an unlawful reprisal and is guilty of an offence.

TAB.TAB: Penalty: 50 penalty units

PARA.TAB: (3) In this section, detriment includes:

TAB.TAB: (a) injury, damage or loss; or
(b) prejudice to safety; or
(c) intimidation or harassment; or
(d) discrimination, disadvantage or adverse treatment in relation to employment; or
(e) dismissal from, or prejudice in, employment; or
(f) disciplinary proceedings.

PARA.TAB: (4) Nothing in the section prevents an alleged unlawful reprisal from being treated as a breach of the Code of Conduct.

SPEECH.PARA: This carries on a theme that I have been pursuing throughout this debate. I have experienced sympathy from all sides but not support. However, I will persist. It refers again to the accountability area. It refers to the protections that we believe should be accorded to those in the Public Service in matters of accountability or whistleblowing where they may feel obliged to act in a way which is in the public interest.

We seek to add to the terms and conditions of Public Service employees through adding to the protection which the opposition propose to put up in their amendment No. 51—which I should foreshadow, since we have not already done so, the Democrats will be supporting. Amendment No. 4, which I have put to opposition amendment 51, affects subclause 55B(1). Instead of reading:
Civil proceedings do not lie against a person—
we would have it read:
Civil, criminal or administrative proceedings do not lie against a person in respect of—
and it goes on. The intention is to enlarge the protections offered to public servants in the exercise of their duties in the public interest.

BREAK.PARA: Amendment 5 again goes to the heart of the intention that I have been pushing throughout this bill. After section 55B(1)—which is headed `Protection from civil actions'—our amendment 5 says:
If a person who makes a disclosure under section 16—
which is the whistleblower protection, the minimalist provision provided by the government—
would, apart from this subsection, contravene an Act, oath, rule of law or practice, the person:

TAB.TAB: (a) does not contravene the Act, oath rule of law or practice; and
(b) is not liable to disciplinary action for making the disclosure;
if the disclosure was made in good faith.

BREAK.PARA: In other words, persons should not be prevented from doing their duty in the public interest, should not be required to obey an unlawful order and should not be required to conceal matters which should not be concealed. That is the protection applied to them.

Amendment 6 adds 55D after the opposition's 55C and is headed `Unlawful reprisal for an offence'. It deals with penalties for persons who intentionally cause detriment to an Australian Public Service employee because the employee has made a disclosure under clause 16. It deals with that all the way through, and `detriment' is defined as:

TAB.TAB: (a) injury, damage or loss; or
(b) prejudice to safety; or
(c) intimidation or harassment; or
(d) discrimination, disadvantage or adverse treatment in relation to employment; or
(e) dismissal from, or prejudice in, employment; or
(f) disciplinary proceedings.

BREAK.PARA: Nothing in this clause prevents an alleged unlawful reprisal from being treated as a breach in the code of conduct. The Labor Party have consistently said they want to leave these matters to the government when they produce their whistleblowing legislation. We have got no guarantee from the government that they will produce whistleblowing legislation. We have got no offer of them to do so. We have got no time frame in which they will produce such legislation. The oppo sition, by consistently rejecting these protections for Public Service employees, are going to hang those employees out to dry unless whistleblower legislation is brought in. Our view is that that legislation certainly will not reach us in this parliamentary term and, when the next government comes into power, there is no guarantee that either side will introduce it.

So, in consistently rejecting these matters throughout, the Labor Party have sided with the executive. They have once again behaved as an executive in waiting and have used an excuse, in my view, to avoid confronting the fact that they need to provide further protection to the Public Service employees in an environment where the nature of their employment has changed so substantially that they are to be made far more vulnerable, and we as a parliament, in our accountability role, are to be made far more vulnerable.

Whilst I do accept the opposition's view in terms of our substantive amendment the other night on part 2, the minimalist provision we then came back with in my view was worthy of support. As I have said, in rejecting it Senator Faulkner has said it is a consistent position. Yes, it is a consistent rejection but, in doing so, you are hanging Public Service employees out to dry and you are behaving as an executive in waiting, not as an accountable opposition. I commend my amendments to the Senate. I have no hope that Senator Faulkner will change his approach, but I do regret that this minimalist position has not been adopted by the opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot give Senator Murray joy on the whistleblower amendments and I have not recanted overnight. I am sorry, Senator Murray.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition can see its way clear to support amendment 4 that Senator Murray has moved. That probably does lead to a minor improvement in the wording of the bill but, for the reasons we have discussed at length in the previous parts of this committee stage, the opposition will not support those parts of Senator Murray's amendments that go to the issue of whistleblowers.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of those comments, I propose to put Senator Murray's amendment No. 4 separately and then amendments Nos 5 and 6. The question is that amendment 4 be agreed to. All those in favour say aye; against say no.
—No.
—I think the noes have it.
—Mr Chairman, you were going a bit fast. I did not hear Senator Harradine say no to amendment No. 4.
—Senator Harradine, could you clarify that?

—We were dealing with Senator Murray's amendments Nos 4, 5 and 6 on sheet 769. As I understand it, we were then going to deal with the immunity amendments that were addressed by Senator Faulkner. I would appreciate knowing the reason for splitting amendments Nos 4, 5 and 6, if Senator Murray would kindly elaborate to the committee on that.
—It is because I agreed with 4, but not 5 and 6.

—If I may put it on the record and confirm the interjection from Senator Faulkner—and I think you were otherwise engaged, Senator Harradine, when the matter came up—Senator Faulkner has indicated no support for my amendments Nos 5 and 6, which therefore automatically knocks them out. However, he did indicate support for my amendment No. 4. If you were to agree for that to go in, we could then deal with the opposition's amendment No. 51 as a whole, as amended by my amendment No. 4.

—I am sorry about this, but could Senator Ellison indicate to the committee the reason why amendment No. 4 should be opposed. It seems to me that it is simply changing the title from `civil' to `civil, criminal or administrative'. Even though Senator Ellison will be opposing that part of opposi tion amendment No. 51—that is, the essence of clause 55B—what would be the purpose of not agreeing to this amendment which simply states, to my way of thinking, what in fact 55B is all about: rather than protection from civil actions it is protection from civil, criminal or administrative actions?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, as a principle in relation to the immunity aspect we are opposed to the insertion of such a prescription in relation to the immunity. On protection from criminal or administrative action, while I can understand the administrative aspect, I would say that if you had a criminal action which could lie against a person, that you would not contain any immunity in relation to that. That is something for the Crimes Act, where special provisions are made where immunity can be given by the authorities, sometimes in the case of cooperation.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment seems to expand it to criminal. I think you would be opening up Pandora's box by having that in the act. There is another piece of legislation in which that should be properly inserted, and I suggest that that is the Crimes Act. In any event, as a matter of policy, the immunity provision is opposed as a whole, and we would have to oppose that to maintain consistency.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened to the minister's answer, and I advise the committee that 55B(i) is a very confined clause. It presently reads `Civil proceedings do not lie'; it would read `Civil, criminal or administrative proceedings do not lie', but we have to see what they do not lie against. The clause says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . do not lie against a person in respect of loss, damage or injury of any kind suffered by another person by reason of:
(a) the making of an application to the Merit Protection Commissioner under this Act; or
(b) the making of a statement to, or the furnishing of a document or information to, an officer for the purposes of this Act.
Far from opening Pandora's box, it just says that with respect to those two particular requirements that `civil, criminal or administrative proceedings do not lie'.

In my view, we do not wish to constrain, control, limit or prevent `the making of an application to the Merit Protection Commissioner', or `the making of a statement to, or the furnishing of a document or information to, an officer for the purposes of this Act'. Why would we? We want Public Service employees to be free from any fear in this matter. That is the reason that we put the amendment up.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, it is somewhat narrow, but nonetheless Pandora's box is still there. If you are trying to bring forward applications without fear or favour, as a starting point that is not bad, but if the application contains wilfully false information, where there is a conspiracy of some sort to manufacture evidence or to distort something, or to wilfully mislead or contain some element of fraud in the statement, then it is the government's belief that criminal immunity should not be afforded. That is the danger you have in these situations. We believe that the appropriate legislation for anything like that is contained in something like the Crimes Act.

—That was my gut feeling; that is why I said nothing when it came up. I am glad that the minister has clarified the matter. I appreciate what Senator Murray is doing. We are going to have to revisit that question of whistleblowers sooner or later, and probably sooner rather than later. I know this was an opportunity for us to do it. I acknowledge that it is a matter about which Senator Murray has been quite knowledgeable and persistent. For the reasons indicated by Senator Ellison, I would be opposing that amendment.
—The question is that amendment No. 4 as moved by Senator Murray be agreed to.
—The question now is that amendments Nos 5 and 6 as moved by Senator Murray be agreed to.
—We will now move to opposition amendment No. 51.
—I think we have reached the point where we are discussing appointments and terminations of secretaries.

—No, we are just going to deal with opposition amendment No. 51 which applies to miscellaneous provisions concerning immunity from suit, et cetera. The question is that opposition amendment No. 51 be agreed to.
—We now move to opposition amendments Nos 52 and 53.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought Senator Ray indicated to me that he was keen to make a contribution on clause 56, the creation of the office of secretary, or perhaps it was clause 59.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make it an all-embracing contribution to clauses 56 and 59, in anticipation that we will get to 59. This is a very convenient time for those technically minded senators to take a little refreshment break to check the future technical amendments, because I will be about 15 minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make the point here, in the more general points associated with this legislation, that these clauses are meaningless. It does not matter what provision you put in the act about secretaries, they have no protection whatsoever from a malevolent government. It does not matter what clauses you put in to protect them, to give them tenure or not give them tenure, the fact is they have no rights whatsoever and they have been treated abysmally by this government.

We have had 11 heads of department go since 11 March last year. That is about one every two months. The first purge was a big one: six departmental secretaries hit the fence. No reason was given to any of them as to why they were not continuing in employment, and large taxpayers' payouts went to them so they could be got rid of. Mr Codd left, and that was a planned retirement. I knew about that before the government changed. Mr Hollway went for a better employment opportunity and Mr Stevens moved on.

If there is one example of how governments will act wrongly, no matter what you put in a public service bill, it is the case of Mr John Mellors, the former Secretary to the Department of Administrative Services. This person could never have been regarded as a Labor partisan. In the time that he served the Labor government, I never once knew him to show any partisanship towards the Labor government, nor would I believe he would ever have shown any partisanship towards a coalition government. It is true that secretaries from time to time have sympathy for one party or another but, usually, at least half never have. Mr John Mellors fell into that half. He was just a good old-fashioned public servant. The treatment of him by this coalition government is absolutely abysmal. This particular individual, who had served the government loyally, was butchered and made a scapegoat for the mistakes of politicians, not his own.
I asked Senator Hill at the estimates committee hearings whether Mr Mellors was sacked and DAS abolished out of revenge. Senator Hill said the following:

The Prime Minister blames his colleagues for the ministerial problems. But there certainly has been a view that some of these matters could have been administered more effectively than they have been.

We have had that debate going on all year. Now it is time to put on the public record who had the debate, when they had the debate, what the sequence of the debate was and how the politicians intervened to put the fix in on DAS to stop them reviewing administration of these entitlements. I intend to go into that in some detail.

The issue has its genesis in the fact that there was a DAS inquiry in 1994 into the now Prime Minister, Mr Howard, sending out letters in support of Liberal Party candidates in the New South Wales postal workers union ballot. That prompted the then Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Walker, to ask, `Just how precise are the definitions about entitlements and what should we do about it?' This was reinforced by Mr Codd's inquiry into Mr Alan Griffiths in the so-called sandwich shop affair where, again, there was a blurring of lines.

What happened is that Mr Walker said, `We'll have to review these things.' He authorised the writing of letters to all political leaders saying, `Here is a proposed set of revised guidelines and definitions, please respond.' Everyone responded: the Democrats responded and I think the government responded. Mr Howard sent a letter off which said that he had received Mr Walker's letter. A month later, Mr Howard then sent back a letter querying various aspects in Mr Walker's letter. Why should I raise this now? I am raising it to show that, back in 1995, Mr Howard, the then Leader of the Opposition and who subsequently became Prime Minister, knew there were problems in the administration of parliamentary entitlements, especially with the definitions.

So the coalition won government, and one of the first things that Mr Jull was advised of by Mr Mellors was the need to review the administration of parliamentary entitlements. Mr Jull, in a burst of enthusiasm as a new minister, wrote off to everyone. Guess what? There was no response from the Prime Minister's office on this subject—we are talking about September-October 1996—no response whatsoever. Mr Morris did not respond; Mr Howard did not respond. I understand that Mr Fischer and Senator Kernot responded. However, not to leave the matter there, Mr Sam Skrzypek did a background paper, which was ready by December 1996—I stress that he is not part of the ministerial and parliamentary services section—and suggested that this whole area needed to be looked at and reformed.

We then move to 18 December 1996. A minute was sent to the Secretary to the Department of Administrative Services, Mr Mellors, proposing draft terms of reference for an inquiry into the remuneration, entitlements and facilities for senators and members. This was discussed on that day between Mr Mellors and the then minister, Mr Jull.

By 2 January 1997, a further minute was produced proposing the actual draft terms of reference and a draft letter to the Prime Minister. The issues in this minute and letter included: first, a fundamental review based on developing the Skrzypek paper; second, improved services to members, which would be the Coopers and Lybrand report; and, third, fix Comcar once and for all—my source puts in (Ho, ho, ho). So they were the three issues put in that particular minute. The then Secretary to DAS, Mr Mellors, asked the Deputy Secretary, Mr Michael Clarke, to put a bit of flesh around this particular matter. So on 3 January 1997, we had the first cut of the budget submission. There was then a meeting on 10 January to discuss this particular cabinet submission. Present were Mr Michael Clarke, Mr John Mackay, Mr Graham Semmens, Mr Gary Gordon and Ms Anne Hazell.

Finally, though, we get to the position on 5 February, and this should be noted in detail. There was a further draft cabinet submission. It contained a reference to a review of entitlements. However, Mr Jull's senior adviser reported that he had `tested the waters', that there was no need to rock the boat and that this recommendation should be taken out of the cabinet submission. I understand the evidence for that is in a file note in the Department of Administrative Services that records, at the time, Mr Sutherland's comments and also records that the minister, Mr Jull, was present when Mr Sutherland gave that direction. When the final draft cabinet submission was produced on 7 February, all reference to a review of the entitlements was expunged. It no longer exists. On 14 February, the final budget cabinet submission was finalised—totally unchanged from the one of 7 February.

I will put this in context before I go on to how we did get a review. What we have heard from the current Prime Minister is, `Oh, look, the previous government never touched parliamentary entitlements. It is our great reform in government that touched this particular area,' yet we know that when Mr Howard was written to in September-October 1995, he only noted his response and then put up technical questions. When he was written to again in September 1996, he did not even have the courtesy to reply to his minister. He did not even note that he had received the letter, let alone reply on the substance.

Interestingly enough, a whole month goes by from 5 February, when this was taken out of the submission, to an answer given by Mr Jull in the parliament. What happened meanwhile was that the Senator Colston matters, and the Senator Woods matters and other matters came to light. Mr Jull went into the parliament and announced that KPMG was going to do a study into the way DAS was administering entitlements. In later press releases of about six weeks ago, when there was a Bulletin article explaining all of the history of this, Mr Jull said, `Oh, no, I just happened to substitute what the Mellors and DAS point of view was for my own.' The point to note is that a full month went by before we heard anything.

When Mr Jull came into the parliament and announced an inquiry into this, he gave his department half an hour's notice. He also gave Mr Baxter, who was doing the report, half an hour's notice. In other words, this was not the planned principal move—as Mr Jull and the Prime Minister like to explain—this was a panic move to head things off at question time. DAS gets informed half an hour before, `We're going to do a review. We're going to employ Mr Baxter. Mr Baxter has just been told'—none of all this post-rationalisation of, `Oh, we thought it would be a quicker result with Mr Baxter.' There is a critically missing month. In that month there was a conscious decision by this government not to have a review of parliamentary entitlements on 5 February. As Mr Sutherland said to the meeting, `Don't rock the boat. We're not interested in this particular area. Delete it out of the cabinet submission. We'll bury it and we'll forget about it.' It was only when the pressure came on and the panic came on that we got this inquiry.

The relevance to this particular clause is that we have a public servant, Mr Mellors, who has done precisely the right thing. Initial ly, he recommended to his minister, `This area needs addressing. Please have an inquiry. Let's reform this area.' The initial reaction of the minister was quite good. He wrote to people along these lines. But when the pressure came on and the waters were tested—when, I assume, Mr Sutherland rushed around and talked to Mr Grahame Morris—suddenly this got jettisoned off. So it is not good enough for Senator Hill to say that there were weaknesses in the department. Those weaknesses, if they exist, had a political origin and the government failed to act, having these things brought to their attention, at the right time to reform this particular area.

What we have is a public servant being blamed for mistakes by ministers. He has copped the blame. He has lost his job. We will hear all the fiction you like from Senator Hill that DAS was abolished for efficiency and rationalisation. Heavens to Betsy! There was not one background paper in PM&C prior to 1 October.

When I asked Senator Hill on 4 June in the estimates committee whether there were any plans to abolish DAS, I got absolutely no response that that was being contemplated. Last Friday when we asked Mr Len Early, Deputy Secretary to the Department of Finance and Administration, what savings there would be from the amalgamation he said, `Oh, there won't be any. We don't anticipate any savings.' In other words, the attack on DAS was a political one. It was motivated by revenge, scapegoating, `Let's shift the blame. Let's get square. Let's get rid of DAS because that's the way we lost three ministers.'

It could all have been prevented if the ministers had accepted the proper advice that was tendered to them by DAS and had authorised a proper inquiry either back in September or in February as a result of budget cabinet. You can have all these clauses you like—56, 57, 58—talking about the appointments of secretaries, talking about terminations, but when push comes to shove, when governments can find a victim and shift blame, they will do it. There was never a clearer example. I might go on in a moment and discuss exactly the way the government gave Mr Mellors the push.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was an interesting contribution by Senator Robert Ray. I shall have to think about that at some length.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not speak for as long in this contribution. I want to go through exactly how Mr Mellors got the boot and put that on the public record. I suppose Mr Mellors and his deputy, who is regarded as directly responsible for these errors, had a rough idea they were for the dump when they attended the Prime Minister's office on Wednesday, 24 September—
—Robert, have you read the Herald today?

—Thank you, Senator Heffernan. Why don't you go up and spin to the gallery like you always do? You have not got a word up in two years. Go on, off you go! Why don't you go around to the Prime Minister's office and ask the Prime Minister, Senator Heffernan, about his meeting with Mr Mellors and Mr Godfrey in his office on the morning of Wednesday, 24 September?

SPEECH.PARA: By this stage the Prime Minister knew that Mr Sharp and maybe even Mr Scott were in a bit of strife. It was then that he was informed that Mr McGauran had made a whole series of paybacks. An hysterical Prime Minister then told those two people that DAS was a disgrace and had let the government down badly. We know from the previous contribution I made that DAS did not let them down at all, but they got a rough idea that they were going to be targeted as first cab off the rank when it came to revenge.

When the government finally got through its traumas and decided to abolish DAS, Mr Mellors wrote cabinet‐in‐confidence to the then acting Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Ruddock, pointing out the whole history of his efforts not only to get this area reformed but also to get it back on track. He also wrote to Mr Max Moore‐Wilton, head of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, putting two requests. In his first request he said, `Look, if DAS is going to be abolished and I am made the scapegoat—and it will be most unfair if I am—will there at least be some negotiation about my departure in terms of remuneration?' In his second request he asked for there to be some public acknowledgment of the job he had done as Secretary to the Department of Administrative Services. He may not have agreed with all the downsizing that occurred there, but he was allocated the task of doing it and he did it. He strictly followed the government's instructions.
He has never had a written response to that letter with his two requests. When he tried to have a verbal discussion with Mr Max Moore‐Wilton, guess what? He was not available.

TALK.START.PARA: —Too busy—

—I anticipate the interjection, Senator Faulkner. He is too busy knocking the backs and sides off bus shelters. It is serious. Mr Mellors is an individual who has spent decades in the Public Service. He gave loyal service to the previous government and this one and he implicitly carried out the requests of this government, yet the senior bureaucrat did not give him the time of day for five days. He did not return his phone calls. He treated him like a leper, like a pariah. When Mr Mellors finally got to see the great helmsman of Prime Minister and Cabinet, he is at least informed that his requests went to the Prime Minister and the Prime Minister knocked him back.

SPEECH.PARA: We know what a vengeful, nasty little individual this Prime Minister can be, but surely that is one of the lowest acts he has perpetrated so far in his 20 months in power. If there have been problems in this government they have been because of ministerial error—it is not just restricted to this government, I concede. It is ministerial error; it is not Public Service error. There was no point in making Mr Mellors the target in all this, but he is. Had Mr Mellors been approached reasonably, I am sure he would have gone, and gone as gracefully as he could. I do not think he saw himself as having a much longer Public Service career; he had been around and he had been a departmental secretary for some time. But why not do it with just a touch of grace, just a touch of kindness? No, it just could not be done.

BREAK.PARA: It could not be done because, to justify themselves, this coalition government had to have its element of revenge. It had to pick someone out to punish. So it picks out Mr Mellors and shoves him aside. It picks out Mr Godfrey. First we are told that there will not be a new deputy secretary position in the new DoFA and then suddenly there is, but Mr Godfrey is marked down for some sort of political reason. I am at a loss to know why. Six others in the senior executive service are hanging out to dry. The great irony is: the people they hung out to dry were not the leakers; they are still there in some form.

If DAS misbehaved, I am not here to defend them, but I do not think there is any great evidence that they have misbehaved. I have not seen the various reports. Obviously, the Auditor‐General's report is only going to go into audit matters. I have not seen Mr Kennedy's report, but I have seen the staff circular that he was kind enough to table in relation to it. I do not want to embarrass Mr Kennedy, but it seemed to me a very balanced, classic Public Service report, done with fairness to everyone and with the appropriate methodology. If that has not turned up any misbehaviour in DAS and if the Auditor‐General does not turn up any misbehaviour in DAS, why was it abolished and why were these various people punished?

It is one thing to sack people, but they treated them so abysmally. Redundancy offers were made in one case and then suspended for a month while some cloud hung over their head, and whisperers were saying, `So and so might have bought a raffle ticket from the Labor Party in 1984. We don't know for sure, but we've heard the rumour, so mark that person down.' Where are we going with these issues to have people treated in this way?

As I said, 11 departmental secretaries have gone. At best, you could say that two went through natural attrition, one went to a better job, six were purged for political reasons and one in particular was just made a scapegoat. At the very minimum, Mr Howard or one of his ministers could have had the grace to acknowledge the role that Mr Mellors played in government. I am sure Mr Jull would have, but he was no longer around in an official position. I am sure Mr Jull does not feel that at any stage Mr Mellors let him down but, in fact, there is nothing he can do about it at the moment. What we have is a situation—it does not matter what are in these clauses—which needs a philosophical approach by government as to where the Public Service is and the degree to which it is politicised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fundamental decency.

—As my leader interjects, it needs fundamental decency. None of these decencies have been observed. This government has said it is a reforming government with regard to parliamentary entitlements; the record shows the opposite. The record shows that at the critical moment on 5 February when this government, without any pressure from any scandals or anything else, could have reviewed parliamentary entitlements and definitions—it was in the budget submission—it got knocked out because they tested the waters.

BREAK.PARA: I am not sure that everyone knows what `test the waters' means. It means, your political operative in the minister's office slips around, probably sees Mr Reith, Mr Morris and a couple of the other movers and shakers in government and says, `What do you think of this?' They say, `Don't rock the boat.' So he came back to a meeting and said, `Don't rock the boat.' Mr Jull did not intervene. Suddenly it slipped out of the cabinet submission and a whole month went by with nothing happening. It was only when the issue broke, the government was under pressure and it panicked, that suddenly it had two simultaneous inquiries into these areas.

That is understandable, but what I really hate is the post‐rationalisation because they did not think we knew about the circumstances. They now say, `We're the reforming government. We're looking into these things.' They looked into them with a gun at their head and when they had the opportunity to do something about it they totally failed the test. So it is no use Mr Jull—after the Laurie Oakes article—or Mr Howard or anyone else ever putting the argument that they were determined to reform these areas. Mr Howard had his chance in 1995 and failed to properly respond to Mr Walker's request. Mr Howard had his chance in 1996 when he did not even bother to reply to Mr Jull's letter. Mr Howard had his chance at budget cabinet and he failed again. The only time he intervened was when this government had problems.

I understand, in these clauses you need flexibility to appoint and terminate agency heads or departmental secretaries—however you refer to them. All I say is: it does not matter what the government's view is, what the opposition amendments are or the Democrats' amendments are; in the end, when it comes to agency heads, governments will do absolutely what they like.

If that is the case, I make this plea: that they come out and honestly say why they are terminating a departmental secretary—because they think the person is politically biased, because they think they are incompetent or, in this last case, `Because we're trying to shift blame. We're looking for a scapegoat and if we've got to lose three ministers, two Prime Ministerial staffers and one departmental official'—unfairly as it turns out—`if we have to do all that, we're going to put a bit of stick around and have a bit of revenge.' The trouble is, they sought revenge on the very people who lived up to the top ethical standards of the Public Service, anticipated trouble, recommended remedies which a political fix knocked out, and then they became the victims. It is absolutely pathetic.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (52) Clause 57, page 28 (lines 13 to 15), omit the clause, substitute:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Secretary of a Department, under the Agency Minister, is responsible for the general working, and all the business, of the Department and is to advise the Agency Minister in all matters relating to the Department.

(2) The Secretary of a Department has a duty to assist the Agency Minister to fulfil his or her accountability obligations to the Parliament by providing full and accurate information to the Parliament about the factual and technical background to policies and their administration.

SPEECH.PARA: (53) Clause 58, page 29 (line 4), at the end of subclause (5), add "but shall be paid remuneration in respect of one office only".

Amendment No. 52 goes to clause 57, which relates to the responsibilities of secretaries for managing a department. The provision as drafted has very little to say about the responsibility of secretaries. The opposition with these amendments is picking up recommendations of the McLeod report, preserving the language of section 25(2) of the current act and adding some very worthwhile detail about the nature of a secretary's responsibilities.

Amendment No. 53 adds to clause 58, which contains the words `appointment etc. of secretary', the words `but shall be paid remuneration in respect of one office only'. This reflects a sensible provision in the current act.

In relation to the aforementioned Mr Max Moore‐Wilton, he appears to concentrate most of his time on the minutiae outside what one would expect would be the normal role and responsibility of a Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. For example, in the last year he has probably given a greater focus to removing the walls at the back of a bus shelter outside the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet than probably to anything else. I think Senator Ray would point out that one thing you would have to say is that at least Mr Moore‐Wilton has been successful in that endeavour.
