I suppose we should give credit where credit is due on this occasion—he has actually delivered, even if self‐interest was what appeared to drive him on in this regard. Of course, Mr Moore‐Wilton has been mentioned before. He was appointed with a special deal as to a couple of directorships. They have now been completed, but the point remains that secretaries ought to be paid remuneration in respect of one office only.

I commend these amendments to the committee. I have taken a little liberty in relation to the issue of the words `in respect of one office only', as senators who have been following the debate would know. However, the point is well made in relation to other matters that have been discussed previously in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats think these amendments are important. Senator Ray drew attention to the politicisation of the Public Service, and I think that is why we need to take whatever steps we can, whether they are symbolic or real, to make sure that this legislation reflects the independent rather than the politicised nature of the Public Service.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 52 spells out that a secretary has a duty to assist the relevant minister to fulfil his or her accountability obligations—and `accountability' is the operative word. As the bill currently stands, the secretary to a department, under the agency minister, is responsible for managing the department, and that is as far as it goes. We think this cuts to the heart of the issue of Public Service accountability; going beyond the government of the day and extending to the parliament and the public. We also think the insertion into the act of this additional duty sends a very important signal to secretaries. For that reason, we strongly support the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes these amendments. I will not take up as much time on these two clauses as the opposition has. It is obvious that they think they are very important, but we had been making good progress until then.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the things that the opposition complained about took place under legislation which they brought in and which related to how the government dealt with various secretaries. I will not comment in detail about what Senator Ray and Senator Faulkner said; suffice to say that amendment No. 52 has two parts. The first part would replace the words of the bill with the language that is currently employed in section 25(2) of the present Public Service Act. The new wording in the bill will reflect the nature of the new employment framework, as the government has set out in paragraph 7.7 of the explanatory memorandum.

It is our view that this amendment is unnecessary. The government prefers the more modern formulation that I have just referred to. In relation to amendment No. 53, which seeks to restrict the payment of secretaries to be in respect of one office only, this is unnecessary, the government believes, given clause 61, which enables the Prime Minister to fix remuneration. In fixing remuneration, he would be able to have regard to any multiple appointments. That is clearly an aspect which the Prime Minister would have in mind. For those reasons, the government opposes these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I would like the questions to be put separately. In respect of amendment No. 52, I know what the minister is saying. He is talking about the secretary to a department, under the agency minister, being responsible for managing the department. It is a management concept. I think that is fine, but that is really what the amendment put forward by the opposition implies. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . is responsible for the general working, and all the business, of the Department and is to advise the Agency Minister in all matters relating to the Department.

That is of course under the agency minister. Ministerial responsibility is not at all affected by the amendment put forward by the opposition. I believe the concept of management is not affected because what it really says is that he is responsible for the general working and all the business of the department—and what is that if it is not managing the department?

Proposed new clause 57(2) includes accountability to parliament in the legislation. I believe that is a very important matter. As we would all know, anything that is in legislation which would uphold and promote the parliament's audit and control functions over executive government decisions, decisions of their departments and the disbursement of taxpayer's funds by those departments is to be supported, so I am supporting that. I am not supporting the other amendment that is in this bracket.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was disappointed to hear that Senator Harradine will not support opposition amendment 53. This bill says that the same person may hold more than one office of secretary. That is the same as applies currently, but the current act says that you can hold more than one office of secretary but you can only be paid for one. I think that is a very important qualification. That is why the opposition has moved this amendment, and I ask Senator Harradine to give that some serious consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: That is why the opposition proposes in opposition amendment 53 to add to subclause (5), in relation to the same person holding more than one office of secretary, the words `but shall be paid remuneration in respect of one office only'. Otherwise you would quite clearly have the circumstance where, effectively, a secretary could receive a remuneration package that would be utterly inappropriate. I think this amendment has merit. It does not affect the flexibility that currently exists under the Public Service Act for an individual to hold two offices of secretary, but it does say that if you do that you are not going to draw two or more salaries.
Amendment No. 52 agreed to.
Amendment No. 53 not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (10) Clause 58, page 28 (line 17), omit "Prime Minister may", substitute "Governor‐General may, on the recommendation of the Prime Minister,".
(11) Clause 58, page 28 (line 20), omit "making an appointment of", substitute "recommending the appointment of a person as".
(12) Clause 58, page 18 (line 23), omit "making an appointment of", substitute "recommending the appointment of a person as".

Amendments 10 to 15 remove the power of the Prime Minister to appoint and terminate the secretaries of the departments. The first group within that, amendments 10 to 12, is about appointment. These amendments restore the responsibility to the Governor‐General, acting of course on the recommendation of the Prime Minister.

Whilst we appreciate that this makes very little difference in reality—although we do think it is important that the Prime Minister of the day be obliged to give the head of state some explanation as to why a secretary is being appointed or terminated—more importantly the Democrats hold a strong view that there is an important and significant symbolic value in having the Governor‐General rather than the Prime Minister approving and appointing departmental heads.

We are strongly of the view that the changes proposed by the government do not give sufficient weight to the notion of the Public Service being something other than the servant of the government of the day. Formally vesting the powers to hire and fire secretaries in the Prime Minister suggests that the Public Service is owned by the government of the day. Vesting those same powers in the Governor‐General suggests a broader community ownership of the Public Service.

The Democrats believe that there needs to be some statutory or legislative signal that Public Service heads are not in the pocket, as it were, of the Prime Minister and the government. We look on the Governor‐General, in this sense, as our head of state. A president would presumably serve the same function in an Australian republic. We are not attempting to shift control of the Public Service away from the executive. We are simply saying that there should be a higher authority, even if it is only one which is nominal, and that should reflect the idea that the Public Service does more than simply serve the government of the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a very interesting statement that Senator Allison made. I would like to hear what the minister has to say about this. It does seem to entrench a spoils system, in the American sense, without any of the confirmation proceedings that are there. It is generally regarded that a spoils system, without any restraint, is not a good one. That is a dramatic change, probably a radical change, in the way things have been done up until now.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments are opposed by the government. As Senator Allison alluded to, the current role of the Governor-General is on the advice of the Prime Minister. This role that the government is giving to the Prime Minister in the legislation is one which it believes is appropriate and, in any event, as Senator Allison has said, is not much different. We fail to see where the radical departure is. We simply say that it is for the government of the day to implement its policies, and it is appropriate that the appointment be by the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think on this issue the case that the minister puts has some merit. I would remind the committee that this particular matter was considered by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. It reached a view reported on page 160 of its report. Paragraph 12.76 said:

SPEECH.PARA: However, the Committee accepts that in practice the current process of appointment and termination of secretaries being made by the Governor-General is heavily influenced by the power only being able to be exercised in accordance with advice that is consistent with a recommendation by the Prime Minister.
Paragraph 12.77 said:
The Committee accepts that the approach proposed in the Bill reflects the reality that such matters rest with the Prime Minister of the day and therefore supports the proposed changes.

I think that is a reality. Senator Allison's amendments would have the effect of maintaining the constitutional arrangements whereby the agency heads are appointed by the Governor-General. Clearly, the constitution provides for such arrangements, according to section 67 of the constitution, until the parliament otherwise provides. I think this is a sensible reform. I was persuaded by the evidence I heard at the joint committee and I would not say the eloquence of the arguments of Senator Ellison but nevertheless the strength of the arguments on this particular matter. For those reasons, the opposition will be opposing Democrat amendments 10 to 12.
Amendments not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (54) Clause 59, page 29 (line 12), at the end of subclause (2), add "and another Secretary to be nominated by the Commissioner".
(55) Clause 59, page 29 (line 15), omit "the Secretary of the Prime Minister's Department", substitute "the Commissioner and the Secretary of the Prime Minister's Department".
(56) Clause 59, page 29 (lines 16 and 17), omit subclause (4).

These are amendments to clause 59 of the bill, termination of appointment. In relation to opposition amendments 54 and 55, we believe that the approach we are outlining here involving both the commissioner and one other secretary will provide better protection than proposed in the bill against capricious or unjustified dismissal.

The argument for opposition amendment 56, which is to delete subclause (4), is very similar to that in the debate we have had earlier. I do not want to get bogged down in it again. I think the minister is probably of the same mind. This is the issue of whether secretaries are covered or are not covered by the unfair dismissals provisions of the Workplace Relations Act. If they are not covered, then it is the case that the clause is really unnecessary.

I would have liked to hear a clearer explanation on the issue of coverage than we have hitherto received from the minister. I am doubtful that will be forthcoming in this context. It may be that senators will suggest that the committee put amendments 54 and 55 together and 56 separately in the circumstances that evolved from the previous debate around the issue of the application or coverage of the unfair dismissals provisions of the WRA.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats support these amendments. Once again, we believe that unfair dismissal provisions of the Workplace Relations Act should apply across the board to all APS employees, from secretaries right through to the most junior APS employee. We do not agree with the Prime Minister holding complete powers over the appointment and termination of departmental secretaries, as our subsequent suggestion will make clear. We will want to talk about amendments 59 and 60 in this light when those two amendments come forward.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought perhaps in relation to secretaries of departments the minister might be able to give the committee a categorical assurance that division 3 of part VIA of the Workplace Relations Act does not apply. I assume that the minister on this occasion could be absolutely categorical in his assurance. If he is able to give such a categorical assurance, he might explain why subclause (4) of clause 59 is required.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes all three amendments. I will deal with amendments 54 and 55 first. They sit in a somewhat different situation from amendment 56 and perhaps it may be appropriate to take them separately. In relation to clause 59, dealing with termination of employment, the government considers that the inclusion of another secretary in the process which is outlined in 59(2) is cumbersome; it adds an additional process. It is considered to be sufficient that the commissioner can deal with this matter and not have a secretary of another department sitting in judgment of a peer.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to amendment 55, again this involves another additional process which the government feels is not appropriate. It is considered that in this situation it is cumbersome to have the commissioner involved in the process which is outlined in clause 59(3).

With respect to amendment 56, which deals with clause 59(4), that goes back to the debate that we have been having for the last two days on the Workplace Relations Act. The situation in that regard dealing with secretaries is that neither the wages nor conditions of secretaries are subject to an award and their annual remuneration exceeds $66,200. This would exclude them from the Workplace Relations Act, or the provisions mentioned earlier, in division 3. I am advised that they may, however, be covered by the Workplace Relations Act if they are considered to be Commonwealth employees. The exclusion, as I understand it, in statute, confirms that to be not the case—that they are excluded from division 3. I think that answers the question.
Amendments Nos 54 and 55 not agreed to.
Amendment No. 56 agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —We move on to Democrat amendments 13 to 15 on sheet 770.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I spoke to these amendments earlier. Clearly there is no support for them but I will put them in any case. I seek leave to move them together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (13) Clause 59, page 29 (lines 8 and 9), omit "Prime Minister may", substitute "Governor‐General may, on the advice of the Prime Minister".
(14) Clause 59, page 29 (line 10), omit "terminating", substitute "advising the Governor‐General to terminate".
(15) Clause 59, page 29 (line 13), omit "terminating", substitute "advising the Governor‐General to terminate".
Amendments not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move

SPEECH.PARA: (59) Heading to Part 8, page 31 (line 2), omit the heading, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Part 8—Management Advisory Committee and Consultative Council

SPEECH.PARA: (60) Page 31 (after line 14), after clause 64, insert:

PARA.TAB: (1) There is to be an APS Consultative Council with the function of making reports and recommendations on matters of general interest in relation to the APS.
(2) The Council consists of the following persons:

TAB.TAB: (a) the Commissioner;
(b) Secretaries of Agencies, as nominated by the Commissioner;
(c) representatives of employees, including nominees of the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

SPEECH.PARA: This goes to the issue of the APS Consultative Council and the opposition's proposal in relation to that. I think section 23 of the current act provides for a joint council which, as I understand it, the government is not proposing to replace. Although the joint council has fallen into disuse over the past couple of years, I think unions are keen to maintain the council, or something like it, as a consultative forum which would deal with APS‐wide issues.

The problem is that the government's proposed management advisory committee does not fulfil this sort of role. It just deals with advice to government on management matters. The preference of the opposition is to maintain a two‐tier advisory structure. I have to say in relation to the consultative council proposal that it is really based on the joint council model which I think was first set up during the time of Prime Minister Ben Chifley.
Senator Harradine interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly has a history, Senator Harradine. I am sorry I did not hear that interjection, but no doubt Senator Harradine will inform us in a moment. I commend these amendments to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats support the establishment of an APS Consultative Council. We think it should have a different function and composition from the management advisory committee. We think it is important for the government to establish a process by which it can receive recommendations on matters of general interest and concern in relation to the APS. However, I would ask Senator Faulkner if he would consider amending his amendment to state in subclause (2) that the council `shall include' the following persons, rather than `consists of'.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that that amendment is far too prescriptive to limit membership of the council to those three groups. If the intention is to establish a genuine consultative group, I do not think we should rule out, for instance, having academics with a strong public sector research background or perhaps even former public servants or representatives of various consumer or professional groups. If Senator Faulkner would consider moving that alteration, we would support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am willing to accept that proposal of Senator Allison.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (by Senator Allison) proposed:
Subclause 64A (2), omit `consists of', substitute "shall include".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to go back one step. I am not inclined to support the opposition's amendment. I will be voting against the amendment to the amendment and against the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (Senator Allison's) not agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that amendments Nos 59 and 60 be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask a couple of questions. First of all, I want to make an observation. I am aware of the history of the consultative council. It has had a very long history. I can recall that very often on the ACT executive we used to get reports about this, but not so many because the trade union movement in those days was not as dominated as it is these days by public sector organisations, not that I am saying that is necessarily a backward step. I would not comment on that matter right here and now.

SPEECH.PARA: What I want to say so everybody knows is that the consultative council is not functioning in the way it was designed to function. As I see it, this is a management advisory committee that is being proposed by the government. It has people on that management advisory committee that are, really, self‐selected, who believe they need to go on the management advisory committee. I think the government should appreciate the fact, and I am sure it does, that there is a need, if the service is going to operate smoothly, for input by the employees or representatives of the employees of the service. I would ask the minister to give some indication and guarantee to the committee as to how the viewpoints of the employees are going to be taken account of by the management advisory committee.

Is it likely that other persons nominated by the secretary of the Prime Minister's depart ment may well include people who would be able to give the viewpoint of the public servants—the employees—so that that can be taken into account by the management advisory committee? We have been along this track plenty of times over the years in various areas of consultation between managers and staff representatives, employee representatives and union representatives. That can only smooth over the problems that managers might foresee. Could the minister give us an indication as to whether that would be something that the government would see as desirable—that is to say, having somebody on the MAC who would be able to express the viewpoints generally of the employees in respect of management matters?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to that last matter put by Senator Harradine, the government has not made any firm decision on this, Senator Harradine. I have heard your argument, which is a good one, and I will certainly take it up with the minister and ensure that this aspect of the debate is considered by the government. I do not think I can take it further than that in the circumstances. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Clauses 6 and 7, page 9 (line 21) to page 10 (line 23), omit the clauses, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 6 Rights of first‐ and second‐tier persons

TAB.TAB: First‐ and second‐tier persons retain all the rights conferred on them by the old Act, except for rights to reassessment for reintegration or reappointment.

SPEECH.PARA: This, again, is a very important amendment. It is designed to grandfather the rights currently conferred on first and second tier persons by the old act, with the exception of the right to reassessment for reintegration or reappointment. Of course, the procedures for that have fallen into abeyance in recent years.

The most significant of these rights are the so‐called mobility rights; the rights of current and former public servants who are in public employment other than Public Service departments to return to employment in the Public Service. The bill provides for APS employees to retain their current mobility rights only for a transitional period which the government now proposes will be three years, after which such rights will become a matter of discretion for the head of the agency to which the relevant employee is attached.

The opposition considers the government's proposals on mobility to amount to a retrospective removal of an important condition of employment. Mobility rights have been an important consideration for many APS employees in deciding to accept offers of alternative employment. We are strongly of the view that it is not acceptable to remove these rights after such decisions have been made.

We note the government's proposals in schedule 2 of the draft commissioner's directions in relation to former employees of the Department of Veterans' Affairs and former APS employees who now work for the ACT and the Northern Territory Public Services, but we consider that they fall far short of fair treatment. We are particularly concerned here about the impact of removal of mobility rights from people employed by ministers and opposition office holders under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act.

The opposition takes the view that governments and the Public Service have at both levels benefited from the frequent movement of people between Parliament House and government departments. We made this point at some length during the hearings of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. Parliament has benefited from the knowledge of the bureaucracy that departmental officers bring with them and departments benefit from the knowledge of political, parliamentary and legislative processes that those who go back to departments take with them. The benefits far outweigh the slight inconvenience to Public Service managers caused by the uncertainty as to when former employees might seek to return. This has not in the past been an unmanageable burden for departments.

The opposition believes that this cross‐fertilisation is very good for our system of government and that it should be encouraged rather than discouraged. That is why the former Labor government initiated the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act in 1984. The mechanism for encouraging such cross‐fertilisation is the preservation of mobility rights during the term of MOPS employment, and removal of these rights will discourage such movement.

We find this very hard to comprehend. It is hard to believe that that is what the government is really seeking. There is also an issue of natural justice. Many MOPS employees have taken the decision to accept their current employment in Parliament House, for the most part in ministerial offices, on the basis that they retain rights of return to their departments for the duration of their employment under MOPS. Staffers know, particularly in the light of the recent destruction of government ranks, that there is little security for them in political employment. I can think of some staff who were working for ministers in the last few months who have now learnt that lesson. We all know it; it is not unique to one side of the parliament or to the coalition parties. It is a fact of political life for people who are employed in a ministers' office.

These mobility rights compensate for that lack of security—it is that important. If the government is determined to remove mobility rights, they should be removed only from APS employees who transfer to other eligible public employment after the entry into force of the new legislation, in the prior knowledge, for those people, that they would have not right of return. Those who transferred on the basis that they enjoyed such rights ought to retain them, as far as we are concerned. That is what our amendment to clauses 6 and 7 is designed to achieve. We consider this a very important amendment of issues that gained a lot of debate and concentration of effort during the work of the Joint Committee of Public Account. They are worthy of serious attention and I commend the amendment to the Senate.

These things really have to be looked at. I would be very interested to hear what the government has to say in response to what Senator Faulkner has said.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the opposition supports the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1997 (No. 2) and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1997. These bills collectively propose to amend the temporary Commonwealth tax safety net arrangements concerning tobacco which were implemented after the High Court invalidated the business franchise fees levied by the states and territories in relation to tobacco, alcohol and petrol.

SPEECH.PARA: The customs and excise bills propose new arrangements for the taxation of tobacco. Prior to the High Court decision, tobacco was taxed under Commonwealth excise, which taxed on the basis of weight, and state franchise fees, which taxed on the basis of the value of the products. The original safety net arrangement involved an increase in the Commonwealth excise of $167 per kilogram. This significantly altered the taxation of various tobacco products. This, in turn, would have flowed on to significant alterations to retail prices and would have affected the relative profits of the manufacturers.

The new proposals will replace this weight based system with a combined weight based and ad valorem, or value based, system which equates as far as possible with the situation prior to the High Court decision. The changes under the customs and excise bills will result in a decrease of $288 million in revenue. However, there is no financial effect on the Commonwealth as the moneys from the safety net arrangements are all on‐passed to the states and territories. Under these on‐passing arrangements, each state and territory receives a separate fixed share of the safety net revenue for tobacco, petroleum and alcohol.

Another bill which will be dealt with later today, the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997, is related to these bills. That bill proposes to give effect to a request by the states and territories to alter their shares of revenue replacement payments for tobacco under the safety net arrangements arising from the change in the method of imposing tax. That bill is also seeking authority to set any future changes to the distribution of alcohol, tobacco and petrol revenues by regulation to avoid the need for additional legislation. Having made those remarks, I indicate, as I said earlier, that the opposition supports the bills.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TITLE.XREF: AUSTRALIA NEW ZEALAND FOOD AUTHORITY AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Senator Parer:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australia New Zealand Food Authority Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 is listed today as non‐controversial and indeed that is the case. However, it is important that I briefly put on the record the history of the bill because the government is proposing a significant number of amendments to it. Whilst we support the thrust of the amendments that are to be moved today—which will enable passage of the bill—there are, nevertheless, some issues of concern which the opposition needs to put on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: When this bill first came before the Senate it related to another bill introduced last year, the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Amendment Bill 1996. The major thrust of those two bills was to implement changes to enable the Australia New Zealand Food Authority to impose a system of charges upon companies seeking approval of changes to food standards. If it had been enacted, it would have been a new feature of the operations of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority because, for the first time, it would have been able to charge companies for the work that was required in giving approval to food standards.

The history had been that food standards applications would be made to the Australia New Zealand Food Authority, would be dealt with as they came in. The Australia New Zealand Food Authority argued that it needed the flexibility to impose charges in order to prioritise its work and enable it to give sufficient time to dealing with some other key issues, including the review of the overall food standards code and a range of other matters that the authority is currently addressing.

The legislation was referred to the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee which issued a report in June of this year. In that report it was indicated—by the opposition and, I think, in respect of at least one aspect supported by the Democrats—that we had serious concerns about proposals which, firstly, related to the imposition of these charges and, secondly, related to giving the authority the capacity to employ persons as non‐public servants.

We indicated in that report that we would be opposing those aspects of the legislation. The legislation has been on the list for some time and is now back before the Senate. On this occasion, the government has indicated that it does not wish to proceed with the two aspects that were controversial—that is, the provisions relating to charges or a system of fees and charges in the future and the provisions relating to employment of non‐public service staff.

In essence, the government has decided not to proceed with the fundamental basis upon which the legislation was put forward and was considered by the Senate committee. However, in the amendments that the government is putting forward today, the government has said that they will not be proceeding with those aspects of the bill that were controversial. Rather they wish to amend the legislation to provide for the establishment of the position of chief executive officer within the authority. Currently, the authority is staffed by a chairperson. I understand the chairperson is full time and there is no position of chief executive officer.

We in the opposition do not oppose these proposals, but I do want to place firmly on the record our concern about the procedure that has been adopted. When the legislation was put before the Senate and considered by the committee there was no reference at all to any proposal to establish this new position of CEO. The Senate committee addressed what was in the bill at that time. Now the Senate is being presented with the same bill, but it has been significantly amended to establish a new position of chief executive officer.

We are prepared to support that. We do so clearly on the basis that that is an appropriate course of action and the government will, through its amendments, not be proceeding with the other aspects that I referred to— namely, the charges and the intended future employment of persons who would not be covered by the Public Service Act. I wish to register our concern that I do not think it is appropriate that the committee was unable to consider the issues that are the subject of the amendments to this amendment bill.

I am advised as a result of my discussions with industry that they were not made aware formally; I am not sure whether they were made aware of this informally, of the government's latest proposals—that is, to establish this position of chief executive officer. In my discussions with the industry, who did appear before the original Senate inquiry, I found that they are not unhappy with this proposal. I know that they would certainly wish it to be recorded that they feel somewhat aggrieved that, whilst they did participate in the earlier proceedings before the Senate committee, they were not made aware of the latest set of changes.

We will be supporting the government's amendments to the bill on the basis that I have outlined except that we will be opposing items 25 and 26 of schedule 1 as circulated on sheet 698. Schedule 1, items 25 and 26, page 9 lines 11 to 24 are the provisions currently in the bill which would enable the authority to employ persons other than as public servants. We will be opposing that provision. I understand the government will not be seeking to pursue those matters and will accept our opposition to it. We will support the bill except for those items.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to request that the Senate accept the incorporation of Senator Natasha Stott‐Despoja's remarks on this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
This Bill makes a number of technical and administrative amendments to the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Act 1991. We have agreed this Bill should pass as non-controversial.

However, before we agreed to this, the Government accepted our amendment to remove the provision which allowed the Authority to employ persons under written agreements on any terms and conditions determined by the Authority. This was clause 26 of the Bill.

The Democrats are not opposed to public service and public sector reform. In fact, we see it as being necessary if Australia is to meet the challenges ahead with an efficient, effective and viable public sector.

But, the Democrats do not advocate provisions which shift towards practices over which the Parliament will be unable to exercise adequate scrutiny. Nor do we support attempts to entrench in law the Government's very limited and narrow vision of an effective public service based on some rosy tablet of private sector expediency. The public service is here to service both the public, and the wider public interest.

We moved this amendment to remove a provision which undermines the general public service employment arrangements. These are matters best dealt with in the Public Service Act and its replacement which is currently before the Senate.

We welcome the Government's acceptance of our amendment and a recognition that statutory authorities must conform with the general employment policies of the public service. Statutory authorities are not the private sector and they must remain accountable to the Government and the Parliament.
The Democrats set out in the Senate Finance and Public Administration Committee minority report our objection to this sort of provision:

"The Democrats are concerned the [Public Service] Bill in its present form signals a shift away from a Westminster style of public service able to give independent, frank and fearless advice to both government and Parliament, towards a new `private sector' model of public service which `belongs' to the government of the day".
The provision proposed by the Government would have been this shift. We are unable to support such a provision. But without that provision we are happy to support this Bill.

The other late changes the Government proposed concern the change to the position of `Chairperson' and `Chief Executive Officer'. The splitting off of the Chairperson's day-to-day administrative functions to a newly established Chief Executive Officer will leave the Chairperson position as part-time and increase the efficiency of the Authority.
We have been assured that these provisions are being introduced to bring administrative efficiencies. I would again seek this assurance Eom the Government in this place.

TITLE.XREF: FARM HOUSEHOLD SUPPORT AMENDMENT (RESTART AND EXCEPTIONAL CIRCUMSTANCES) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 October, on motion by Senator Ian Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate that the opposition will support passage of the Farm Household Support Amendment (Restart and Exceptional Circumstances) Bill 1997 . The bill has been considered by the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee, and it was the unanimous recommendation of the committee that the bill be supported and passed without amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: I might just say that the government has made great play of its package of measures that were announced a few weeks back now by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson)—the assistance to agriculture package. We acknowledge that there are some worthwhile proposals within that package, including the legislation that is now before the chamber. But we do say as a matter of record that overall the package is largely a repackaging and a rebadging of many initiatives that were introduced by the previous government. At the same time, there are some changes that are welcome. On that basis, we support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats support the Farm Household Support Amendment (Restart and Exceptional Circumstances) Bill 1997 . I want to make a number of points. If it were not for the start‐up date and the need to put in place the measures contained in this bill, we would have spent more time discussing it. We would probably have suggested to government some further improvements. Those improvements go not only to the detail of the bill but also to the philosophy behind it. It is in terms of that philosophy that I want to put some points on the record today.

SPEECH.PARA: We use words like `adjustment' as though they were benign terms to describe something which, for many farmers, is in fact a very stressful experience. For them, adjustment means actually getting out of farming. Sometimes I think we put a lot of pressure on farmers by referring to them as `non‐viable' or `uncompetitive' or `inefficient' or `not good enough', as though the whole predicament was solely their own doing, and we fail to admit that at times it is government policy or the lack of government policy which has contributed very significantly to the situation in which farmers find themselves.

I believe that is policy of all of the major parties. I do not leave the Democrats out of that, as we seek also to struggle to understand the situation of agriculture not only in Australia but also in a global sense, for there are massive changes that have been and are taking place in global farming. I do not believe that they are all positive. In fact, I think that globalisation and competition policy, which we often laud as the answer to all of our problems, is really proving—to me, at least, and I think to many other people—to be simply not working. We keep on projecting globalisation and competition policy as though we were all playing on a level playing field. I know that the rhetoric says we agree there isn't one. Nevertheless, the policies remain in place which project a level playing field as though it were reality.
So we continue to reduce tariffs in many of our primary industries, despite the fact that in many other countries tariffs—

TALK.START.PARA: —And non‐tariff barriers.
—And non‐tariff barriers as well—are still in place, and we expect to compete with those countries. We know the problems that farmers have with low commodity process, and I could go on.

SPEECH.PARA: Another major factor in the whole problem of agriculture is the dominant paradigm, a paradigm of extension and competition adopted by government and even by industry bodies purporting to represent all farmers. And yet each year we have a new batch of farmers fitting into the following categories: 10 per cent prosper; 40 per cent manage to keep afloat; 30 per cent struggle like mad to stay afloat; and 20 per cent go under. What we do not acknowledge is that every time we take the 20 per cent off the bottom we actual ly then spread the 100 per cent out again and so we have a new 20 per cent at the bottom. Of course, the 10 per cent at the top today will eventually be split up into the categories and they themselves will be dropping off the bottom, if we continue the way we are going.

We know that farmers have lower access to business improvement management and technology compared to city business counterparts. That is a reason for our government to continue fostering their extension activities. Government sponsored agriculture extension is notorious for looking after the top 50 per cent and leaving the rest behind. But we know from Australian commercial and corporate contact extension programs that this need not be the case. When appropriate agricultural extension is directed to all farmers, there is measurable improvement in uptake of technology and financial position among most farmers.

Indeed, looking after the top 10 per cent of farmers in some ways is not efficient. These master business people will thrive regardless, and often in spite of government extension intervention. They are the ones who already have well‐honed research, technical, financial and management skills. What is required is equity of access, and we know from research that it is not adequate to say, `Well, here we are. Come and see us.' Nor is it adequate to run standard government extension programs without also providing individualised business improvement programs.

We would have improved the Farm Household Support Amendment (Restart and Exceptional Circumstances) Bill 1997 in a number of ways. We put these on the record as something that we would like to pursue in the future. When we talk about adjustment and restarting, we would like to see governments taking account of the possibility of restarting not just off the farm but restarting on the farm as well. We believe that, unless governments do begin to take account of the possibility of some farmers restarting on farm, we will continue the failure which has been part of the experience of so many farmers in the last few years. This means that government has to accept best practice in business improvement programs. Government should genuinely provide access to financial counselling, technical‐management extension advice—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is exactly what this bill provides for. That is what we are doing.

—Just wait till I get to the end, Senator Boswell. You delay me. I am trying to get through this as quickly as I can. I do not want to hold you up. Government should provide access to family‐partnership counselling, career counselling, collegiate ongoing mentoring from farmers and ex‐farmers, access to the property management planning, and one‐ or two‐year monitored and reviewed action plans.

SPEECH.PARA: Now, to answer your question, Senator Boswell: what we would like to see is that this is available not just to the very viable farmers, who are the ones who usually access it, but we would like to see equity in that to enable some of those farmers who would perhaps be dropping off to have the opportunity to restart, because we believe that not enough account is being taken of that.

We believe that as long as government and peak industry body policy continues to have a vision only for the need to restart off the farm then we will continue to lose those we regard as non‐viable. But as I said before, that will continue to eat up not only those who are non‐viable today but some who will fall into the bottom category in the future.

We need to use sensible definitions of `farmer' and take into account that farmers can be women, second families, couples on the farm, young people, single people, and relatives not in the immediate family. I do not get the impression that government appreciates the diversity of labour situations on farming small businesses in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on! That is absolute nonsense.
—What did you say?
—I said it is crap.
—So it is crap or it is nonsense.
—Order! Senator Woodley, it would be more appropriate if you directed your remarks through the chair.

—It is the government's time that is being wasted, Mr Acting Deputy President. It is no problem to me. I am happy to take my full time. I need to point out that in using the word `crap' I was simply repeating a word that was directed at me. It was not my wish to use that word.
—Don't complain if native title does not come on next week. It is in your hands.
—What was that, Senator Campbell?
—It is your responsibility.
—Senator Campbell, it would be appreciated if you could conduct yourself in an orderly manner. Senator Woodley, could you continue with your speech, please.

—I certainly will. I am being provoked but I will try not to be. I believe that there are a number of other things that we need to do in order to improve this bill and that I hope will be part of the continuing debate, because I know that Senator Boswell certainly wants the best for farmers in Australia, as I do, even though we do not always agree about how that can be achieved. There is no doubt that that is his intention.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we do need a clearer definition of `exceptional circumstances', and I hope we might develop this through consultation with farmers, rural counsellors and the various farming bodies. I would hope that we could enable exceptional circumstances to continue until a social security income test demonstrates that farmers are able to stand on their own, in cases where farmers are individually drought declared by their state or territory.

We need to ensure that professionals with extensive rural knowledge and experience are the ones to conduct the viability, income and asset tests. Unless there are going to be huge numbers of DSS centrepoint staff undertaking extensive tertiary training et cetera, then I do not believe they have the expertise to do this and we ought to use the people who are on the ground and who know.

I believe we should include disease eradication program participants as being eligible for the restart scheme. Many of these people discover that they have an eradication program all of a sudden put on their farm. This often has a devastating impact on their financial and psychological states. I also believe the DSS review of estimated incomes should be conducted in March of the year when DSS payments are received. Often when farmers have to repay lump sums this can be very damaging to their cash flow.

We need a genuine proactive public education process to ensure farmers know what government programs are available. The existing processes do not work in many places. I will not spend the time of the Senate, but we had a lot of contact with farm counsellors who were saying that people just do not know what is available. We need to do more work in that area.

Finally—and I have not used up all my time—I think we need both in government and in the Department of Social Security to keep a level head on the subject of rorting. Recent press releases show that the problem in rural Australia is that most eligible farmers do not access government programs of this kind. They either do not know of the programs, do not know of the eligibility requirements or do not want to be part of restrictive, privacy-invading government programs.

I commend the bill to the Senate. Those are the issues that the Democrats would like to put on the table for further debate around the issue of support for farm families. We trust that the positive aspects of this bill will be taken up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The time of the Senate is running out as we are nearing the end of the year. There is some very important legislation coming up. A great number of rural and regional families have their future in the hands of the Senate on the Wik debate and they want to get a decision. With that in mind, I seek the support of the Senate to incorporate my speech.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

BREAK.PARA: This bill is part of the government's commitment to implementing its rural policy, Agriculture Advancing Australia announced by John Anderson on September 14th. It is an integrated package of assistance to farmers designed to build a strong and sustainable rural sector.
It recognises the important role farmers and their communities play in Australian society both economically and socially.
It is a package we can all be proud of. This government has delivered comprehensive reform to the bush and rural industries, our National Party heartland, through its triple AAA package.
This is a government initiative that cares about the people of rural Australia and understands their special needs and circumstances.
Through these provisions and the rest of the Agriculture—Advancing Australia package the government aims to assist farmers through changing and adverse conditions.
It provides ongoing incentives for structural change within farming industries, giving targeted assistance to farmers wishing to move out of farming and into other businesses or employment.
These provisions invest resources where they are needed encouraging social and economic growth in rural communities and providing access to an adequate safety net.
Rural industries have a strong future, they are highly productive and competitive and provide a quarter of the nation's export income.
Farmers contribute significantly to the overall economy and are leaders in contributing to our export trade. They run efficient, highly productive and essential industries.
The rural sector's success as exporters is vital to Australia's prosperity.
Increased exports means jobs for Australia both on farms and in local rural service industries.
None of this would be possible without the right economic framework and this government has laid many of the foundations already for a strong and healthy rural sector.

There are some good signs for Australian rural producers, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade expects that the value of rural exports will increase by as much as $1 billion dollars per year as trade liberalisation continues exports of beef and wheat are expected to rise alone by $300 million. The dairy industry has been another success story with their exports expected to rise by $200 million per year.
There are so many benefits to trade liberalisation and our rural industries have recognised these benefits and taken the initiative, responding to the rapid growth of Asian and other food markets.
This package will provide vital assistance to the people of rural Australia, who are the backbone of this nation's wool, grain and cattle industries.
They are the ones which have hung on through neglect over more than a decade of Labor bad management with shameful interest rates of 23 and 24 per cent.
The financial battle farmers faced under the previous government was almost unwinnable.

Farmers must overcome many difficulties to achieve their successes, including severe drought, economic hardship, low commodity prices and other adverse conditions. Farmers have endured conditions which have made it very difficult for them to operate in a profitable manner.

My colleague, John Anderson, has produced a package that recognises the need for financial and career counselling, long-term planning, as well as immediate financial assistance these are provisions that allow farmers whose farms are unviable to make a new start. These are measures which provide for a smooth transition into new industries.
It is a responsible approach where farmer's experiencing financial difficulties have the opportunity and choice to move into new areas.
This bill will allow farmers to gain assistance and make informed, financially sound choices about the future of their farm.
Unlike the former labor policy, the farm family restart scheme will not force farmers to sell their farm in order to gain assistance.
Farmers will receive assistance for a period of twelve months and must seek financial advice and career counselling in that time.
This process will allow farmers to asses the viability of their rural business, while ensuring the basic necessities are available
Farmers may choose, after consultation with financial advisers and career counsellors, to move into another industry and a re-establishment grant of $45,000 will be available to eligible farmers.
It allows farmers to make informed assessments of their financial position and will provide incentives for farmers to move into other industries, before they have depleted their assets.
There is no requirement for farmers to put their farm on the market or undergo an activity test as would be required under the social security system.
It is more than a welfare payment. It provides support while farmer's asses their financial position.
In addition to the Farm Family Restart Scheme, this bill provides for exceptional circumstances provisions. These measures are similar to the current drought relief payment.
Exceptional circumstances recognises that there is a whole range of circumstances affecting normal management practices.
Drought, flood and other exceptional circumstances have a devastating effect on not only primary producers, but on provincial towns and small businesses dependent on these primary producers.
These provisions account for the damaging results of rare and severe events, as well as drought.
The provisions in this bill recognise the special needs of rural producers and provides valuable assistance for farmers experiencing financial hardship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth, Sen Judith

TALKER.NAME: Senator TROETH
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say very briefly that the farm family restart scheme and the exceptional circumstances relief payment represent significant positive new policy developments for the farm sector. I thank honourable senators for their comments. I commend the bill to the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 October, on motion by Senator Parer:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the debate earlier on the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1997 [No. 2] and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1997 I indicated the purposes of those bills and the relationship with amending the Commonwealth's taxed safety net arrangements with regard to tobacco, alcohol and petrol. I did refer to the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 , which proposes to give effect to a request by the states and territories to alter their shares of revenue replacement payments for tobacco under the safety net arrangements arising from the change in the method of imposing tax. I do not think I need to make any further comments, other than referring to my earlier remarks and indicate that the opposition supports the passage of the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats do not oppose the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 . We will, however, be moving one amendment to the bill which will be circulated when the committee stage is called. That amendment will deal with the question of accountability for grants by the Commonwealth to the states. It is particularly designed to deal with the problem of Premier Kennett and his moves to knock over the independence of the Auditor-General which therefore puts Commonwealth grants at risk of not being properly and independently audited.

SPEECH.PARA: Members of the Senate may recall that the Australian Democrats put such an amendment to an earlier states grants bill. The Labor opposition at that time opposed it on the grounds that they thought it was not the appropriate bill and that it should be put to the Auditor-General package of bills. We duly did so. When it was put to the Auditor-General package of bills—surprise, surprise!—Labor turned it down.

At the time of the states grants debate, Senator Conroy and Senator Carr came into this chamber and made impassioned speeches against Premier Kennett, his arrogance in office, his lack of accountability and sundry other allegations. However, that kind of speaking has not been matched by action. We are concerned to ensure that the actions and attitudes of the opposition leader in Victoria, Mr Brumby, and the actions and attitudes of Labor senators, particularly from Victoria, in this chamber do not amount to mere posturing.

So we advise in advance that we will again be putting that amendment to the Senate. If Labor fail to support it this time, it will reflect on their real attitudes as an executive in waiting rather than as an opposition dedicated to accountability and to keeping the Commonwealth money grants appropriately protected. Accordingly, I foreshadow that that will be the amendment we will be moving. I look forward to seeing whether the Labor Party squirm out of that one yet again.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that consideration of the bill in committee of the whole be made an order of the day for a later.

TITLE.XREF: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (PARENTING AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 October, on motion by Senator Parer:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Parenting and Other Measures) Bill 1997 and to draw to the attention of the government the effect of its policies on Australian families, particularly on low income families. Australian families are very concerned about what is happening now and what may happen in the future. Australian families, particularly low income families, are facing a great deal of uncertainty and insecurity at this time. I have to say that, under this government, they are justified in being concerned that they may not have a job next week. Under this government, they are right to be concerned that their already stretched household budgets may not be able to meet the extra costs that this government is going to impose on them.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to go through a few examples of this. They will be spending more on child-care costs. As we know from the report that was tabled yesterday, in some cases they will be spending up to an additional $40 a week. They will be spending more on community care services and HACC services. If they can afford private health insurance, the benefit they would have received from the rebate will have gone in increased premiums. They will be paying more for pharmaceuticals. Health card holders will pay an additional $3.20 for the co‐payment and, as at 1 February next year, potentially as estimated by the AMA an additional $30 per month with the new drugs tax. They will be paying more for dental treatment with the abolishment of the Commonwealth dental health scheme.

They will be paying more for housing with the reduction in rental assistance and the reduction in the availability of public housing. They will be paying more for their elderly parents to get into a nursing home and they will be paying more as a daily fee once they get in there. If they have children between the ages of 16 and 25 who are seeking work or are in education, then they will have to support those children searching for work up to the age of 20 and they will have to provide more assistance to their studying children.

All round, if you are a family in Australia, particularly if you are a low income family, under the policies of the present government you are a loser. Australian families over the last two budgets have lost $10 billion—that is from health, housing, education and social security. If this government believes that it can carve $10 billion out of the pockets of Australian families and it will have no effect, then it had better rethink its position.

I will look at the provisions of this bill. Schedule 1 combines the parenting allowance with the sole parent benefit. Ostensibly this is the provision to ensure simplification; to put two allowances together under the same name. As this government has always done, when it simplifies it uses it as an excuse to take away a benefit some low income person has. This is no exception to that general principle because, as usual, it has gone for the lowest common denominator.

Sole parents will lose in the following ways. Before, there was an assets taper whereby the sole parent payment was reduced gradually as their assets increased. Instead of their payment being reduced by $3 a fortnight for every $1,000 of assets that they have, under the new arrangements proposed in this bill they will immediately lose their sole parent benefit, or the parenting payment as it is now to be known.

There is also now the application of an income maintenance period for sole parents which did not previously apply—that is, if they have cashed out annual leave, sick leave, long service leave or maternity leave and it is paid as part of a redundancy payment, they will now have to wait the period that those payments cover before they are eligible for the parenting payment. There is also a reduction in the overseas portability from 26 weeks to 13 weeks.

There are some small winners in these provisions, but the net effect of these changes is that there is $7 million taken away from low income families that have children. When we know very well that children living in families relying on the sole parent benefit are some of the worst off in our community, those who are struggling the hardest, it really is a very harsh provision to be applying.

But it does get worse when we move to schedule 2, which applies to the child disability allowance. Firstly, as of 1 July, eligibility for the child disability allowance will be based on a prescribed list of disabilities and a child disability assessment tool. Secondly, the child disability allowance arrears will be cut from 12 months to six months. Once this government starts cutting away at payments made to disabled children, it really is hitting the bottom of the barrel. If I were a member of the coalition now, I would be a little embarrassed. If this government does not believe that the disabled children in our community are entitled to some sort of support, I really cannot see who it does believe is entitled to support.

There is only one positive change in relation to disabled children—that is, in order to get over the high jump, in order to qualify for the child disability allowance, you can now add two children together. So, if you are a family that is unfortunate enough to have not only one child but two children who are disabled, you can add them together so you get over the high jump. It is a small positive thing—I do not like to be negative always—but I have to say, in the light of the negative changes the government has made, it really is pretty small. There has been some debate about exactly who are affected by these changes and how many. The government itself says there will be about 12,000 children who are affected, but this certainly does not seem very clear, and maybe the minister would like to clarify that when she is on her feet.

BREAK.PARA: Also, there seems to be some argument about the sorts of disabilities children suffer from, which will mean that some will lose out with these changes to the children's disability allowance. There seems to be some argument on behalf of the government that the sorts of people who are going to be missing out are three particular classes of children. They will be children with attention deficit disorder, children with diabetes and children with asthma. I suppose the whole basis of the argument is that these children are not really disabled, that it is not really a problem for them, that they require no additional help.

Firstly, despite the fact that those figures were relied on in the budget portfolio document, there seems to be little support for that view put forward by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. I am sure the government is well aware of the debate in relation to that issue. It seems to me that in some cases the children who will miss out will be not only those in the three categories but also those who suffer from other disabilities.

Putting aside that argument for a moment, it is important to say that I do not believe the three classes of children with those particular disabilities are unworthy of support. If that is a view held by the government and by the department, they have never had children, dealt with children or cared for children who are in those categories. It certainly is a great difficulty that children have to overcome, particularly in the category of ADD. For those children who suffer ADD in our community, it can often be the difference between their being educated and their not being educated. In many cases, to overcome that difficulty they have to have extensive additional teaching and coaching to get even the bare necessities of an education—to be able to read and write.

This government is saying that, if you have a child with attention deficit disorder, it does not care if you cannot get that additional help. If you are poor, if you cannot afford to pay for that additional training yourself, that is just too bad. I really do not see how this government feels that the community are winners if there is a generation of children with a disability and the government does not provide them and their families with the tools to overcome it. That sort of short-sightedness also applies to children in the categories of having asthma and diabetes.

Despite our objections, this government seems hell‐bent on proceeding with this part of the bill, and this is not the first time that this government has had a go at the disabled in Australia. It is not the first time, because we fought it off before. When the government attempted to alter the arrears for the child disability allowance in earlier legislation, we defeated it, and I hope we will be able to do that again.

There are also other areas where this government is eroding the support that is being provided to the disabled. In the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Family and Other Measures) Bill , which we have previously dealt with, there was the introduction of a new disability impairment table for adults who are disabled. Under that new table, thousands of people with disabilities would have to look for work, and where there were no jobs available those people would miss out. That amendment got through on the basis that the Australian Democrats agreed that they would allow its passage if the government would review it at some time in the future. I was quite disappointed by that position, but I cannot get away from the fact that this is a proposition put by the government that does have a responsibility for running the country. Obviously it thinks that it is all right to reduce the eligibility of disabled people for the disability allowance.

Something else has happened, probably less obviously, and there was some discussion about it at the estimates committee hearings—that is, at the same time, there has been a crackdown on the availability of the mobility allowance. I questioned the officers at some length about this issue. They tried to impress upon me that this reduction, or this removal of a number of people who are on the mobility allowance—or, more accurately, the failure of many people to qualify for the mobility allowance—was as a result of the fact that there had been some confusion about the mobility allowance. They said the reality was that, previously, people who were not entitled to it were receiving it and they had just clarified the guidelines to ensure that this did not occur. I beg to differ.

A number of people who have contacted the opposition have an entirely different view of it as well. They see that they had an entitlement before to an allowance, not a large allowance but just enough to allow people who are quite disabled to get around, to attend living skills classes, to attend venues outside their home that would give them a greater level of skill. Maybe it would not give them a sufficient level of skill to immediately obtain employment, but for some people, particularly those who are disabled, the journey to being able to obtain employment is a very long and arduous one. The early steps may have a tenuous connection on the face of it to eventually getting a job but, in my view, anything that increases the skills and exposure of disabled people to the outside world is a step towards getting them a job. I believe that this government has treated the disabled, both children and adults, despicably. I hope that it reconsiders its position in the future.

Schedule 3 of the bill is rather peculiar. The government has changed `family payment' to `family allowance'. We are not opposed to it, but we are a bit puzzled by it. Why this government would bother to make 255 amendments to the Social Security Act just for the purpose of changing the name from `payment' to `allowance' seems to be rather extraordinary, although I suppose there is some ideological basis for it. I am a bit concerned about not only the amendment and the fact that it wastes the time of the Senate in dealing with it but also the cost involved in it.

What is the cost of this ideological bent of this government to change `payment' to `allowance'? How much does it cost for the stationery? How much does it cost for the application forms—reprinting it all, of course, because of the change of name? How much is it going to cost for the publicity to inform people of what is happening? Again, I would like the minister to respond to that when she is on her feet, if she can. How much will it cost the community for this change of name, which appears to me to be entirely based on ideology? If the minister has another explanation, I would be very interested to hear it, but I certainly could not think of any other reason.

Schedule 4 of the bill deals with the hardship provisions. It standardises the arrangements for determining when severe financial hardship can be invoked to waive ordinary income maintenance and liquid assets waiting periods. A person must have liquid assets of no more than two weeks payment. For the income maintenance and liquid assets test, they must also demonstrate that they are in this financial predicament because of what is, in the view of this government, unavoidable and essential expenditure. This has been a vexed question: what exactly can be the basis for hardship provisions? This seems to be an improvement on the previous position, but I am not sure if it is exactly the ideal. I suppose I have to concede the benefit of a slight loosening up.

The problem with `unavoidable and essential expenditure' is that sometimes things occur to a family that may not necessarily come within this category. In those circumstances, should the family have to potentially go without food and lodgings for maybe two weeks? I suppose it is not often that it occurs, but I am sure it does happen. Say, for example, the father of a family takes the only income the family has and goes off and gambles it. Obviously you would not describe that as being essential expenditure but, then again, is it really fair that the family in that situation should go without food for that period if something like that should occur? Obviously the father has done something completely irresponsible, but should the rest of the family suffer as a result? Again, I would be very interested to hear if the department has given any consideration to this circumstance or whether there is some provision that can deal with this sort of situation.

Schedule 5 extends the health care card eligibility to disabled children who do not otherwise qualify for the child disability allowance and bases the health care card eligibility on income averaged over eight weeks. Of course we support the first part for all the reasons that I have said already—I think disabled children need all the help they can get—but we are a bit concerned that this mechanism extends the period over which income is assessed. It essentially means that you do not have to wait for four weeks for the health care card; you have to wait for eight. We are a bit unhappy with that. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bartlett, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Parenting and Other Measures) Bill 1997 was first introduced into the parliament, the second reading speech stated that the bill had two key aims. Firstly, it was designed to simplify income support arrangements for parents, regardless of whether they had partners or not. Secondly, it aimed to reduce the social stigma sometimes associated with being on a sole parent pension. Both of these are laudable aims. However, the Democrats are not totally convinced that this bill goes all the way to achieving those aims. But, inasmuch as we believe that it does, we recognise the value of those aims and support them.

SPEECH.PARA: I will look firstly at the simplification aspect. The Democrats have argued for many years that the Social Security Act is far too complex. A simple illustration of that is the measure in this bill to change the name of the family payment back to family allowance. It has taken nearly 50 pages of amendments to make that very basic change. I do not think you need much more demonstration than that of just how huge and incredibly complicated the Social Security Act has become.

The Democrats are convinced that a simpler act would be fairer to both Centrelink customers and the staff who have the very difficult job of trying to interpret this huge and ever‐changing morass of legislation. If we could simplify the act, it would also significantly reduce the cost of administering our income support system. We acknowledge that a complex system such as social security does require complex legislation, but we do urge the government to increase their efforts to make the act easier to understand and administer.

BREAK.PARA: One schedule of the amendments made by this bill will replace two existing payments—that is, the sole parent pension and the partner allowance—with a single new payment, the parenting payment. On the surface, this does seem simpler. However, as often happens, if you dig a little deeper, you find that the new payment is in fact paid at two separate rates and under two separate conditions; it just has the single label over the top. So, while there is some alignment of payment conditions, this certainly is not a major step forward in attempts to make the Social Security Act more accessible or simpler for those who have to work within it and receive payments under it.

Turning to the other core purpose of the bill, as expressed by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman), that parts of this legislation are aimed at reducing some of the social stigma on sole parents, it should be noted that the way in which the government intends to achieve this goal, according to the provisions contained in this bill, is by putting longer waiting periods on sole parents, imposing a tougher assets test on them and reducing the portability of their payment. I don't think this is necessarily the nicest way to reduce the social stigma.

There are a number of minor improvements for sole parents, which we acknowledge. But, overall, as a result of this legislation, we will see a reduction in support to low income families of more than $6 million a year. That is a bit of a price to pay for having a bit less stigma.

It seems that the biggest benefit for sole parents is a change in the name of their payment. I do not necessarily want to underestimate the value of this, because labels are sometimes quite important in our society.
