I note that the National Council of Single Mothers and Their Children has welcomed the introduction of a more inclusive payment—one that will be made to all parents whether they have partners or not.

I would like to make the point that, if this is the best the government can do to assist the group of social security recipients who have been shown in study after study to be the group most likely to be in poverty, then we do have a fair way to go. At this point, however, I would like to put on the record that the Democrats were very pleased to receive a number of commitments from the minister's office in relation to this new payment. These commitments were: that the level of parenting payment paid to sole parents would be legislatively pegged to 25 per cent of male average weekly earnings; that sole parents will remain eligible for both the employment and education entry payments—at least while those payments still exist; that a sole parent can continue to receive their payment pending any review of their entitlement; and, finally, that sole parents will continue to receive the more adequate pensioner concession card. These are important measures in terms of reducing disadvantage for what is one of the most disadvantaged sections of our community. The Democrats welcome those commitments from the government.

As I understand it, a further commitment given by the minister's office was that Austudy regulations would be brought on at a later date to ensure that students who are sole parents will remain eligible for the pensioner supplement. I would ask the minister, when she does get the chance to respond to this at some time down the track, if she would put that commitment on the public record for us. These are all vital commitments for the Democrats, and they were instrumental in ensuring our qualified support for this legislation. There are a number of amendments that I propose to move in the committee stage, on behalf of the Democrats, to make the legislation a little fairer. I will talk to those in the committee stage.

I would like to make a point about the legislation's stated aim of reducing the social stigma for sole parents and social security recipients. It seems to me that it is a little incongruous. While this aim is a good thing, it does not seem to gel terribly well with the role the government has played in the media debate over recent months about social security fraud. I am sure all senators would have seen some of the recent headlines trumpeting the crackdown on social security fraud. In a few of the headlines from the last few weeks, the Herald‐Sun talked about 200,000 cheats and $1,400 million in rip‐offs on welfare, the Adelaide Advertiser talked about welfare cheats being stripped of $369 million, and the Daily Telegraph had the headline `Red Handed: 330,000 welfare payments stopped'.

It seems to me, and to the Democrats, that these sorts of factually incorrect headlines do enormous damage to the way in which the community views all social security recipients. If we are talking about people having a stigma attached to them, I think this has a hell of a lot more of an impact on those people than will changing the title of a few payments. Some of the editorials that followed on from these misleading headlines, giving the impression that there are hundreds of thousands of cheats out there, demonstrate how much damage is done and how much that stigma is still attached to welfare recipients.

In the light of these factually incorrect statements, and in light of the current bill's stated objective of removing the social stigma from sole parent pensioners, it is important to look at what sort of response the stories did get from the minister and from the government. As far as I am aware, we have not once heard the minister stand up and say, `These headlines grossly misrepresent the truth. The level of fraud in social security is not out of control and it is not out of proportion to fraud in any other sphere of government.'

I have not noticed the minister once defending social security recipients in the face of this media misrepresentation, or playing a constructive role in allaying community fears about the level of welfare fraud or reducing the stigma on those who receive payments. To date, I have not seen this happen even once. Indeed, it seems to me, and to the Democrats, that the minister and the government have done the exact opposite and put out very carefully worded press releases which, whilst not quite saying that all overpayments are due to fraud, leave the very clear impression that this is the case. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, is it true that you have been forewarned about the potential disaster to the Great Barrier Reef which is posed by acid sulfate soils? Is it true that you have received advice from Australia's foremost experts on acid sulfate soil management about the magnitude of this problem? What action have you taken on the basis of this advice? What action do you propose to take in light of the information revealed on last night's ABC news report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —There were specific matters raised in the report but Senator Faulkner's question started off on a much more general tone. As honourable senators would be aware, acid sulfate is a significant issue along the southern New South Wales coast, along the Queensland coast, in the Northern Territory, in Western Australia and even in some areas of South Australia and Victoria. In fact, there is estimated to be some two million hectares of acid sulfate soils in Australia. Developments obviously disturb these soils and it is important that the acid sulfate is properly managed.

ANSWER.PARA: Therefore, if Senator Faulkner is asking whether we are aware that development projects along the Queensland coast as it adjoins the Great Barrier Reef waters need to be carefully managed, yes, I am aware of that. Regrettably, in the past, there have been many developments where that was not the case, largely out of ignorance. People are still learning not only the consequences of acid sulfate soils but also how to effectively manage them.

In relation to the news report on channel 2 last night—it was more of a five‐minute commentary piece in the middle of the news report, quite an unusual occurrence—it was grossly misleading, because the point is that in the case of the Hinchinbrook development there is an acid sulfate management plan in being. In fact, the original draft of that plan was put out for peer review, including review by Professor White. As a result of that re view, the report was considerably strengthened and the plan that was put into place was a strengthened plan.

The effect of that plan is to enable the development to take place in a way that does not threaten the world heritage values of the Great Barrier Reef; in other words, to contain th acid sulfate soil during the development process. That, my advice is, is being adhered to, and there is no occurrence in relation to that development that is putting any of the world heritage values at risk. You might be somewhat surprised to hear that, in light of the tenor of the piece on channel 2, but that is in fact the case.

The plan sets out a number of steps that need to be taken to protect against acid sulfate soils. I will not go into all the details of that at the moment. An independent monitor, the Queensland Acid Sulfate Soil Inspection Team, is in place to monitor the effectiveness of that plan and the deed expressly prohibits the discharge of any water below a pH of six or above a pH of nine, and daily monitoring is being conducted to ensure that these levels are being complied with. In other words, there is in place a plan to protect against acid sulfate soils leaching into reef waters. It is being adhered to; it is being properly monitored; and my best advice as late as today is that there is no threat at all to the Great Barrier Reef or its world heritage values.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, what about the advice from Professor White and Mr Sammut? Are you saying that Professor White and Mr Sammut are not recognised as reputable, authoritative and world recognised experts in their field, or do you accept their advice is accurate and you are simply burying your head in the sand about this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course not. That is a silly question. Professor White's first report went through how you deal with acid sulfate soils. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: The asset sulfate management plan for Port Hinchinbrook espouses these principles.
Professor White did, I acknowledge, go on and suggest some improvements, as did the other reviewee, and their views were taken into account in a strengthened management plan.

Madam President, what was so disgraceful about last night's report—you might remember, if you saw it—was that they tested the acid sulfate soil and found that in fact it was acidic. The point is: where they tested the soil was where the acid sulfate was supposed to be captured so that it did not get swept into the offshore waters. Did that come out of the channel 2 piece? Of course not. You were led to believe that in the next rains it was all going to be washed into the sea. The plan is to a design, and it is being implemented, to ensure that that is not the case. In fact, if every development along the Queensland coast was pursuant to such a rigorous and demanding plan as this, then there would be much less damage done to the reef and its important values. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. Is the minister aware of claims that the Australian market would `choke' on a privatisation of the size of one-third of Telstra? Is the minister aware of claims that the limited scale of domestic share market funds would result in pressure to increase the level of foreign ownership in Telstra beyond that provided for in the government's one-third sale legislation? Minister, have these claims proven to be accurate and to what extent should they be taken into account in government policy formulation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Senator Ferguson is quite right that there were claims made of that order—absolutely extraordinary claims. You have to go back to January 1996 when we first announced our policy to partially privatise one‐third of Telstra. At that time we talked about it being worth perhaps $8 billion—in other words the company being worth around $25 billion. What sort of response did we get?

ANSWER.PARA: The sandpit club of course immediately went absolutely troppo. You had Paul Keating out there using the very words that Senator Ferguson used, that the market would choke on a privatisation of this size. Of course, he had no evidence to support it. It was simply part of the ongoing, monumental scare campaign that they hoped to whip up. Not only were they proven to be monumentally inaccurate but they have never apologised for it. Presumably they will continue to go on burying their heads in the sand on this issue.

As far as the level of foreign ownership is concerned, you will recall that we put a limit of 35 per cent on foreign ownership, which would give just under 12 per cent of the company as a maximum for foreign investors. The reality is that this float, this issue, proved so overwhelmingly attractive to ordinary Australians, both retail—mums and dads, and families—and institutional investors, that it was only necessary to make available what amounts to about 6.3 per cent of the total of the company for foreign investors. In other words, around 19 per cent of the share offer ultimately found its way into the hands of foreign investors.

It was not just something that was said in the heat of the election campaign because, despite Mr Keating doing his very best to whip that one up as well and saying that there would inevitably be more sales to foreigners, that we would lose control of the company as soon as we introduced a partial sale, there was a Senate committee report. Do you remember the filibuster that was involved with this lot sending it off to a committee and months of running around the country trying to, again, whip up some antagonism?

What we had there was an unholy trio. You know Senator Schacht—he is the leader of the disgruntled unionist faction in South Australia. We had his colleague from the lunatic far Left fringe in Victoria. He basically heads up his own faction, doesn't he now, Senator Conroy? The last thing you would ever want to put on your CV is that you worked for Kim Il Carr. Nonetheless, he was part of this, and then Senator Lundy.

You had this trio saying, `Further pressure to increase the level of foreign ownership will arise from a recognition of the limited scale of domestic share market fund.' What would they know? They clearly did not understand even the basics of the share market, and they didn't want to know, because they have been burying their heads in the sand on this issue right from the outset. It is the biggest conflict of interest in history.

The only reason they do it is that their masters tell them that that is what they have got to do. It is not the usual story of saying, `Jump!' and their asking, `How high do I jump?' They actually go to the ACTU and say, `How high do you want us to jump on this one?', and the ACTU says, `We know you privatised everything in sight when you were in government, but would you mind doing a backflip from now on, so that we can appeal to our own membership.' That is why the Courier‐Mail the other day was talking about Labor's irrelevancy. It referred to:
. . . the yawning gap between modern day reality and the new policy positions of the federal Labor Party.

more than a bit rich coming from a leader of a political party which, in government was robust in its commitment to privatisation. There were no Labor tears, crocodile or otherwise, when the people's bank was floated in successive tranches—

On it goes. It makes it clear that this lot are completely out of touch, not interested in sensible policy and not interested in getting it right for the future. They are not interested in lower rates of interest or indeed reduced levels of taxation which can flow from sensible privatisation. We are delighted to hear it repeated by Senator Ray and Mr Beazley that they will not be privatising any more of Telstra. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from the Republic of Malawi led by the Speaker of the National Assembly, Mr Rodwell Munyenyembe. On behalf of honourable senators, I welcome you to the Senate and trust that your visit here will be both informative and enjoyable. With the concurrence of senators I would invite the Speaker to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.
—Hear, hear!

PARA.EMPHASIS: Mr Munyenyembe was thereupon seated accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill. Minister, I refer you to your previous answer to my earlier question in which you put great store on the fact that the original acid sulphate soils management plan for Port Hinchinbrook was peer reviewed, found to be flawed, and amended. Minister, isn't it true that you did not resubmit the amended plan to Dr Bowman of CSIRO, and Professor White, after they said the original was flawed? Why didn't you do that? Who provided the alternative advice on the amended plan, and can you guarantee that you received the best scientific and engineering advice available? If you did receive such advice, will you release it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised that Senator Faulkner has the nerve to raise this issue because under his government 10 years ago there was significant disturbance of these acid sulphate soils. What did his government require to be done to safeguard the world heritage values? Absolutely nothing. They allowed the soils to be washed around for a period of 10 years.

ANSWER.PARA: As a contrast, what we have put in place is an elaborate plan which includes the following parts: burial of acid sulphate soils below the water table; construction of perimeter drains around the spoil ponds to catch any leachate; stockpiling of hydrated lime to be used in the acid treatment pond prior to discharge, if required; and an independent engineering check of the condition of the soil pond walls.

As I said, this was a report that was not flawed. I didn't ever say it was flawed, so I prefer you not to suggest that I did. I said that after it was peer reviewed by two eminent scientists/engineers there was advice as to ways in which it could be improved.

TALK.START.PARA: —They said it was flawed.
—He didn't say it was flawed. Have you read Professor White's report? I don't remember him saying it was flawed.
—What did he say?

—He set out some ways in which it should be improved. What I have said to Senator Faulkner is that the advice, as a result of this peer review, was taken into account in development of the plan that has been implemented.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a thorough plan that is designed to ensure that world heritage values are properly protected. There is no evidence to suggest that those world heritage values are not being adequately protected. As I said before, if there were more of such plans attached to other developments that have taken place in the past, or will take place in the future, along the Queensland coast adjacent to the Great Barrier Reef, then we as a nation would have greater confidence that those values will be protected from leaching of oil sulfate soils.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask the minister a supplementary question. He has not answered the substance of the question as to whether, when the plan was resubmitted, it went to Professor White and Dr Bowman of CSIRO. Why didn't you resubmit the amended plan to them? Why didn't you do that, Minister? Who provided to you the alternative advice on the amended plan? What we want to hear from you, Minister, is a guarantee that that advice was the best possible scientific and engineering advice available to you as Minister for the Environment. They are the questions you were asked, Minister. I would ask you to have a crack at answering them.

—Madam President—try as he might! The Queensland acid sulfate soil inspection team—experts in the field—appointed to perform the role of independent monitor for acid sulfate soils advised that the final plan will ensure that acid sulfate soils are adequately dealt with. Senator Faulkner, you do not understand the process. The process was that a plan was prepared that was believed to be adequate. It was put out for peer review. It did not have to be put out for peer review. It did not go to one reviewer; it went to two reviewers. They gave advice. As a result of their advice, the plan was further strengthened and has been implemented. The plan is ensuring that world heritage values are properly protected. There is no suggestion otherwise.

—My question is to the Special Minister of State, who is doing an outstanding job with the Native Title Amendment Bill. Minister, the Greens and the National Indigenous Working Group have made claims concerning the government's Native Title Amendment Bill—that our bill requires indigenous Australians to show a current physical connection to land to access their native title rights to land. Is this claim misleading? What is the true situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Abetz for his question. The Australian Greens and the Greens (WA) did put out a statement yesterday which, regrettably, does suggest that they have not quite understood key parts of the Native Title Amendment Bill and I think it is important for them to do so. Contrary to the views expressed in that statement, the government's bill does not set onerous requirements nor does the bill make it difficult for claimants to assert their traditional rights.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is important for us all to remember what the High Court decided in Mabo. The High Court decided in Mabo that courts can recognise common law native title based on indigenous people's traditional law and customs where the native title claimants can prove they have maintained their connection to the land and where it has not already been extinguished. The bill does not get in the way of courts making those decisions. It does remain under our bill for the courts to decide where native title exists, who holds it and what it might consist of in particular cases.

The bill does not require Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders to show any physical connection to the land in order for them to make their claim or to enjoy their native title rights. That is simply not part of the bill. What the bill does is as follows: for native title claims, the bill sets out clear and simple requirements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. I believe this bill is on the Notice Paper . Could you please direct the minister not to move into areas which are specifically dealt with in the bill.

—Order! The bill is on the Notice Paper . It is incumbent upon the minister to be careful not to intrude into those matters. There has been some laxity in recent times about questions being asked of matters on the Notice Paper , but the minister does need to be careful as to the extent to which he intrudes.

—Madam President, on the point of order: may I simply say that I am responding to a press release put out by Senator Margetts which made misleading statements about the nature of the government's proposals. My response is simply in response to those statements.
—You may proceed with answering it, keeping outside the areas in the bill.

—What the government is proposing is that a claim lodged on behalf of a group cannot cover areas where native title has already been extinguished, for example, on freehold land; it cannot claim exclusive possession of land where native title can only coexist; and it must define the areas and native title rights being claimed. These are very sensible proposals and should not be difficult for properly researched claims to meet.

BREAK.PARA: I want to say that the mix‐up in relation to the Greens is between making a claim and having that claim registered. Claimant groups can seek registration in order to access interim statutory access rights and the right to negotiate. In relation to your press release, I think it is important for you to understand the difference between lodging a claim and having it registered. For registration, at least one member of the claimant group must have or have had a traditional physical connection to some part of the land claimed. That is a very important difference. In relation to the Mabo test, the Mabo decision said that, in order to establish native title, you must prove to the court that you have maintained a traditional connection to the land. That is a matter entirely for the courts.

In relation to registration of a claim and the benefits that attach to registration, all we are saying in relation to a claim is that one member of the claimant group must be able to establish that they have or have had a physical connection to the land at some stage in their life. That is simply not an onerous requirement and it does not relate either to the claim being made or to proving the claim in court.

The bill does not restrict the number of claimants in a group. We understand that a lot of these claimant groups are very large indeed. All we are saying is that simply one member out of a whole claimant group, in order to get it registered, has to have or have had some connection with the land at some stage in their life. I think it would contribute to this public debate if people such as Senator Margetts understood what they are talking about, read the bill and understood it, understood the processes involved and understood what the High Court decided in the Mabo case.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, is it true that you were told that Keith Williams had begun the earthworks at Port Hinchinbrook before submitting an acid sulfate soil management plan? Is it true that the independent on‐site monitor at the time lost his job after pointing this out and recommending that work at the site be halted? Are you satisfied that the Queensland Acid Sulfate Soil Inspection Team is fully independent, or is it just an arm of the Queensland government, which will stop at nothing to have this development built? Finally, is it true that work has continued at the site, that significant damage will be done to the adjoining world heritage area as a consequence and that you are doing nothing absolutely nothing to prevent it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know how many times you can beat it. The point is that this is a development being carried out pursuant to best engineering practice and probably the most demanding deed of obligation that has ever been put into place with any development on the Queensland coast. The number of different assessments that need to take place, the number of different peer reviews and the level of monitoring are really quite extraordinary. But I do not apologise for that. I accept the responsibility to ensure that, when developments take place on the Queensland coast, world heritage values in the adjoining park are adequately protected. We put in place this process to ensure that, whilst this development took place, those values would be protected.

ANSWER.PARA: I have already drawn the contrast between our approach and the approach of the last Labor government. It allowed the acid sulfate soils to be disturbed; left them there for a period of 10 years under Mr Williams and under previous ownership; and did not care at all whether they got washed into the channel. That is the comparison; that is the alternative. That is the way that these things used to be done under Labor. Any comparison between that approach and the current approach, with its degree of scrutiny, management and engineering demand, tells its own story. The bottom line of this development process is that the acid sulfate soils are properly being contained during this construction phase. The plan is working and is being monitored by the Queensland Acid Sulfate Soil Inspection Team.

As for the great revelation of Senator Faulkner that some of the work started prematurely, I remind Senator Faulkner that I said last year that that had occurred and that there had been some breaches. I put out a public statement to that effect and set out the actions that I had taken to ensure that there were not any further breaches.

Again, the bottom line is that, despite those breaches, there was no damage to world heritage values. We are confident that the plan that is put in place will continue to protect the world heritage values. It will protect them—it is designed to protect them—during the wet season as well as the dry. Unlike what was suggested on the ABC last night, our best engineering advice—this is the way the plans have been constructed—is that the soils will be properly contained during a period of wet as well as a period of dry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister for the Environment confirm that, at the time Mr Keith Williams began earthworks prior to submitting an acid sulfate soil management plan, the independent on-site monitor lost his job after he pointed that out and after he recommended that work on the site be halted? Minister, isn't it actually true that in the case of the Port Hinchinbrook development, thanks to action taken by the previous Labor administration, you actually have in place the necessary mechanisms to exert some leadership and prevent acid sulfate damage, yet you have done nothing? You have found it all too hard to take on the developer and the Queensland government and do something about the obligations you have as federal environment minister to protect Australia's environment.

—That is so much nonsense, and Senator Faulkner knows it. He has lost the argument. Therefore, he seeks to assert a position rather than ask a question. The point is that there are two independent monitors. Professor Saenger has the responsibility of overall monitoring of the project. Beneath him there is the specialist acid sulfate monitoring team, the Queensland Acid Sulfate Soil Inspection Team—a team of experts. What better protection can be put in place to ensure the protection of these values? I suggest that this is an unprecedented level of protection and something that is in stark contrast to the disregard of these values by the previous Labor government and Senator Faulkner in particular.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for the Environment. I recognise that he is doing a good job and keeping a straight face trying to defend the indefensible in relation to Port Hinchinbrook. I understand his frustration, given that he was landed with this resort.
—Senator, what is your question?
—You are worse than Cheryl.

—I thank Senator Abetz for that compliment. I recognise that the minister was landed with this development by the Labor party, thanks to the previous state Labor government, the Goss government, giving this resort the go‐ahead. Has the minister received any expressions about another concern in north Queensland regarding the rate of land clearing in the Daintree region in Far North Queensland? Can he confirm that low coastal rainforests north of the Daintree River have been subject to several incidents of illegal clearing in recent weeks? Can he inform the Senate how much land has been cleared in that region in the last three months?
—It is privately owned.
—Does he agree that further clearing of private or publicly owned land in this area will have an irreparable impact on the ecological values of that area? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —We are concerned about any clearing that takes place in the Daintree region. We have to distinguish of course between that which is within the world heritage area and that which is not. Within the world heritage area, there is a prohibition on clearing for commercial purposes and, when we get evidence of such an occurrence and we are able to prove it, we will take the appropriate action under the law.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been three instances of that that I recall. In the first instance, I appointed a special investigator under the legislation, as I have the power to do. It was properly investigated and the advice came back to say there was not a case for prosecution. In the second instance, I would need to refresh my memory but, as I recall, it was not dissimilar. The third instance is the one that has been getting publicity outside the world heritage area of recent times. Senator Bartlett, who I now take the opportunity to welcome to the Senate, would be aware of our efforts to seek to put in place local land clearing rules under the local shire council.

BREAK.PARA: Finally, I am pleased to say that the Queensland government and the shire have agreed that such land clearance obligations should be put in place. They will be put in place and we are facilitating that as we are able. I am pleased to say that it is quite a cooperative approach to the issue now. That will give us greater assurance in the future that any clearing in important areas in the Daintree—notwithstanding that they are not in the world heritage area—will be properly managed for the future. I think that is the position that most Australians would like to see adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you for the answer, Minister. Given that some clearing guidelines have been put in place by the local Douglas Shire Council—but it appears that, at least currently, they are unwilling to enforce those laws and are allowing land to be cleared in contravention of them—what pressure are you bringing to bear as federal environment minister to ensure that illegal clearing is prosecuted? You would be aware of funds that have been expended to date in the Daintree rescue package to protect the area by buying the land back before it is cleared by the mates of the guys on my left. Will you consider providing further funds for a revitalised Daintree rescue package to protect this area before it is too late and before further land clearing is done?
—It is private land.

—Obviously, the National Party folks on my left are quite happy for the land to be cleared. Minister, I seek a commitment from you that you will do what you can to prevent that land—whether it is private or public—from being cleared. Perhaps for the education of your colleagues here, you could confirm that, regardless of whether it is public or private, if it is cleared, it causes environmental damage.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to give gratuitous advice, but it is not a bad idea if the honourable senator listened to the answer before he read the pre‐prepared supplementary question because I had actually answered most of what he included in the supplemen tary. After 16 years, you are allowed to give a bit of gratuitous advice.

ANSWER.PARA: The point is that we agree that there are important conservation values in that region, whether they be within the world heritage area or not. You are correct that we have been participating in the buyback, which will lead to an extension of preservation. There will always be areas with important conservation values outside of reserves and we are keen to see in place effective local laws to ensure the conservation values in that regard. That is why we have been working cooperatively with both the shire and the Queensland government to ensure that those local laws are in place, that they are adequate and that they are enforced. We will continue with that approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Senator Kemp, since your duties involve helping design the tax laws, can you tell the Senate whether the government supports companies which buy back their own shares and simultaneously create an artificial capital tax loss for their shareholders to be offset against future capital gains? Does part 4A of the tax act apply to such transactions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you Madam President, and thank you to Senator Cook for the question.
—That always means you don't have an answer.
—It is always a pleasure to get a question from Senator Cook.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't know what all the fuss is about. I am trying to reply to Senator Cook and there is a lot of noise from the other side. Senator, you are referring, I think, to an issue which is currently before the government and which you and I are both aware of. The tax office is currently looking at that particular issue and—
—Which issue is that?

—You wouldn't know, Kim, because you never ever read the newspapers, but Senator Cook certainly knows what I am referring to. The tax office is currently examining this particular issue and I will be in a position to advise you of this in due course.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the tax office is looking at the question, as you say, Senator, can you tell us what action the government intends to take to prevent the Commonwealth Bank of Australia artificially manufacturing millions of dollars in capital losses for its shareholders to be funded by the Australian taxpayer? What do you intend to do about that?

—What we always intend to do is to enforce the law. That is what the role of the government is. What I have said to you, Senator, is that the ATO is currently examining this particular issue, and I understand that the Taxation Office is meeting with the CBA today.

—My question is directed to the Special Minister of State, Senator Minchin. I refer the minister to the government publication, recently circulated as an insert in many Australian newspapers, called `Republic—yes or no'. Is it appropriate that taxpayers' money has been spent on promoting just two groups standing for the Constitutional Convention—Australians for a Constitutional Monarchy, the ACM, and the minimalist Australian Republican Movement, ARM—with almost one‐eighth of the document given over to advertising the views of just those two groups; that is, no change and minimal change. Given that, for example, three out of the seven grouped candidates and 10 out of the 17 ungrouped candidates standing for the Constitutional Convention in Western Australia are calling for wider constitutional reforms to be discussed, is the minister satisfied that the publication even attempts to represent community views in relation to wider constitutional reform?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —The government, very responsibly and probably, I think, for the first time in this nation's history, undertook to distribute very important, useful and factual information about the Australian constitution, based on the facts revealed by the Labor government's own research into public awareness and understanding of our constitution. That research showed that some 80 per cent of Australians actually do not know what is in the constitution; 73 per cent do not know what the Governor‐General does; 52 per cent do not know what a republic would mean for Australia; and nearly half the community could not name both houses of the federal parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: In the face of that research, the federal government, quite responsibly, decided to devote some limited resources to distributing easily read, factual, objective information about the Australian constitution to benefit people both in the lead‐up to the election of delegates to the convention and for the convention itself. That document described factually the current constitutional arrangements and what benefits there were in those.

The document also went into quite some detail about all the issues involved in any move to a republic, in a very fair and objective way given that the government's position is that no change is required. The government spent its resources on explaining to people all the issues involved in any move to a republic, it canvassed all the options: what is involved in any—

TALK.START.PARA: —Your resources!

—The taxpayers' resources, Senator Bolkus. We explained what issues were involved in any move that would involve the appointment or election of a president and what the consequences of that would be. The question of the powers of a president were examined and explained in some detail.

ANSWER.PARA: We also made the decision that it would be a good opportunity for both sides of this debate to have their say in this document, which was distributed in newspapers around the country. Some 6¾million copies of that document were distributed around the country in newspaper inserts.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are more than two sides and you know it.

—There are broadly two sides to this debate: are you for a repub lic or are you against a republic? I know that for the Greens there might be millions of sides of lots of debates, and you always have trouble working out which side of a debate you are on, but basically I think that most Australians understand that the debate here is: are you for a republic or are you against a republic?

ANSWER.PARA: We have two main community groups who stand for one side or the other of this debate: the Australians for a Constitutional Monarchy and the Australian Republican Movement. They broadly represent the two sides of this debate. We did offer to those two groups the opportunity to explain their cases in this document. We presented very fairly, on the back of this document, their unedited, unscripted, uncensored declarations of the arguments for and against the republic.

I think we produced a great service to the Australian people in the lead‐up to this convention election and to the convention itself. I am surprised that someone like Senator Margetts, who is so interested in public debate and information going out to the community, would complain about what the government has done here. It is the first time that a federal government has taken the initiative to distribute on a mass scale easily read and understandable information about the Australian constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister recognise that, despite his press release of 28 August that stated that the convention would only deal with the question of whether or not Australia should become a republic, and if so what the best republican model is—and that could, in fact, mean anything—that the convention is free to set its own agenda and could, for example, set in process for the community to debate whether or not the Australian constitution should include a preamble to recognise prior indigenous occupation of Australia. How could you gag the selected or elected delegates who represent those community views?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —The government convened this convention in order for it to examine the questions of whether or not Australia should become a republic, what sort of republican model Australia should have if we are to move to a republic, and what the timing and circumstances are if any change should be considered. The Prime Minister has already said that he hopes the convention will devote most of its time to developing an appropriate republican model. That is the job of the convention.

ANSWER.PARA: Ultimately, of course it is a matter for the 152 delegates present to decide how they want to conduct that debate. I am very confident—as I am sure the Labor Party is—that this convention will be keen to debate what sort of republican model we are to adopt if we are to become a republic, and to have the threshold debate about whether or not we should make the change.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. I refer the minister to the Treasurer's press release of 8 August 1997, headed `Budget measures to prevent trading in franking credits'. Minister, given your responsibility for the detailed design of taxation laws, could you therefore explain the risk diminution aspect of the 45‐day rule applying to the government's proposed measures to prevent trading in franking credits. Can you confirm whether, in a situation where the net equity risk is such that the net delta of a financial derivative is less than 0.7, the arrangement will not attract the risk diminution aspect of the 45‐day rule?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for the compliment that I designed this particular law. However, it was people other than me who were able to draft this particular legislation. There is an issue in relation to trading in franking credits. We were attempting to protect a system which has worked well in the Australian community, and the purpose of the legislation was to make sure that the credits actually flowed to those people who bore the economic risk.

ANSWER.PARA: When this announcement was made in the budget context, there were widespread discussions with the community. There were some amendments made to address some of the issues which were raised. But there are some fairly technical aspects to that question, Senator O'Brien. I will come back and advise you as to the context of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Unless you can answer it now, Minister, you might need to come back on this other matter: will you also explain how the risk diminution aspect of the 45-day rule will apply to employee share ownership schemes; and what is the situation where the employer is wholly owned by non-residents?
—I will seek advice on that particular issue and come back to you with an answer.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Minister, will you inform the Senate of this government's commitment to an industry led training system which provides opportunities for young people; will you also inform the Senate of the recent developments in this system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McGauran for that question. It was acknowledged last night by Robert Gerard, the President of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, that some of the initiatives we have seen developing in the education and training arena over the last 18 months, led by industry, are world class. A strong role for industry in the training system is a high priority for this government. This will ensure that together we will secure a vocational education and training system that provides Australia and its business with a competitive edge through a highly skilled work force.

ANSWER.PARA: This government has made very significant reforms in the training system. The national new apprenticeships initiative takes the concept of quality training into new industries and occupations. It will meet the needs of employers and young people. In addition, the Commonwealth in funding through ANTA has committed $560 million in incentives to employers, apprentices and trainees to support up to 220,000 places over the period from 1997 to 1999. New apprenticeships will be competency based, and this represents a significant move from the traditional time based apprenticeship system.

It is interesting to note that the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union is reported in today's paper as providing an apprentice system for children of union members. This is another aspect with the union seeing that having a private provider or user choice system is a very good idea. There are still those in New South Wales who do not think this choice is such a good idea. But, obviously, the CFMEU sees merit in this because it is setting up its own system for apprentices. That would seem to suggest that it too agrees with the government's policies on this matter.

On the question of more jobs for school leavers, this government has introduced the jobs pathway program through which we are funding 70 projects to provide assistance to more than 20,000 young people at 1,100 secondary schools across the country. Up to 10,000 young school leavers will be found jobs, and a further 10,000 young people at risk of leaving school early will be encouraged to remain at school.

I am also pleased to announce that at the ANTA ministerial council last Friday—and no doubt Senator Carr will be interested in this—the ministers for vocational education and training endorsed a revised ANTA agreement for submission to their respective state and territory cabinets for approval. Unfortunately, the minister from New South Wales was unable to attend due to parliamentary commitments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense.

—But we look forward to New South Wales coming on board in this regard, Senator Carr. In that agreement, the Commonwealth has set its funding for the next three years—some $2.6 billion in funding for vocational education and training—and this is in addition to some $400 million annually funded for other Commonwealth vocational education and training programs.

ANSWER.PARA: May I also touch on another aspect which I experienced—and Senator Carr would remember this because he was there—and that was at the Australian National Training Authority training awards function which was held last week. That was a particularly successful evening. I had the privilege to present the Apprentice of the Year award to Jason Jones from the Northern Territory. Jason has taken on an apprenticeship in carpentry and joinery after working as a labourer in the industry for several years. That young man provides an excellent role model for other young people. But his was not the only success story that night. Senator Carr could attest to the fact that there were a good many other successes, including with older people taking on apprenticeships. In one particular case, a person advanced in years qualified. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer. I refer the minister to an article in the Australian Financial Review on 28 October entitled `Hardship in tax relief law change'. Has the department advised the minister that if a small business person belongs to a non-fixed family trust and another beneficiary in the trust holds at least one share in either a public or private company unrelated to the trust, then that company is considered a connected entity for the purposes of determining the $5 million rollover eligibility threshold?
—I am aware of that particular article. The issue has been brought to the attention of the government. I believe we will be moving an amendment to deal with that particular problem.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, does this mean that if a non-small business person beneficiary holds 100 shares in Telstra, then all of Telstra's assets would be included in the calculation of the $5 million eligibility threshold under the newly inserted sections of the Income Tax Assessment Act?
—On that particular matter, I will seek advice—
—Oh!

—Well, the tax law raises particular issues. Senator, I regret to say that the last time you asked me a question, the underlying assumption was wrong but, because you presumably want a serious answer to that question, I will seek advice and provide it to you.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. Minister, in question time on 30 October, I asked you—and it has taken me this long to get a partial answer—whether calling number display, CND, would be introduced if the 80 per cent awareness levels had not been achieved. Minister, you were unable to answer the question then. Since then you have put out a press release which has partially answered my queries. As I understand it, Minister, you are seeking commitments from Telstra, Optus and Vodafone for appropriate safeguards. My questions are: what are the appropriate safeguards? What will you do if the 80 per cent awareness of how to opt out of CND is not achieved? Who decides what is the 80 per cent awareness?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —We have informed the three carriers of the government's determination to seek compliance with the safeguards recommended by the Privacy Advisory Committee of the former telecommunications regulator Austel. Those safeguards included the 80 per cent public awareness of the introduction of CND. Senator Stott Despoja asked: what is public awareness? I am happy to have that debate at another time. She also asked about the use of appropriate ethical procedures by organisations which receive CND services.

ANSWER.PARA: We are requesting these measures on an interim basis, and that is the platform on which I have written to the carriers. Optus and Vodafone have already introduced CND, and Telstra's plans are to operate from 1 December. We have requested these measures on an interim basis pending the development by the Australian Communications Industry Forum of a code of practice on CND issues, which will be registered with the Australian Communications Authority.

I have asked the carriers to comply with the principles and the requirements set out in the PAC report which, of course, includes the 80 per cent awareness requirement. I have asked the carriers also to include provisions in their contracts with business and government customers indicating that they should comply with the guidelines set out in the PAC report. These guidelines set out the PAC suggested appropriate, ethical procedures for use by organisations which receive CND services. Some concerns have been expressed about the potential use of CND, and the PAC's recommendations are designed to address these concerns.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you have said that you are happy to have the debate about what constitutes public awareness at another time. I think the debate is appropriate here. Firstly, how can you assess what is 80 per cent public awareness if you do not have a definition of what constitutes public awareness? Secondly, you refer to a code of practice. If these measures are due to begin on 1 December, when do you expect that code of practice to be registered? There is not a lot of time between now and 1 December. Minister, there are no privacy protections or laws in place and, from what we can see, there will be none by 1 December when CND is going to be introduced. What assurances can you provide the public that the CND service will have adequate privacy protections to guarantee that consumers' information is safe?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice that Senator Stott Despoja does not make any attempt to define public awareness for the blindingly obvious reason that I think everyone understands what is meant by the concept—in other words: is the public aware of what is involved in caller number identification? That is what public awareness is about: is the public aware? If you want to offer an alternative definition, you let me know about it and we will take it into account at some later stage.

ANSWER.PARA: Clearly, you did not understand what I said about 1 December being the operative date. The request to the carriers is designed as an interim measure pending the formulation by ACIF of the guidelines and the code of practice, which will be determined over a period, but in the interim we want to make sure there is no gap. That is why we have asked the carriers to, as quickly as possible, come back to us with assurances as to how they will comply and how they will request others to comply with both the public awareness requirement and the ethical procedures.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, in light of your responsibility for the detailed design of taxation laws, can you outline to the Senate how the government's proposed new arranger provisions for FBT will differ from current arrangements? Isn't it a fact that, under the government's proposal, if a third-party—say, a client—invites an employee to lunch, and the employer did not stop the employee attending the lunch, then FBT would apply? Could you please explain why the government wishes to impose FBT when an employer and an employee both attend a lunch provided by a client, yet if an employee attends on their own there may or may not be an FBT liability? Could you further explain the circumstances under which FBT will be payable when an employee attends a lunch provided by the client and those circumstances where no FBT will be payable if the employee attends the lunch?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a whole host of questions there.
—There was one issue.

—No, there was a host of questions there—all of which relate to the FBT issues which your government brought in and which, you are quite right to say, caused very extensive problems to small business. On that issue, you are absolutely right. What we have done in relation to FBT is look at the issue and the problems that you have raised and consult with small business and bring in amendments which, of course, will deal with at least some of those problems that you have raised.

ANSWER.PARA: You have raised a whole host of questions in relation to the arranger provisions and, you are quite right, they were a problem. Those particular provisions were causing problems to small business. In relation to tax advice, I am always naturally cautious to give tax advice. Of course one is cautious, because there are many circumstances involved in this. Senator, if you are genuinely interested in this issue, I will look at the questions that you have raised and reply to them. I will take those questions on notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, in that question there was really one issue, and one issue only. I will ask you to answer this question: can you explain the circumstances under which FBT will be payable when an employee attends a lunch provided by the client and those circumstances when no FBT would be payable if the employee attends the lunch? Why are there different circumstances?

—The issue is whether the employee attends the lunch at the request of the employer or whether he attends the lunch not at the request of the employer. That is the difference, Senator. That is one of the issues which were raised in relation to these arranger provisions.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Cultural Industry Strategy

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron. How will the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural industry strategy which was launched today assist indigenous Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Knowles for the question. This morning I jointly launched the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural industry strategy with my colleague Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. The national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural industry strategy is about enabling indigenous Australians to promote their culture, create jobs and generate income. When implemented, it will provide significant economic opportunities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities.

ANSWER.PARA: Unemployment is still a grave concern for indigenous Australians with an unemployment rate of 38 per cent. Also, only two per cent of the indigenous working age population are self‐employed compared with eight per cent for the total working age population.

The national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural industry strategy has strong links with the tourism industry. Tourists are interested in the uniqueness and diversity of indigenous culture. Indigenous arts and crafts are estimated to be worth nearly $200 million per annum with tourist purchases of indigenous arts and crafts estimated as being over 50 per cent of total sales. I thought, Madam President, even the opposition would be interested in this in the interests of their constituents.

The strategy highlights the importance of promoting and marketing indigenous cultural industries domestically and internationally and is linked to the recently launched national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander tourism industry strategy.

There are many opportunities through identification of investment opportunities, employment and product development and partnerships in the tourism sector. The strategy will encourage indigenous people to make the most of opportunities such as those available at the Sydney 2000 Olympics and the Paralympics. A productive and progressive partnership between indigenous and non‐indigenous Australians within the cultural industry must be encouraged if we are to see indigenous people develop economically in this area.

As you know, Madam President, this is what indigenous people constantly ask: that they be allowed to be economically independent so that they can have self‐empowerment. The government is supporting their endeavours in that regard. The national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural industry strategy has the potential to create employment and economic benefits for indigenous people, besides being important to the Australian economy as a whole.

This is the third of three strategies that have been released over a period of time; the first being the rural industry strategy, the second being the tourism strategy, and now the cultural industry strategy. All are designed to produce employment for indigenous people, particularly recognising the abilities that they have in areas where there is no other employment available for them. This gives them the opportunity by linking together the marketing opportunities that are available, particularly with joint ventures, to have control. Importantly and overriding in this respect is that they have control of the marketing of their own culture; a vivid culture which is unique to this country, a culture that we must respect and recognise, and promote on behalf of the indigenous people themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to my answer to Senator Jacinta Collins's question without notice in question time yesterday about drugs and the claims that on 5 November 1997 the Port Kembla office of the Australian Customs Service asked the Wollongong shark patrol to provide a surveillance flight for one of its officers at no charge because they lacked the funds to pay for it, I have been provided with the following advice.

SPEECH.PARA: Based on information from a New South Wales police officer that a vessel was acting suspiciously in waters south of Moruya, the Port Kembla office of the Australian Customs Service approached a local aerial service company, Wollongong Aerial Patrol, on 5 November 1997 to establish if an aircraft was available for surveillance purposes if necessary. Customs has mechanisms in place whereby coastwatch can engage civilian aerial services for surveillance purposes. This is on a fully paid basis.

During the course of further Customs inquiries regarding the vessel, it was established the vessel was undertaking routine fishing functions and that Customs intervention was not necessary. Had the incident turned out to be a high priority tasking, appropriate aerial services would have been engaged on a fully paid basis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to a number of questions which were asked of me by Senators Lundy, O'Brien and Murphy, I have sought the advice—
—Order! There is too much noise in the chamber and too many people moving about. Would senators take their seats?
—Senator Forshaw, cease interjecting.
—As I said, three questions were raised in relation to IT matters. I have sought the advice of the Minister for Finance and Administration and I am now able to provide that advice to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to matters that Senators Lundy, O'Brien and Murphy raised in relation to the sale of FIRM, I am advised that in accordance with the government's competitive tendering and contracting policy, the Department of Finance and Administration has commissioned a scoping study on the feasibility of the sale of the Commonwealth Payroll Service and its central accounting and payment service, including existing FIRM system software. This scoping study is being conducted by KPMG Corporate Finance. The consultant's final report is due to be provided to the department later this week.

Contrary to Senator Lundy's assertion yesterday, the minister advises me that preliminary findings of the study indicate that the sale of the CPS and CAPS is feasible. However, until the government has had an opportunity to digest the contents of the final report, no decision will be made in respect of the sale of CPS and CAPS.

There were questions from Senator Lundy in relation to the accrual budgeting system. The Minister for Finance and Administration advises me that in a completely different scoping study on the implementation of an accrual budgeting framework, the issue of a suitable central financial management system for the Commonwealth was considered.

BREAK.PARA: The scoping study considered a number of alternative system scenarios. Given that firm has a cash accounting system only which is incapable of performing the requirements of an accrual framework, KPMG, who advised the scoping study team on systems related issues, recommended that firms should be replaced by an off‐the‐shelf system. Subsequent to the scoping study, the department specified the user requirements for the central system and invited suitable vendors on the OGIT shared systems suite to undertake scoping studies and propose solutions to satisfy these requirements.

Again, I am advised by the Minister for Finance and Administration that, contrary to Senator Lundy's assertion yesterday, no decision has yet been made and no system has yet been purchased. The department is currently evaluating solutions proposed by vendors.

Senators O'Brien and Murphy raised questions in relation to the outsourcing of applications development. In relation to the question on the outsourcing of applications development, I can again provide some information from the Minister for Finance and Administration.

The Department of Finance and Administration has not awarded any contract for applications development or maintenance work in relation to firm and pay systems to IBM GSA. The department has sought bids under the DAS PE63 contract for IT services for application development and maintenance services to supplement in‐house resources. Contractual negotiations with the preferred bidder, Computer Power, are nearing completion. IBM GSA was not invited to submit a proposal. This is not related to the Department of Finance and Administration IBM GSA contract or the whole of government outsourcing initiative. Almost all government departments have employed contractors in their applications and systems development for many years.

Senator Murphy raised a question in relation to the OAS IT security. On the issue of the OAS information technology, the chief executive has indicated that this issue was among the first of the matters he identified as requiring resolution and the amalgamation of OAS with the IT outsourcing functions from OGIT. He has indicated his intention of negotiating with the Department of Finance and Administration and IBM GSA to dispense with the services of IBM GSA following the physical collocation of the two functions during December. The OASIT would then move to appoint an appropriate contractor to manage its small in‐house desktop IT functions under arrangements that would be seen to fully protect the probity and security of access to OASIT information. The details of this change have yet to be developed.

The OASIT would not wish this move to be interpreted as any criticism of IBM GSA whose service to the OAS in the short term that has been in place has been commendable if it is seen necessary to avoid any suggestion that IBM GSA could have inappropriate access to OASIT information relevant to contracts in which it may have an interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation on the grounds that I claim to have been misrepresented.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In desperate tactics, Senator Minchin may have seen that the ground is shifting, but the minister has indicated that I said something in a press release and that the National Indigenous Working Group said something in a press release which indicated that we stated that you had to require indigenous people to demonstrated a current physical connection in order to claim native title. We double‐checked the press release. On the back page of the statements `Key principles of the National Indigenous Working Group on Native Title', the wording says `requiring indigenous people to demonstrate a current physical connection to land in order to enjoy native title.' The minister indicated that, in fact, a physical connection was required from at least one claimant to register for native title. So he has, in fact, proved that the press release was correct.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT—Senators Ferris and McGauran, on behalf of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, have raised a matter of privilege under standing order 81 and ask that I give precedence to a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee.

In debate in the Senate on 23 October 1997, Senator Conroy referred to the content of an advice received by the committee from its legal adviser. The committee states that it had not authorised the disclosure of this advice. If this is correct, there appears to have been an unauthorised disclosure of the document by Senator Conroy.

For the reasons indicated in my determinations on 23 and 28 October relating to other instances of alleged unauthorised disclosure of committee documents, I determine that a motion relating to this matter may have precedence in accordance with standing order 81.
I table the correspondence from Senators Ferris and McGauran. A notice of motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee may now be given.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the following matter be referred to the Committee of Privileges:
Whether there was an unauthorised disclosure of any advice to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, and, if so, whether any contempt was committed in that regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), to questions without notice asked by Senator Faulkner today, relating to the acid sulphate soils disturbed by the Hinchinbrook development.

SPEECH.PARA: During question time today, Senator Hill was asked a number of questions about the issue of acid sulfate soil management in the Great Barrier Reef. I remind the Senate that the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill, launched an important booklet, which was commissioned by me prior to the election, called An introduction to acid sulfate soils .

TALK.START.PARA: —No wonder the ABC had it last night!

—You pointed out during the launch of this booklet that such soils were a serious problem and I am disappointed that you are laughing about the matter now. In fact, you said that $1 million‐worth of fish from east coast commercial markets were rejected each year due to diseases related to acid sulfate soils. You also said in your speech that this was the tip of the iceberg. The minister's contribution is important; what a tragedy it is that he is unable to heed his own words. What a tragedy it is that he just read a speech about the importance of acid sulfate soil management, but did not actually read the booklet. The minister should listen to the Jack Beale Professor of Water Resources at the Australian National University, Professor Ian White, a world expert on acid sulfate soils.

SPEECH.PARA: What Professor White said last week was that if Port Hinchinbrook was a chemical factory or a mine it would be shut down. This is the same Professor White who not only reviewed the original acid sulfate management plan for Port Hinchinbrook, but latterly has had an opportunity to look at the actual acid sulfate soil management plan that has been approved by Senator Hill.

What Senator Hill appears to be very disappointed about is that the ABC has got hold of this management plan. The history of this matter is most interesting. Dr Bowman of the CSIRO found that the original plan, cooked up by Keith Williams, the developer, with the Queensland government, was seriously flawed. Of course, he was not consulted again. The plan was re‐jigged but the revised plan was not sent back to Dr Bowman. The Queensland government set up its own body to review the revised plan, and surprise, surprise, Madam Deputy President, it got the tick.

Earthworks proceeded at Port Hinchinbrook; the developer defied Senator Hill, who called for a halt to the work until the plan was approved. There was hardly any change to the proposed plan; stable acid sulfate soils were dug out, left to bake in the sun over months and months—something you just cannot do with those soils—and Professor White has looked at the amended plan that was approved by Senator Hill, still finds it inadequate and has called for a close‐down of work.

Jes Sammut, the author of my booklet on acid sulfate soils, has reviewed the plan and he has found it seriously wanting. Of course, Port Hinchinbrook is just one site along the east coast which has the potential to unleash sulfuric acid into World Heritage waters. But it is the one development site along the coast about which Senator Hill has the power to show some leadership, call a halt to the work, get world‐ respected scientific authorities into the site and do what has to be done before the acid affects the corals, causes heavy metals and ultimately rots the foundations of the resort itself.

What has he done, of course? Nothing. He wants to trash the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. He would not express his confidence in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority because they are willing to stand up to Senator Hill on this issue; they are willing to show some leadership and have some guts on this issue. This is a minister who has miserably, abjectly failed in terms of fulfilling his obligations in protecting this most important area.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner has to leave; I wanted to tell him that GBRMPA approved the turbidity control plan, including the acid sulfate plan, in accordance with the terms of the deed. So much for what you believe would be the attitude of GBRMPA to this plan!

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose the only useful thing that has come out of this debate today is that some further publicity has been given to a serious national issue—that is, the management of acid sulfate soils. As I said in question time, they cover a very large part of coastal Australia. A lesson we have learnt over the years is that they need to be managed carefully and they were not always so managed in the past. A lot of current research has taken place on ways of more effectively managing such soils to avoid damage. It is something that we applaud and support, as was demonstrated by my launch of the booklet which Senator Faulkner referred to.

Madam Deputy President, it should be remembered that this was a project that the Queensland Labor government supported and approved. As far as the on‐site development was concerned, apparently, Senator Faulkner supported it as well. Senator Faulkner, as you might recall, took certain actions to protect some of the vegetation types, but he did not take actions that stopped disturbance of the soils, the criticism of which he is now making here today.

When we inherited this matter, it was a partly developed site. It had been cleared and partly excavated a number of times over a long period. But it also occurred under the Labor government. The acid sulfate soils had been disturbed and they had sat there for 10 years, being weathered and so forth. In complaining about us, he says they were left to withstand one summer. Under him, Labor left them to withstand 10 summers. Of course, that is different, because Labor is in opposition; it is no longer in government.

Labor basically supported this project. It is true that there were modifications in relation to foreshore management, but basically Labor supported it. I presume that if Labor had stayed in government, they would have done something similar to us, which was to put in place a management plan to ensure that the further excavation and development of the site was done in a way that would safeguard the site from a number of potential dangers. One of those potential dangers is unwise management of the acid sulfate soils. I presume Labor would have done that, but we did not have the opportunity to find out.

The important point is that when we came into government we did that. We had the developer sign on to a deed which we believe applied the most onerous, demanding obligations—he would not like to hear `onerous'; I should say most rigorous obligations—to ensure that the World Heritage values that are not on the site but are adjacent to the site are protected. In other words, in relation to acid sulfate, to ensure that the acid sulfate soils are not washed into the adjoining ocean where they may or may not cause some damage in the future.

We therefore required a plan for acid sulfate management to be approved. We were not satisfied just to leave it at that. We then required that that plan be peer reviewed by two separate scientists. It was peer reviewed. We took into account the advice that was given in those reviews and then applied a more demanding final plan. As I said, that plan went through the approval process, ultimately being approved by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, which has the principal responsibility for oversight of this development for us, in a way that protects the World Heritage values.

In question time I set out the safeguards that have been built into that plan to ensure that acid sulfate soils cannot be washed out to sea, even in the wet season, and therefore ensure the world heritage values against any inadvertent flow of water off those soils. The key point in this whole debate is that the best advice that I can get is that the plan is working well, there has been no damage to world heritage values and there is no case to suggest there has been any damage. That really undermines Labor's case. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I have real interest in this issue because it was an issue that was widely canvassed earlier this year at a hearing of the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee in Ballina. A real focus came on this issue of acid sulfate soils and the real inability of our society to deal with the issue because we have not known a great deal about it in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: Now there is an emerging raft of research on the issue. As the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill, said, and rightly so, if the acid sulfate soil had been disturbed on that site and had been exposed—and therein lies the problem—then the development should have been stopped point blank. The issue should have been dealt with and not allowed to proceed.

BREAK.PARA: The body of research knowledge that is emerging tells us that this problem is far worse than we have even contemplated. It says that we really need to address the issue properly. The suggestion that was put up during question time by Senator Hill that we would bury the acid sulfate soil below the water table once the development had been completed leaves the issue widely open to dispute.
