What we have here is no solution to the problem whatsoever.

The problem starts to exist once the acid sulfate soil is exposed. The acid sulfate soil then oxidises and once water comes upon it, it then forms sulfuric acid. What we have here is a problem that cannot be buried. It does not matter how far you try to bury it because, as we heard in the evidence that was given to us in Ballina, as the water settles on the acid sulfate soil that has been oxidised and the water then comes to the surface, you still have the same problem. You have got the problem of sulfuric acid that will leach into the system. Then you have got the problem in regard to damage to fish life, mangroves, the general environment, corals and so on. Burying it below the water table, as I understand the problem, is not the simple answer.

Whilst Senator Hill gave undertakings about scrutiny, management and what would or would not be happening during the construction period, the real problem would occur when the construction is finished. I believe that that is the criticism that is being levelled at the project at this stage. The government has not addressed it because the experts cannot address it.

We have a major problem of mounds of acid sulfate soil and what to do with it? Burying it is not the answer. What is the answer? Something should have happened in the first place when the management plan was found to be ineffective, inefficient and was rejigged. We have got the Queensland acid sulfate inspection team overseeing it and my information is that they are not the most experienced people in this country. There are people of far greater expertise. When one has people such as Professor White and others being critical of the current processes, then the government needs to act now because the problem is one that does not simply go away by burying it.

What we need to see is this government not trying to fob off the problem, not pretending that there is an easy remedy to the problem, but dealing directly with the problem. If they had heard the range of experts that I have heard on this issue, they would know that the solution is not simple. It is not simply trying to bury it in the ground. That is something that the government needs to take note of and desperately needs to do something about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —Like my friend on the other side of the chamber, I have had quite an interest in acid sulfate soils. He is absolutely correct when he says that the problem is when acid sulfate soils are exposed. It is absolutely true what Senator Hogg said, it is when the acid sulfate soil is exposed and it begins to oxidise that you have problems.

SPEECH.PARA: What Senator Hogg did not tell this Senate was that these acid sulfate soils were exposed in the mid‐1980s. They were in fact exposed during the time that the Labor Party, the party of which Senator Hogg is a member, was the federal government. They were exposed at the time that venerable former Senator Richardson was the Minister for the Environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wanton vandalism.
—What was the concern of the Labor Party in the mid‐1980s about acid sulfate soils at Port Hinchinbrook? The answer is that there was no concern.
—No research or understanding.
—Senator Hogg interjects that there was no research or understanding.
—He admits it.

—He admits it. There was absolutely no research by the Labor Party. There was no understanding by the Labor Party. When the research was done they did absolutely nothing about it. That is the truth. That is what happened under the Labor Party. What a difference a day makes, Senator Watson. What a difference an election day makes. As soon as they find themselves in opposition, suddenly this is an issue. When Senator Faulkner was Minister for the Environment—we certainly had the research by then, Senator Hogg—did Senator Faulkner do anything about this? No, Senator Faulkner did nothing about it either because it was not an issue for them. Now they are in opposition they suddenly find that it is an issue.

SPEECH.PARA: What Senator Hogg, my friend on the other side of the chamber, did not tell the Senate was this: this government has put in place one of the most stringent environmental management plans that could possibly be put in place. Senator Hogg was correct in saying that it is not sufficient to merely bury acid sulphate soils. What Senator Hogg did not tell the Senate was that that is only part of the management plan. The other part of the management plan involves the building of ponds, of drainage systems and of treatment of the water. We do not just let this water flow into the channel. The water first has to go into a drainage channel.

Here is an interesting fact. The ABC report last night vindicated the work of this government because in fact what it showed was so-called acidic water being taken from a channel. The whole point of the channel is to stop acidic water flowing out into the passage. The water flows into a channel and then from there it goes to a sump and from there it can be treated. But the ABC did not bother telling people this. This is proof that the system works because this water was not allowed to flow straight out into the channel. What happened when the ALP was in government and these acid sulphate soils were exposed to the sun, not baking for one season but baking for 10 seasons in the sun, and when the run-off flowed directly from there into the passage? What was done by the ALP?

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing.

—Nothing. You are absolutely right, Senator Lightfoot. Nothing was done by the people who sit opposite. There was no control over leachates. There was no control over run‐off. There was no requirement to treat it. Nothing at all was done.
—No research.
—No research.
—No care.

—No care, as Senator Hill says. They could not care less. Their only care in this is that they think they can scare up some sort of environmental vote out of the whole thing. The truth is that if there is to be an environmental vote obtained as a result of this episode it is an environmental vote which will be obtained by the coalition because we have put plans in place to ensure that the vandals, as Senator Lightfoot described them, on the other side do not continue to neglect these problems.

BREAK.PARA: Dare I say it, isn't it a good thing that the ALP lost the last election because this problem would still continue at Port Hinchinbrook today. Nothing would have been done. There would have been no improvements. We have made very stringent efforts to ensure that we do protect the environment. What we do need to do is make stringent efforts to protect the ALP from their own environmental ignorance. That is what we are facing today—environmental ignorance from people who do not understand the issues, never took an interest in the issues and now suddenly have become converts on the road to environmental Damascus. All I can say is that they had better do a better job of penitence. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bartlett, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is worth reminding the Senate that this debate is about the potential damage to the Hinchinbrook channel and reminding the Senate about how magnificent an area that is. Obviously, as a representative from Queensland, it is something that I have a particularly strong interest in. It is a major asset, both an environmental and economic asset, for the Queensland people and this federal government has a legal responsibility to protect those world heritage values and protect this area from damage.

SPEECH.PARA: I must agree, as Senator Hill and Senator O'Chee have both pointed out, this is a problem that has been visited in the past at least in large part due to the actions of the Labor Party. The basic fact is that the Port Hinchinbrook resort should never have been given the go ahead in the first place.

BREAK.PARA: I do have some sympathy for the federal Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) trying to figure out a way of preventing the inevitable environmental damage that will occur from this resort from happening. Basically, he is on a hiding to nothing because there are so many different potential environmental impacts from this resort. Acid sulphate soils is simply one in a very long list. We have to sheet home a large proportion of the blame for that damage to the Queensland Labor Party because it was the Goss Labor government over so many years that bent over backwards to do everything it could to make sure this resort went ahead.

Whilst it is important to ask today what the federal environment minister is going to do about this issue, it is also important for the Senate to ask today what the Queensland Labor Party is going to do about this issue. There is a state election coming up in Queensland in the not too distant future, quite possibly March next year. Peter Beattie, the state opposition leader in Queensland, has been fairly silent about what the Labor Party is going to do about Port Hinchinbrook.

His federal colleague Mr Kerr has been reported in the press over the last few hours calling for work to halt at Port Hinchinbrook. That is always easy to say and I certainly congratulate him for his statements in that regard, but I would like to hear from the state Labor Party about whether they share that position, whether they will do something about this if they get back into government in Queensland next year. I would be very interested to hear what position they will take on that. It is important that Mr Beattie and the Queensland Labor Party make their position clear on this issue. Whilst it is a responsibility of the federal government, it is even more so a responsibility of the state government and it is much easier for them to put on tighter controls and to prevent damage from this development occurring.

Having mentioned that, the other question that still remains is what the national government is going to do and what the federal environment minister, Senator Hill, is going to do about this issue. It is a matter of great concern to the Democrats that it does appear that, despite the information that has been put forward not just over the last 24 hours but over many months prior to that, the federal government is going to continue to do not very much at all. It is clear that the minister knows about the dangers of acid sulphate soils. He has demonstrated that today in the chamber and from the speeches he has made in the past with the information booklets he has launched. So it is not a matter of his not being aware of the danger and the problems; it is a matter of his not being willing or perhaps not being able to act on it.

I have a great concern that a spokesperson on behalf of the minister was reported in AAP last night as saying that there has been no adverse impact on the world heritage values of the area to date. I think that is probably fairly debatable. Even if it is the case, that there has been no adverse impact to date, that gives the Democrats great concern because what do you do once the adverse impact becomes apparent? It means that the acid sulphate has escaped into the channel. The minister might be very skilled but I do not know how he is going to go about sucking all the acid out of the Hinchinbrook channel. It is a little bit late to be worrying about the impact once it becomes apparent.

There are enormous amounts of information that have been given by eminent scientists—Senator Hill himself calls them eminent scientists—that this is a disaster waiting to happen. It is a disaster that needs to be prevented now, not one where we sit back and wait for it to happen and then have to do something. The big issue is whether Senator Hill is going to join the Queensland Premier, Mr Borbidge, up in Port Hinchinbrook to celebrate the opening of the first stage of this resort next month, or whether he is going to join the Democrats and others in taking the environmentally responsible path of preventing it from being opened and helping to close it down. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lightfoot, Sen Phillip

TALK.START.PARA: —During my short time here I have been continually surprised at the way that the opposition knocks Australia. It is no exception today with the opposition knocking the development at Port Hinchinbrook. I think it is very valid to express one's fear over developments of this nature if those fears are expressed and are bona fide. Quite clearly, this one is not. The Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) has demonstrated here in the clearest and most unambiguous of terms that there is nothing to worry about, so why does the opposition continue to spread fear tactics among the people of Australia?

SPEECH.PARA: If we were to use the Hinchinbrook development as a pro forma for the rest of Australia, then it becomes a very serious thing indeed if it impinges upon and stops developments of this nature. They may not be perfect developments but they are developments that we need. I do not support the unmitigated release of acid water or acid sulphate into any area that may damage the environment, let alone one of world importance like the Great Barrier Reef. Nor do I support anything that is not the truth in this place. You either accept what the minister says, supported by Senator O'Chee and others on this side of the chamber, or you accept what is said in a spurious and even nefarious fashion on the other side.

Let me remind the chamber, Madam Deputy President, that this was a project approved by the Queensland Labor government some decade ago. This was a project that was approved in this very chamber when the opposition was in government—in fact, approved by the person that has become infamously known as `Richo'. He supported this. This fear has been spread, based on the evidence that the ABC ostensibly took recently where a Cloudy Bay chardonnay bottle was dipped into a channel. The program did not have the truthfulness to demonstrate that that channel was actually running into a sump—the very reason that it was put there. The ABC did not say that sump is then treated, if the pH factor is too high, to bring it down, and, if it falls below six, it is treated to bring it up to a pH balance of about seven—it did not include that—and that water is then released and only then released into the channel.

What happened 10 years ago was not that. It was in fact disturbed and, with the contact of the oxidisation and water, of course it did form some dilute sulphuric acid that was allowed to run into the channel. In terms of parts per million in the Hinchinbrook Channel, my information is that it is not something that would be detrimental to the reef or to any other aspects of the environment within the channel. Those are the scare tactics. Let me quote, if I have time, from Professor White, under `General Comments':

PARA.EMPHASIS: The overall management philosophy for acid sulfate soils at the Port Hinchinbrook site is in general accord with accepted practice. Acid sulfate soils can be managed in land developments with no risk to the environment, provided they are recognised and treated in accord with best practices. Best practice dictates avoidance of disturbance where possible coupled with treatment of all acid which may be produced by any disturbance. The acid sulfate management plan for Port Hinchinbrook espouses these principles.

SPEECH.PARA: The management plan that the minister spoke about—the management plan that the minister and this government insisted on being upgraded—meets world standards. Scare tactics are no way to induce people to stop development in Australia. We need development. We need it to be done in a proper fashion. We do not need the peddling of fear to turn people against development in this nation. You people on the other side would be the very first to scream, Senator Murphy, if it curtailed employment. And that is what curtailment of development does; it curtails employment. Here you are knocking Australia again, knocking a development that is of a world class standard and knocking those safeguards, those checks and balances put in place to protect the environment and to protect the world heritage value of the Great Barrier Reef. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PARA.EMPHASIS: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows that we citizens of Australia support the Government's efforts to assist nations with the clearing of land mines and also support a world‐wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti‐personnel mines.

Your Petitioners request that the Senate support our call for a world‐wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti‐personnel land mines, give priority to expanding Australia's support for mine clearance in affected countries and use its influence to encourage other countries to give greater support to mine clearance efforts.
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

EMPHASIS.TAB: immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;

support incentives for nationwide employment in composting, soil remineralisation programs, and the planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PARA.EMPHASIS: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned shows that the Taliban have:

EMPHASIS.TAB: implemented a gender apartheid against the women of Afghanistan;
refused to allow Afghan women to work outside their homes, to earn income, and to access the Afghan society's education, health and other resources;
failed to respect Afghan women's rights to education, to safety and the sharing of public spaces, and to public mobility;
enforced veiling for women and have imposed a dress code policy against women;
and have failed to uphold the human rights of Afghan women and men as accorded to them under Islamic constitutional laws.

PARA.EMPHASIS: We, the undersigned, are deeply alarmed at the practices and policies of the Taliban against Afghan women and girls.

We therefore urge that the Senate should seek to allocate development assistance monies in support of Afghan women's education, skill building, capacity‐building, health‐related programs and other basic needs for civil society.

We further call upon the Government of Australia to use its good offices with governments of other nation states, with the international community, with the United Nations and with multinational corporations, to hold the Taliban accountable to uphold and respect the human, civil and political rights of Afghan women, girls and men.

We call upon the Government of Australia to urge these bodies to withhold recognition of the Taliban, access to the UN seat and donor assistance. We urge that economic transactions be conditional upon the respect of the Taliban towards the Afghan people and particularly the human rights of women and girls.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the Advance to the Minister for Finance—Statement of Heads of Expenditure and the amounts charged thereto pursuant to section 36A of the Audit Act 1901 for the year ended 30 June 1997. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the Advance to the Minister for Finance—Statement of Heads of Expenditure and the amounts charged thereto pursuant to section 36A of the Audit Act 1901 for the year ended 30 June 1997 be referred to legislation committees for examination and report in conjunction with documents previously referred to legislation committees as part of the additional estimates process.

(2) That consideration in committee of the whole of the Advance to the Minister for Finance for the year ended 30 June 1997 be made an order of the day for the day on which legislation committees report on their examination of the Advance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a couple of things about this. Firstly, this is not usual. It is quite abnormal practice. The usual practice in an event like this is for the Advance to the Minister for Finance to be made available to the Senate at the same time as the portfolio budget statements are. We have just heard in this motion that it is the intention of the government to have it referred to the legislative committees as part of the additional estimates process. The additional estimates process, in the main, occupied the consideration of the Senate last week when most of the legislative committees met to consider the estimates in their particular portfolio areas. Some of those committees have concluded their consideration. Some of those committees still have further consideration of those estimates to go and intend to sit tomorrow with a possible spill over tomorrow.

SPEECH.PARA: As I say, the usual practice is for these to be tabled at the same time so that they can be dealt with concurrently with the portfolio budget statements. In the case of some estimates committees, it may well now be the case that they will not meet again before they report to this chamber and thus be unable to deal with the Advance to the Minister for Finance. In the case of other committees that are meeting tomorrow, it would seem appropriate that the government at least give an indication to the parliament that officers be available in those estimates committees to answer questions about the Advance to the Minister for Finance. I think it is appropriate that I indicate now to the chamber that, when the Committee of the Whole sits to deal with the appropriation bills and this matter, subject to the opportunity I might now avail myself of to see the details of the Advance to the Minister for Finance, I reserve the right to ask questions in the Committee of the Whole on the advance.

I conclude by putting one other reservation down in view of the lateness and the abnormal practice being engaged in here. It may well be that the committees that have met and are deciding the nature of their report to this chamber might now wish to meet again or include in their considerations the proposal that they hold over until their next meeting commentary on the Advance to the Minister for Finance. I put those reservations down in order to later be able to take up the options that I have referred to and to not be accused of bad faith when I do. I also do so in view of the lateness of the document and the unusual practice being engaged in here by the government.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Prime Minister's Attendance at CHOGM and Visit to Indonesia

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a statement by the Prime Minister on his attendance at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, held in Edinburgh from 24 to 27 October 1997, and a visit to Indonesia from 28 to 29 October 1997. I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

The continuing relevance and value of the Commonwealth to its members is well demonstrat ed by the fact that 51 member states attended the Edinburgh meeting, 43 of them represented by their head of government or head of state. It is a particular pleasure to record that Fiji was among those members, taking its place again at the Commonwealth table with the wholehearted support of my government.
This was my first CHOGM. It reinforced for me the strengths of the Commonwealth:
. it spans a broad diversity of nations, developed and developing, from all corners of the globe and representing a quarter of the world's population
. its members share a common heritage of language, traditions and values, which forms the basis for the Commonwealth's ability to reach consensus and work constructively on many issues

. it has perhaps the widest grass‐roots support amongst its member countries of any international body, with a vast network of associated organisations bringing together people from all walks of life—these personal and professional links are the lifeblood of the Commonwealth.

These strengths underpin the value of the Commonwealth to Australia. The Commonwealth also complements our key bilateral relationships and our focus on regional forums such as APEC and the South Pacific Forum. It is the principal avenue for our engagement with many Commonwealth countries beyond our immediate region. As the third largest financial contributor to the Commonwealth, Australia has a positive role in promoting the economic and social development of those countries.

The outcomes of the Edinburgh meeting were good—for Australia and for the Commonwealth as a whole. I should say at the outset that the meeting's success—and its harmonious and constructive atmosphere—owed much to the capable chairmanship of Tony Blair. I was pleased to be able to work closely and effectively with him. The United Kingdom was an excellent host, and the people of Edinburgh and Scotland gave us a warm welcome.

For the first time, CHOGM focused its discussions on a theme—Trade Investment and Development: the Road to Commonwealth Prosperity. That economic focus was reinforced by the inaugural Commonwealth Business Forum, held immediately before CHOGM.

I was one of several heads of government asked to address the Forum. It was an opportunity for me to argue the case for Commonwealth member countries to open their markets and economies if they are to maximise the opportunities globalisation can offer.

The outcome of CHOGM's discussions on its economic theme was the Edinburgh Commonwealth Economic Declaration, Promoting Shared Pros perity. The declaration expresses the economic principles shared by Commonwealth members and is the companion to the 1991 Harare Declaration, which set out the core political and human rights principles of the Commonwealth.

The declaration is significant in the degree of common ground reached among developed and developing members on the need for continuing trade liberalisation, the importance of encouraging investment flows—especially through sound macroeconomic policies and financial systems, strong regulatory and supervisory frameworks and good governance—and the crucial role of the private sector in achieving economic growth.

While this good outcome reflected wide support for trade liberalisation, the meeting showed we have some way to go in winning universal acceptance of the value of a new round of global trade negotiations. As I said in my address to the Business Forum, Australia believes a new global trade round should be launched by the end of the century. There is support for a new round among other Commonwealth members—but it is not unanimous.

The declaration recognises that some countries need help in adjusting to and taking advantage of globalisation. governments need to facilitate the sometimes difficult adjustments required, and explain and manage reforms in a way which ensures community understanding and support.

I am pleased to advise the Senate that Commonwealth leaders welcomed and strongly endorsed Australia's initiative to respond to this need by establishing a Trade and Investment Access Facility under the Commonwealth umbrella.

The facility will help Commonwealth members manage the potential economic and social impacts of trade and investment liberalisation. My announcement of Australia's contribution of $1.5 million over three years to start the Facility was backed up by funding pledges from Canada, Britain and New Zealand.

I see this not only as a practical and constructive response to the concerns of many developing countries about the impact of opening up to the global economy but also as a means of helping generate the momentum of trade liberalisation world wide and opening up markets for our exporters.

The outcome on climate change was also a good one for Australia's national interest. Against many expectations and dire predictions of Australia being isolated on this issue, the economic declaration advanced our interests by recognising that
. as a general principle, the costs of protecting the environment should be borne in accordance with shared and differentiated responsibilities
. both developed and developing countries have to play a part in reducing greenhouse gas emissions in order to solve what is a global problem
. a successful outcome at the climate change conference in Kyoto would involve realistic and achievable goals.

The Edinburgh meeting also reinforced the importance attached by the Commonwealth to the principles of democracy, good governance and human rights set out in the Harare declaration. Heads of government confirmed the Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group's mandate to respond to situations where the Commonwealth's principles are seriously or persistently violated.

We bluntly told Nigeria that it must improve its human rights record and return to democracy. Nigeria remains suspended from the Commonwealth, with the Ministerial Action Group authorised to invoke various measures if it considered these would encourage a return to democracy and respect for human rights. If Nigeria's transition to democratic government is not completed by 1 October 1998, heads of government will consider its expulsion and further sanctions. We also condemned the military coup in Sierra Leone and agreed to continue its suspension from Commonwealth meetings.

The outcome on membership was also positive in maintaining the integrity of the Commonwealth by emphasising the common threads which unite an otherwise diverse group. Leaders agreed that, to qualify for membership, countries should have a constitutional association with an existing member, comply with the Harare declaration and accept Commonwealth norms and conventions.
As well as our contribution to these outcomes, Australia's strong commitment to the Commonwealth was demonstrated in my announcement of an expansion of Australia's assistance for Commonwealth sport.

Australia is the Commonwealth's largest sports donor, seeing the social, health and economic benefits for young people of participation in sport and the important role of sport in strengthening Commonwealth ties.

We will continue the successful Protea sports program in South Africa, which was due to wind up next year, and work with South Africa to extend it to other parts of Commonwealth Africa, with funding of $1.8 million. We will also extend support for junior sports development in the Caribbean, with funding of $1.35 million. And, subject to a review, our sports development program in the South Pacific, ASP2000, will be extended until 2006.

Australia's support for the Commonwealth was also expressed in my offer—which was warmly accepted—that Australia host CHOGM in 2001. It is very fitting that Australia's Commonwealth friends will be able to join us in our celebration of the centenary of federation.

One of the great values of CHOGM is the opportunity it provides for formal and informal discussions with a range of leaders, establishing the personal contacts which are such an important part of strong bilateral relationships. It was, of course, a particular pleasure to meet President Mandela for the first time—he kindly invited me to visit South Africa and I reiterated how welcome a visitor he would be in Australia.

My discussions with Mr Blair in London, building on our meeting earlier this year, set the tone for our close cooperation in Edinburgh on a number of issues, including climate change. We also had a useful exchange on what is one of the few irritants in our bilateral relationship—the indexation of pensions paid to former residents of the United Kingdom who now live in Australia.

My meetings with Mr Goh Chok Tong and Dr Mahathir allowed a very useful discussion about the financial instability in Southeast Asia, including appropriate action at the forthcoming APEC leaders meeting. It was also good in the lead up to the Vancouver meeting to talk with this year's chair of APEC, the Canadian prime minister, Mr Chretien, and to discuss the Ottawa Treaty on landmines which Mr Downer will sign on behalf of Australia.

My meeting in Edinburgh with Mr Haiveta, the deputy prime minister of Papua New Guinea, allowed me to hear about the drought afflicting our closest neighbour. I repeated Australia's determination to help the government and people of Papua New Guinea get through this very difficult period.
Madam President, my subsequent visit to Indonesia—my second as Prime Minister—coincided with developments of crucial importance to Indonesia's future, and to the future of the region.

Given the timing, it was both inevitable and in keeping with Australia's deep and abiding interests in the bilateral relationship that the financial situation in the region and its implications for Indonesia were a focus of my meetings with President Soeharto and his ministers.

My offer that Australia was ready to participate in any IMF package to assist Indonesia underlined the strength of our commitment, as a friend and neighbour, both to the partnership with Indonesia, and to the Asia Pacific region whose future Australia and Indonesia share.

Australia is not a fair‐weather friend. Our offer showed that we are a reliable neighbour and member of our regional community, prepared to help out during difficult periods. Moreover, our response has been warmly welcomed by leaders in the region and demonstrates Australia should be confident about her place in our region and the regard in which it is held by her neighbours.

It is in our national interests that the significant economic progress made by Indonesia over the last thirty years—progress which has meant better lives for the majority of Indonesian people—is continued. Stability and prosperity in Indonesia and wider region are important for Australia, for our economic prospects, and for the living standards and jobs of Australians.

The government is confident that the measures Indonesia has agreed with the IMF will help stabilise Indonesia's currency and lay the basis for good growth in the medium term. While I was in Jakarta I launched a joint venture between the Commonwealth Bank and Bank Internationale Indonesia. This enterprise is a timely and strong expression of confidence in Indonesia's economic future.

It is also a measure of the growing commitment of the private sectors in both our countries to work together for mutual benefit. Our commercial relations with Indonesia are now very significant and growing apace. Our two‐way merchandise trade grew by 20 per cent last financial year to $5.2 billion, and two—way services trade grew to $1.3 billion in 1996.

The numbers of Indonesians and Australians travelling in both directions for business, education and tourism are also growing strongly. About 360, 000 Australians visited Indonesia in 1996 and 150,000 Indonesians came here. There were more than 16,000 Indonesians studying here in 1996. Those contacts are deepening understanding between our two countries.
Our commitment to strengthening the relationship with Indonesia was also marked during the visit by my announcement of

. the opening of six new honorary consulates, four of them in eastern Indonesia—the region covered by the Australian Indonesian Development Area—which will give a boost to our trade and investment links
. the provision of a further $44 million over the next five years to fund short‐term training courses under the aid program
. a further contribution of $360,000 for ground fire‐fighting training and equipment for the Indonesian fire services—as well as funds for drought relief in Irian Jaya announced by Mr Downer.

The strong, constructive and broad‐based relationship we have with Indonesia provides a solid foundation for us to talk about any differences which we have. On the issue of East Timor I said that, while Australia recognised Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor and would act consistently with that, we thought it desirable both for Indonesia and for Indonesia's friends, for further progress to be made in dialogue and greater control over their own affairs by East Timorese.

We talked about the need to agree expeditiously arrangements fair to both sides on the exploitation of LNG in the Timor Gap. Progress was subsequently made at a meeting between Senator Parer and his Indonesian counterpart, Mr Sudjana.
President Soeharto and I also discussed the forthcoming APEC meeting and the importance of working together to strengthen APEC and achieve its goals of free and open trade and investment.
I would like to conclude by expressing my appreciation to President Soeharto and his government for their kind welcome and hospitality during my visit. I present a copy of my ministerial statement.
Motion (by Senator Chris Evans)—by leave—proposed:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw to the Senate's attention that, since the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has been in Indonesia, some one million hectares of rainforests in that country have been burnt. The report does not make any direct comment on that. However, the smoke haze still hangs across northern Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worthy of note that the Prime Minister followed his visit to Indonesia with one to Tasmania on last Saturday week. On that occasion, in the wake of his visit to Indonesia, he signed away the future of one million hectares of Tasmanian forests to the woodchip industry. This means that, in rotation rather than in one go, an equivalent area of Tasmanian forests, including rainforests, will be burnt in the coming 20 years, in addition to that massive amount that went up in the conflagration in Indonesia.

It seems that we have a Prime Minister who learns little from his perambulations around the planet and from the environmental catastrophe that is currently engulfing the countries to our north, including our country. It is extraordinary that the Prime Minister and members opposite should have then deliberately engaged in setting the death warrant on Tasmanian forests for their future destruction and burning—with the massive addition to greenhouse gas problems for the planet into the future—as if nothing was happening to the north and as if this environmental catastrophe to the north did not matter.

This is a complete failure of logic and a complete breach of faith with future generations of people in this country and elsewhere around the planet, which are going to be much the worse for this government's actions. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That these bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
NATIONAL TRANSMISSION NETWORK SALE BILL 1997

The National Transmission Network Sale Bill 1997, together with the National Transmission Network (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997, implement the Government's decision announced in the last Budget, to sell the National Transmission Network.

In the election we announced that we would increase the national broadcasters' responsibility for transmission of their programs. These bills provide the ABC and SBS with a direct commercial relationship with transmission service providers. The ABC and SBS have been seeking such a relationship for many years.

The sale of the transmission network will provide a range of benefits. The ABC and SBS, and other network users, will finally operate in a purchaser/provider relationship with service suppliers. Transferring this operational activity to the private sector will produce the scope for greater client focus and responsiveness that flows from normal commercial practice. In addition, it sets the scene for a greater degree of competition in the transmission services market, particularly with the introduction of digital terrestrial broadcasting. Sale proceeds will be used to further reduce the public debt.

In agreeing to sell the network, the Government recognised the importance of safeguarding important broadcasting policy objectives. We have made it clear that the maintenance of existing ABC and SBS coverage and service quality, particularly for regional and remote communities, is a prerequisite.

In addition, we will ensure that existing Community Service Obligations will be preserved, including those for network users such as Radio for the Print Handicapped, remote commercial satellite broadcasting services, self‐help retransmission groups and emergency service operators.
In the medium term, we recognise that there is likely to remain limited competition in the transmission services market, especially outside major metropolitan centres.

Against this background, these bills balance the desire to maximise the benefits of establishing commercial synergies, with the need for competitive safeguards to protect the Government's broadcasting and social policy objectives.

The Network will be transferred to one or more national transmission companies which will have agreed contracts with the ABC and SBS spelling out transmission requirements. These companies will be sold to the network purchaser, or purchasers, with the contracts in place.

A compact with the ABC and SBS will spell out the Government's transmission coverage and quality expectations—in return for full funding of the costs of the broadcasters' five year transmission contracts.
The onus will therefore be on the ABC, SBS and other users to ensure that adequate and appropriate transmission services are obtained to meet their needs.
The bills provide a regulatory framework to underpin these contractual arrangements.

It is necessary to ensure the continuity of contractual arrangements in the event of on‐sale of the network, and to safeguard against the transfer of assets necessary for the continuation of ABC, SBS, Radio for the Print Handicapped services and emergency services.

Accordingly, this bill contains provisions requiring Ministerial approval before transfer of any assets associated with these "nominated services". This requirement will enable the Minister to ensure that the proposed transferee adopts the conditions of the previous contracts with the ABC, SBS, and Radio for the Print Handicapped operators in relation to their core performance obligations. The provision will also allow an assessment of the likely commercial or financial viability of the proposed transferee to further safeguard the continued provision of national broadcasting services.

The legislation also provides for an access regime similar to that put in place for the telecommunications industry for the benefit of certain nominated customers. The access regime will guard against any imbalance in negotiating power, which could have led to essential transmission services and facilities not being available, or only being available at monopoly prices. The access regime will:
guarantee access to transmission services for the ABC, SBS and the Radio for the Print Handicapped operators, and will

guarantee access to existing Network sites and towers for groups such as community broadcasters, self‐help retransmission groups, remote commercial satellite broadcasters and emergency services, as well as the ABC, SBS and Radio for the Print Handicapped.
If the parties are unable to reach agreement on the terms and conditions to apply, they will have recourse to the ACCC to arbitrate the matter.

This combination of contractual and legislative provisions will balance the likely market power of new network owners to ensure continued access by national broadcasters and other nominated users on reasonable terms and conditions.
Commercial users of the network will have recourse to standard fair trading legal safeguards, including those under Part 3A of the Trade Practices Act 1974.

The new arrangements also require a number of technical changes to other portfolio legislation. The National Transmission Network (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 amends the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983, the Special Broadcasting Service Act 1991 and the Radiocommunications Act 1992 to allow the broadcasters to deal directly with transmission service providers, and to enable the ABC and SBS to maintain control over the Radiocommunications spectrum used to broadcast their services.

The ABC and SBS will also be able to establish their own transmission services. This power, together with the ability of the broadcasters to purchase future requirements from other providers, will provide commercial leverage and introduce contestability into the market.
The ABC and SBS will report to the Parliament, through their annual reports, on any significant changes in transmission coverage or quality of national broadcasting services.

The ABC and SBS will be responsible for dealing with any complaints from the public about reception quality. In the unlikely event that a suitable and timely response is not provided by the broadcasters, and a substantial problem appears to exist in relation to changed transmission coverage of a community, the Minister will have the option of directing the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) to investigate the matter.

With this contractual and legislative package, the ABC and SBS will at last have a direct commercial relationship with the provider of their transmission services, and a degree of flexibility in determining how best to meet their future transmission needs. At the same time, the Australian public can be confident that coverage and signal quality for national broadcasting services will be protected.

In addition, self‐help groups, emergency service operators, and remote commercial satellite service providers will be protected by the access regime. Capped charges in contracts or supplementary funding will ensure that they are not financially disadvantaged.
The National Transmission Network Sale Bill 1997 also contains some technical requirements to facilitate the sale.

These include provisions to ensure, if necessary, that ownership of fixtures can be separated from ownership of the land on which they are located. Some transmission facilities have been built on non‐Commonwealth land and the power to "sever" the fixtures from the land is needed to make it clear that the Commonwealth is the owner of Network assets.

This bill also ensures that the new Network owner will not be subject to State and Territory planning and environmental laws for facilities existing or under development at the time of the sale. Of course, a new owner will be subject to all planning and environmental requirements for new facilities or substantial changes to existing ones.

Sale proceeds are expected to return to the Budget in 1998‐99 as an offset to outlays. The Government has agreed that total outlays for transmission services after the sale will be contained within current forward estimates. No additional resources are required for the negligible financial impact of administering the regulatory arrangements contained in these bills.

These bills will allow the timely completion of the sale of the transmission network. As promised, the Government will deliver the benefits of a more commercial transmission environment, and give the national broadcasters the direct responsibility for transmission of their programs which they have sought for so long. At the same time, the bills provide the safeguards necessary to preserve the Government's national broadcasting and other social policy objectives.
NATIONAL TRANSMISSION NETWORK SALE (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1997

The National Transmission Network Sale (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 supplements the National Transmission Network Bill 1997, in putting in place arrangements to effect the Government's decision to sell the National Transmission Network.

This bill amends the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983 and Special Broadcasting Service Act 1991 to make it clear that both the ABC and SBS have the power to produce, transmit and arrange for the transmission of programs. It requires both organisations to provide details in their annual reports of significant changes in transmission coverage of national broadcasting services.

Where a substantial problem appears to exist in relation to changed transmission coverage of a community, the Minister will have the power to direct the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) to conduct an investigation into the matter.
Minor amendments to the Radiocommunications Act 1992 will facilitate ABC and SBS control of the Radiocommunications spectrum used to broadcast their services.
This bill will have no financial impact.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first sitting day in 1998, in accordance with standing order 111.

DEBATE.TITLE: CLASSIFICATION (PUBLICATIONS, FILMS AND COMPUTER GAMES) REGULATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1997 No. 282 and made under the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995, be disallowed.

To translate that motion into understandable English, I am opposing a regulation brought forward by the government which involves enormous fees being levied on film and literature in this country for the purpose of classification—that is, classification and censorship. I understand from the government that the aim of this matter is to make the business of having classification of films and literature a user pays operation in which people who put forward films or pieces of literature for classification will pay for the cost of that classification.

I am going to point out why that does not occur; I am going to point out why these regulations are a breach of faith with past commitments—at least, inherent commitments of the Senate—and I am also going to point out why they are going to have a decidedly detrimental impact on small producers of film and literature in Australia in particular. That must concern us all because it will lead to a diminution of the output of both those categories of art and their contribution to the Australian community.

These fee increases represent a second set of increases imposed by the Office of Film and Literature Classification. The fees were previously increased dramatically on 1 January last year. The fees were more than doubled, in some instances, on that occasion. With the new fees effective from 1 November this year, the total increase over the 18-month period amounts to: for film, 360 per cent; for video, 130 per cent; for computer games, 69 per cent; and publications, which did not cost anything to classify before last year, have gone from zero to $130.

Appeal fees—that is, for people who are appealing against the classification applied to their books, comics, videos and computer games—involve an even bigger increase. In the last 12 months, there has been a 700 per cent increase in appeals against film classifications. The fee increases are even greater than the Office of Film and Literature Classification commissioned consultant inquiry that the so-called pivotal report recommended.

This circumstance has a heavy impact on small players right around Australia. The fees are the same whether you are Village Roadshow or whether you are a specialty, high quality, small producer such as David Bradbury or Michael Cordell. Whether you are selling 10,000 videos or you are a community group which is making 20 videos for private sale, you pay the same classification cost. I repeat that: if you are a small specialty video producer, you pay the same as a large company producing tens of thousands of videos. Obviously an increase in the fee from $500 to $1,130 for a 90-minute film, as proposed here, will not make that much difference to the big player, to the multinational, but it is going to have a profound impact on the small player. It is going to, in effect, prevent the production of small quality videos. It is going to be inhibitory as far as their production and distribution around this country are concerned.

On the other hand, when we come to literature—and some might cavil with comics being under the definition of `literature' but, as an avid comic reader in my earlier years, I have to side with comic distributors and those who use them—if you are a small independent comic importer and you want to sell just a dozen copies of that comic, it would be simply uneconomical to do so in these cir cumstances. You have to pay $130 to have them classified if there is some matter in the comic, such as nudity, which might lead you to have to submit the comic for classification. Eighteen months ago, there was no such fee. People could introduce small quantities of comics, books and so on for distribution in Australia. The niche market there had full range, but here is a very strong deterrent to people to do so. So small numbers of specialty literature, including that example of comics, simply will not be imported any more.

The government has argued that the fee structure has to be uniform for small and big players, otherwise it would be classified as a tax and, therefore, would be unconstitutional. Presumably, they have to base their fee on recovery costs only. When the fee was increased in 1996, the Senate then threatened to disallow it. That is the first tranche of classification fees. However, a Senate inquiry which ensued recommended against the disallowance of that set of fees in January 1996 and said, in effect, `Let's give the government another chance.' Here we are with the second tranche of these fees. Last time around, that committee recommended that the government consult closely with the industry before this second round of fees was put in place and that a Senate committee inquire into the impact and the acceptability of the second round of fees. There has been no such inquiry by any Senate committee.

The question which then arises is: are these fees legal? My advice is that they are probably not. I know that recently Senator Bolkus asked about these fees in estimates committees and was told—he can correct me if I am wrong—that the fees are for full cost recovery. For this year, it appears that the fees are going to be more than cost recovery for the second part of the year, but they are going to be argued as cost recovery over the whole of the year because the fees were lower before the introduction of this current set of fees. I do not think that will hold up in court. Moreover, it does appear that the Office of Film and Literature Classification is anticipating it may have to introduce tax legislation to maintain these fee increases next year. If that is the case, why not now?

BREAK.PARA: There is a wide range of producers and distributors in Australia who are against these fees. I suspect that many people in the production and sale of literature and film around this country do not know what is coming or do not know what impact this will have on their business. Certainly those who are aware of it are vehemently opposed to these fees being passed by regulation through the Senate. They include organisations such as the Australian Visual Software Distributors Association, the Eros Foundation and the Australian Independent Distributors Association—the latter being filmmakers.

Many sorts of businesses will be affected. I have referred to some of those, but let me point to a few. There are 25 small comic book importers, such as Impact Records in Canberra, Half a Cow in Sydney and Polyester in Melbourne. There are the Australian producers of small scale films such as documentaries, the sexual erotica industry, the importers and distributors of the high quality foreign language films from Europe and Asia, and the independent producers throughout the English speaking world working outside the Hollywood studio system. In short, this formula might be okay for the Hollywood big guys—it is not going to be more than a pimple on their back—but it is going to have a huge impact on the small home‐grown producers and, in particular, quality producers of film, video and literature.

It in that sense is regressive. It in that sense is bad for the arts industry, for the creative talent that there is in this country. There ought to be a better answer than this one. Whatever the answer is, if the government is insistent on full cost recovery then it ought to be weighted so that the big producers pay more. It appears there is a legal inhibition to that. What we have got here, effectively, is a doctrinaire approach by the government which is going to hit small players around this country. The government ought to be doing better than that. Simply to say, `User pays,' regardless of the impact and the detriment that occurs to industry, particularly the creative industries in this country, is not good enough. That is why I oppose these regulations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition has concern with these regulations and part of that concern was spelled out during the Senate estimates hearings last week. Our concerns are twofold, and they are concerns that I think Senator Brown has canvassed pretty well already.

SPEECH.PARA: The first concern we have is that these regulations, these charges, that the government is proposing are charges that will have a very strong, direct and negative impact on diversity. They are charges which the big players in the industry can accommodate and factor in to their costs, but because the charges are the same across the board their impact on the smaller players will make it much more difficult for those players to sustain those fees.

The fee structure that the government is still pursuing, combined with the higher fees, has a direct impact, I think and fear, on diversity in this area. It is not just the fees on their own. We say to the government: we do not mind your recouping this amount of fees from the system, but the amount that you are expecting to recover for this financial year, combined with the fee structure, makes it a system that we would have to oppose. We maintain that there is a level up to which it can be argued that fees can be sustained across the board. But we are concerned that, after a certain level, the combination of the amount raised and the fee structure which hits everyone, small or large, with the same amount would have a deleterious impact on diversity.

Senator Brown mentioned the impact on people like David Bradbury. He is one of the players. But let us acknowledge that there is a very big market in the community for niche films, documentaries and the like. To have them in all their diversity pinned to the same amount as the big Hollywood features is something that the government has to reconsider.

We say to the government: look at alternatives. For instance, rather than pick on the minor players and the diversity of players that this measure seems to do, accommodate usage of a particular video, a particular film, and maybe pick up more through the high volume turnover.

The second important issue that we are concerned about is the constitutional aspect of this legislation. In the estimates committee I think officials made it clear that, in respect of next year's charging structure, they would have to introduce a new regime and bring in tax laws to recoup the sorts of amounts which they are looking at recouping next year with increased fees. Their concern is that, unless they use the tax legislation, the fees and charges would be unconstitutional because the fees and charges would extract from the community much more than it would cost to run the film classification system.

That is next year. The concern we have now is as to this year's regime and the charging structure that the government has proposed. Our concern here is the same one: we think that the actual costs that were provided to the committee, the actual level of fees, allow a fair degree of concern about what the government is doing, because a full year effect will raise more than they should reasonably be allowed to raise for the cost of the classification system—not for the whole cost of administration or other parts of the administration of this area.

There has got to be some doubt, I think, in respect of constitutionality. But, putting that aside for the moment, our real concern is the combined impact of the existing fee structure and its high fees on diversity. Particularly for that reason, we support Senator Brown's disallowance resolution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond briefly to this matter. Senator Bolkus knows full well that, prior to some recent increases, this industry has not had increases for a number of years and that increases were proposed by the previous government. You yourself, Madam Acting Deputy President, may be familiar with that.

SPEECH.PARA: Much has been made of the charges to the industry and the nature of those charges. I think it is important to point out that, as I am advised, on the basis of population the 1 November 1997 fees for classification of a feature film in Australia are lower, Senator Brown, than those charged in countries such as New Zealand, Canada, the United States of America and Britain. So failure to allow these amending regulations will result in the industry and, in particular, the film industry, paying fees which do not even approach the recovery of costs associated with the provision of classification services by the Commonwealth.

I am further advised that the revised regulations prescribe differential fee scales which take into account views expressed by industry during consultations on this matter which were conducted during 1996 and 1997. I am advised they were very broad consultations over that period of time. Regular and ongoing contact is maintained with the Motion Picture Distributors Association, the Australian Video Retailers Association, the Amusement Machine Operators Association and the Eros Foundation. There is, perhaps, a less easy involvement with the Australian Independent Distributors Association which, I am advised, was formed in August this year to represent independent cinema film distributors.

In relation to that matter, I am advised that consultations with members of the group have been conducted informally and that the group has neither sought nor been involved in formal consultations with senior departmental officers since its formation—since August 1997, and that is perhaps not surprising—and that members of this group were nonetheless involved in formal consultations on the subject of the fees prior to the formation of the new body. In so far as you can say it is possible, the views of the group have in fact been taken into account.

We could go on ad infinitum if we wanted, but the bottom line is this: the consultations have been made with a wide range of people—I have highlighted that. I have indicated that, if we do not proceed with these amending regulations, you will have a very viable industry paying fees way under those paid in other countries. The only point which I think is worth making in addition to that is that these regulations give effect to matters that were put forward by the industry during the consultations—that is what these regulations do.

BREAK.PARA: Some of the matters that were put forward in these consultations which I think need to be taken into account are matters such as reduced fees for simultaneous applications for the classification of films for public exhibition and for sale or hire, reduced fees for films which had been edited following a prior classification, differential time ban fees for film classifications, differential fees for public exhibition and sale or hire classifications, and differential fees for computer game applications. The government strenuously urges parties, as dimly as the chance appears, to support these regulations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Justice (Senator Vanstone) and Senator Bolkus for those contributions but it does not rest there. I go back again to say that small film and video producers in this country are faced with massive increases in fees which are going to affect their businesses in a way that is not going to touch the big feature film producers which were a feature of the minister's delivery. For a small film producer, the classification fee going from $500 to $1,130 will make a big difference. For a whole range of video and literature classifications, the massive increase in fees—of course, there were no fees at all 18 months ago on much of the literature that is being classified—is going to make a big difference. Nothing that the minister said is going to offset the fact that small producers especially in this country are going to be hit by these big fees.

SPEECH.PARA: The big fees are coming in not because they are higher in some categories elsewhere overseas; they are coming in to fulfil a government philosophy which says that everybody should have to pay the same amount of money for the time it takes to classify their product regardless of who they are, whether they are MGM and Hollywood or whether they are a small producer at an arts school or a specialty art house in Australia producing quality literature and quality film.

These fees are enormously regressive. The government is going to recoup $2.3 million this year and $5.4 million next year. I would like to know where the extra $2 million is coming from and what proportion of that is coming out of the small Aussie productions, as against the amount that is going to be extracted from the multinationals. Multinationals can bear this quite well; it is our own arts industry that we are concerned about. Nothing the minister has said has assuaged the concern I have about that industry.

The minister indicated that the players have been adequately consulted. That is not the feedback I and my office have had. There is a feeling out there that people were not consulted adequately about these fees, they are opposed to the fees now and they want the government to find another way. I put it to the Senate that we ought not be passing these regulations, that the least we could do is fulfil an earlier request in reviewing the first tranche of fees by the appropriate Senate committee that any future fees also go to a Senate committee, so that the public does get an opportunity to have input and so that the players do have an independent alternative to a government assessment of their plight before enormous increases in fees like this are levied on them. I support the disallowance motion and hope that the rest of the Senate will do likewise.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Brown's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.
