TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering opposition amendment No. 2 moved by Senator Faulkner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was previously addressing that part of the explanatory memorandum which dealt with this, but perhaps an overview in a more detailed fashion might address the concerns that Senator Harradine had. Clause 6 of the bill, which is the subject of opposition amendment No. 2, deals with two quite different sets of rights—namely, the first‐ and second‐tier persons, as they are called.

SPEECH.PARA: In clause 6, the first‐tier people are basically APS officers who have gone to Commonwealth employment outside the APS. They are deemed to be on leave without pay and can return at any time. Their service outside the APS counts for all purposes. These rights continue indefinitely for Commonwealth office holders and, normally, for three years for everyone else. This category covers anyone who left in the last three years. An example could be someone like a member of the APS who left to join Telstra or some other statutory authority.

The second set of rights are those of so‐called second‐tier persons. This term covers both first‐tier people who become second‐tier after three years and also APS officers who are transferred to a Commonwealth authority from the APS as a result of the transfer of APS functions to that authority. These second‐tier persons have no automatic right of return to the APS unless their career is adversely affected or they face retrenchment from the Commonwealth authority that they are working with. They can, however, apply for gazetted vacancies which are only available to current APS officers, and their non‐APS employment is normally recognised for long service leave purposes.

While overall numbers cannot be estimated with precision, the assessment is that there are about 50,000 people who have first‐ or second‐tier rights. Of this number, there are about 700 on leave from the APS because they are working under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984—in other words, they are MOPS, as referred to by the opposition. As indicated in the second reading speech, the current provisions, which cover 60 pages of the current act, are very complex and represent a considerable liability for APS agencies. These mobility provisions were critically commented on by the McLeod report as quoted at 3.3.11 of the explanatory memorandum. The government is proposing their replacement with a simpler model, subject to appropriate transitional arrangements.

The JCPA accepted the need for a simpler system for the future. The committee gave careful consideration to the transitional arrangements. In relation to APS officers working for members of parliament or the Governor‐General or as statutory office holders, the committee recommended that the Prime Minister should exercise the power under clause 21 of the Public Service Bill to issue a general direction to agency heads stating that agency heads must grant leave without pay to Australian Public Service employees to take up statutory appointments, employment under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act, which I mentioned, or employment under the Governor‐General Act. In effect, this would allow these people to then return to the APS.
This recommendation has been accepted by the government. The JCPA supported the principle of transitional arrangements and at paragraph 11.49 made the following comments:
The Committee believes that in the interests of the efficient and effective management of the APS, it is reasonable to impose a time limit on the continuation of present mobility rights.
It is the view of the government that there should be a limit to those mobility rights. The JCPA went on to say:
. . . the transitional period should be extended to three years to allow:
. a realistic transition period . . . and
. APS management a longer period to manage any influx of former employees to the APS.

That recommendation was accepted by the government. I refer to the explanatory memorandum at 3.3.15 which deals with that. This means that current rights will continue for up to three years if a person otherwise remains entitled to exercise them. The person can always leave the APS or leave their employment and go and work in the private sector. That will be done by regulation.

BREAK.PARA: The opposition amendment would have the effect of keeping alive for an indefinite period a set of what the government believes to be very complex arrangements which are ill suited to APS arrangements. The amendment also fails to recognise that these mobility provisions were first introduced when most Commonwealth employment was under the Public Service Act and goes back to 1978 when you had Australia Post and Telstra as part of the APS.

It is the government's view that a different approach is now needed. The majority report of the Senate Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee did not refer to these issues. However, the minority Democrat report saw merit in removing the automatic safety net of the right to return to the APS. For those reasons, the government cannot agree to this amendment and will be opposing it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened carefully to what Senator Ellison just said and what Senator Faulkner said beforehand. I made certain comments before the debate was interrupted. I was interested to hear what the minister has just said. I was looking for the explanatory memorandum. I was trying to find that reference, which I can see now. It relates to the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter does raise quite considerable issues. I was frankly surprised. I did not know that so many people would be affected, that some 700 officers of the Public Service would be affected because they are under the MOP(S) act. That is a substantial number of people. I am not at this stage prepared to, in effect, limit their rights. It may not be limiting their rights. I can understand what the government is saying. It is saying that the new Public Service is to be a streamlined, well‐managed organisation, et cetera. It seems to assume that it is not now. I hesitate to make that remark. Like all of us, there are some good bits and some bad. There are some excellent areas of the Public Service, as we all know.

It does worry me a bit now that you mention there are some 700 people likely to be affected. I would like to know how these people are likely to be affected and are likely to respond. Is a three‐year period sufficient for those persons to give consideration to what then to do? Will it mean that the older employees who are under the MOP(S) act will choose to go back to departments whereas the younger ones who may feel that they have more show of getting back into the Public Service in some other way will remain?

What effect will this have on the advice that is given to members of parliament and I suppose to parliamentary committees? I do not know whether we are talking about those people who are working for parliamentary committees. I would really like to have a better look at this. I would be inclined to move for the adjournment of this legislation until a later hour of the day or until the next day of sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I might be of assistance to Senator Harradine. I mentioned that it was a recommendation of the JCPA that the Prime Minister should exercise his power under clause 21 of the Public Service Bill 1997 to issue a general direction to agency heads stating that they must grant leave without pay to those employees who take up employment under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act. This direction should cover existing Australian Public Service staff who may need to seek an extension to their current arrangements as well as staff seeking to move to such employment in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: What that means is that in the event of the Prime Minister issuing this direction, which he said he will do, these employees are then given leave without pay. They can stay there so long as they have leave without pay. They, of course, are employed as staff of members of parliament but they are on leave without pay. That can exceed that three‐year period and they can then return to the APS. If that direction is given, it then, I believe, addresses the concern that you have.

The Prime Minister has said that he will do this and this recommendation has been accepted by the government. It is at 3.3.22 of the explanatory memorandum, if you want to follow it. It has transitional arrangements. That was the leave without pay section I was referring to before we adjourned. It says:

The JCPA report recommended that the Prime Minister should exercise the power under clause 21 of the Public Service Bill to issue a general direction to agency heads, requiring them to grant leave without pay to APS employees to take up statutory appointments, employment under the MOPS Act or employment under the Governor‐General Act. The government has accepted this recommendation in principle and the matter will be addressed further after the passage of the Public Service Bill.

What that means is an acceptance that the Prime Minister will issue that direction, which means that direction is made to the agency heads and then they grant leave without pay. That is how we believe that provision is accommodated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just for completeness, I would like to refer to the remarks that we made in our report on this matter. We said that, whilst accepting that existing right to return arrangements are complex and in need of reform, we support the ACTU's suggestion of retaining such mobility rights in defined circumstances. We can see merit in removing the automatic safety net of a right to return to the APS provided there are clear guidelines for granting applications for leave without pay and an avenue for external review should applications be refused. I think it is important, Minister, when you quote us as being in support of this, to understand that qualification. Perhaps I can ask what your response is to that? Are there clear guidelines for granting applications for leave without pay and is there an avenue for external review, as you said?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Through you, Madam Temporary Chair: there are no guidelines for the grant of it. The agreement is that it will be granted. So that is what is being said in the explanatory memorandum. It is an acceptance of the committee's recommendation. I think it cannot be clearer than that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think one issue that the minister has not addressed is the issue of certain rights being taken away from APS employees, not just limited to 700 people employed under the MOP(S) Act that Senator Harradine identifies but a significant number of others as well who undertook certain employment decisions. The government is proposing to change those conditions and that will have retrospective impact. I think the minister has not addressed the issue of retrospectivity in the contribution that he has made to the chamber. It might be useful for the committee, if senators are pondering their approach on this particular amendment, because it is an important one, for the minister to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The point that Senator Faulkner raises is something the JCPA looked at. It was clear at 11.49 where it says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee believes that in the interests of the efficient and effective management of the APS, it is reasonable to impose a time limit on the continuation of present mobility rights.
That was a clear statement by the committee and it did not think it was retrospective then. I think that that was squarely addressed by the committee which Senator Faulkner was involved in.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the minister has satisfied me in his explanation relating to the people under MOP(S). I thought they were the people that we were talking about. Are there other people? Senator Faulkner now says that there are others, not under MOP(S), who are likely to be affected in such a way that their rights may be retrospectively taken away; that is to say, those who have made certain employment decisions on the understanding, I suppose, that reinstatement would ultimately be available to them under the Public Service Act.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we are talking here about first‐ and second‐tier persons. As I understand it—and the minister could correct me if I am wrong—I think people employed under the MOP(S) Act are first‐tier persons. I would need to seek advice of the government as to precise numbers of others that we might be talking about, but, Senator Harradine, I am certainly aware of the fact that there are significant numbers of others. I think that is perhaps something that the minister might provide us some information on.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that we cannot give any better assessment than we have done in relation to that. We do know that 700 are on leave from the APS because of the MOP(S) situation. I said earlier that overall numbers cannot be estimated with precision, and it is difficult because they are people who have first‐ or second‐tier rights. I cannot assist the Senate any further than I have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be voting at this stage for the amendment proposed by the opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Clause 9, page 11 (lines 6 to 12), omit subclauses (2) and (3), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (2) A continued determination may be amended or revoked by the Agency Head in the same way as if it had actually been made under section 24 of the new Act, provided that no provision of the determination is diminished or revoked unless that provision is incorporated in an award or certified agreement.

(3) Unless it is sooner revoked, a continued determination (including any amendments made by an Agency Head under section 24 of the new Act) ceases to be in force on the third anniversary of the commencing time.

SPEECH.PARA: Existing determinations relating to remuneration and conditions will continue in place after this bill enters into force, but they will be subject to change at the discretion of an agency head. The amendment that the opposition proposes here is aimed at preventing agency heads amending or revoking a determination in a way that diminishes any provisions in an award or a certified agreement. It will also provide for a sunset period of three years, rather than one, as proposed by the bill, which in our view will allow sufficient time to renegotiate conditions in continuing determinations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is opposed to this. The section referred to, section 82D of the old act, is in fact a head of power to make determinations about pay and certain conditions of employment in the APS, so we are looking at a move by the opposition to make provisions of any determination more inflexible by being incorporated in an award or a certified agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: The government's position is that these are management instruments and they do not require any relation to anything else. They can stand on their own and tying them into an award or a certified agreement will make things more inflexible and more cumbersome.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: For the benefit of Senator Margetts, I will run through what these are about. These amendments were agreed to previously in the Public Service Bill. They specifically prevent agency heads from entering into individual workplace agreements with parliamentary service employees. As I said earlier in the debate on the Public Service Bill, we are moving these amendments for two reasons. Firstly, the secretive nature of AWAs precludes full accountability for the expenditure of taxpayer funds and would enable deals to be made between a secretary and a Public Service employee. Those deals would not be open to public scrutiny. Secondly, it would enable different terms and conditions to be set for the same job within the Public Service, which is something that the Democrats do not see as appropriate or desirable within the Public Service context. We recognise that there may be occasions when an AWA is appropriate. Our amendments allow for regulations to exempt particular categories of employees from this provision.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the words of a former Prime Minister, life was not meant to be easy. Here it is about to get complicated. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —We support this amendment. We believe that the unfair dismissal provisions of the Workplace Relations Act should apply right across the board to all parliamentary service employees, including SES officers, the clerks and the departmental secretaries.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment not agreed to.
Amendments (by Senator Faulkner)—by leave—proposed:
(44) Clause 59, page 30 (lines 26 and 27), omit subclause (4).
(45) Clause 60, page 31 (lines 8 and 9), omit subclause (3).

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats see no reason why the parliamentary clerks and the departmental secretaries to the parliamentary service should not have access to the unfair dismissals provisions in the Workplace Relations Act. I am yet to hear a satisfactory explanation from the minister as to why some classes of Public Service employees should not have access to those provisions and why they should not have the same access as other Public Service employees and other private sector workers. The only rationale is the obvious one: that the government wants the capacity to dismiss senior public servants on political grounds. That is not acceptable to the Democrats. It is particularly unacceptable in relation to the parliamentary clerks. As we all know, they occupy a unique position within the Public Service structure. We can see no reason for them to be denied access to those relevant provisions in the Workplace Relations Act.

—Are we saying that, in the unlikely event of the parliament coming to a decision that the clerks should be given a package because they were not undertaking their tasks in an appropriate manner, they should have available to them, such as it is, an appeal under the Workplace Relations Act? Am I misunderstanding that?
—We are just trying to seek clarification for a moment, Senator Harradine.
—If that is correct, what does that say about this institution?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that the carriage of these amendments allows that avenue of appeal. Senator Harradine, are you worried that there is not this avenue of appeal? As I understand it, the effect of these amendments, which the government opposes, would be that there would be this avenue of appeal.

—I am just thinking, but it would be a most unlikely case. I cannot imagine the Clerk, Mr Evans, doing anything that would be improper so far as this Senate is concerned but, if a decision was taken by the whole of the Senate that the clerk was no longer an officer who should be in that position—after, no doubt, the matter had been referred to the committees and various other procedures had been adopted—the matter could be dealt with by a commissioner under the Workplace Relations Act. I do not think that would be appropriate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, identical amendments applying to secretaries to departments were successfully moved during the committee stage of the Public Service Bill 1997 . What we have here in the Parliamentary Service Bill 1997 is these amendments applying to the secretaries to the parliamentary departments. Again, as I understand it, for the purpose of the bill, secretaries to parliamentary departments include the clerks of the chamber departments. I think that is an accurate explanation, Senator Harradine. No doubt the minister will quickly jump to his feet if I have in any way misled the committee, but I believe I am accurate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 59 of this bill specifically refers to the termination of the appointment of the Clerk of the Senate or Clerk of the House of Representatives, and clause 61 goes on to deal with the suspension of the Clerk of the Senate or Clerk of the House of Representatives. So the bill does squarely deal with the situation and the understanding that Senator Harradine has is correct. It does mean that an outside body could make a ruling which is contrary to the decision of this Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to be corrected, but I would understand that, if such a situation were to occur—and it is still possible that this parliament could make mistakes—access to unfair dismissal provisions may mean that, if the Clerk of the Senate lost the confidence of the Senate, he would be in an untenable position. However, I think we are all human beings. If there were an avenue for appeal—if it were proven, for instance, that we were unjust in our findings, we had acted on a number of circumstances that had not had a chance to be debated properly, we were found to be incorrect in our assumptions for some reason or something of that nature—under the normal provisions of industrial relations, there would be some ability for compensation. I would agree with the concerns of Senator Harradine, but I would just like to have that checked.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, it would not be a good idea for somebody who had lost the confidence of the Senate to continue in the position of clerk. However, given that we are human beings and it is possible that all of us might have got the thing wrong, it should not be unreasonable that the person involved should have access to appeal and at least access to compensation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to try again. The minister, during debate on the Public Service Bill 1997 , was able to give us categorical advice that division 3 of part 6A of the Workplace Relations Act did not apply to departmental secretaries and, I believe, executive agency heads. Hence, the argument was mounted in the chamber that this particular provision was unnecessary, and we have clause 7 defining `secretary' as:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Secretary of a Department and includes the Clerk of the Senate and the Clerk of the House of Representatives.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer both queries. Senator Margetts mentioned compensation, but one of the remedies is reinstatement, and that is the gravamen of Senator Harradine's concern. In relation to Senator Faulkner's query, in the prior debate on the Public Service Bill 1997 , we said that our clauses excluded the operation of division 3 of the Workplace Relations Act. The passing of that amendment overrode the exclusion, which meant that, if you adopted the amendment, you were bringing in unfair dismissal; if you did not, then you were excluding it. In this case, if you adopt the amendment, you are bringing in the application of unfair dismissal, and that is how it works.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, clause 59(1) says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate may, by resolution passed pursuant to a motion of which notice was given at least 6 sitting days before the day on which the resolution is passed, terminate the appointment of the Clerk of the Senate.
But clause 59(3) says:

A resolution terminating the appointment of the Clerk of the Senate or the Clerk of the House of Representatives must state the ground on which the appointment is terminated, which must be one of the following:

It then gives three bases. I take it that `must be one of the following' is not the statement but the actual ground of the appointment. On `(a) the Clerk has been guilty of misbehaviour', with judges it is normally `proved misbehaviour', but I would doubt that there would be much turning on that. Answering the issue which Senator Harradine has properly raised—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is separation of powers.

—Except that, if this becomes legislation, I would have thought that if this Senate dismissed a clerk, the clerk could take proceedings, saying that it acted outside the statute. This would become a statute and, therefore, subject to a legal challenge. Therefore, as it stands, the clerk would have an avenue to go to the court to show that he had not been guilty of misbehaviour or that he was not incapable because of physical or mental incapacity to do his or her duties. The courts would be making the ultimate decision. Would that be right, Minister?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is arguable that there could be implications here in relation to AD(JR)—the question of the clerk having the ability to have the decision reviewed. It would not be as defined as perhaps division 3 of part VIA of the Workplace Relations Act; it would be of a more general nature and it would be based on administrative review.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the remedies could possibly be reinstatement, but I put it to the committee that the course of action would be a lot more tenuous; it would not be as defined as one for unfair dismissal. I put it to the committee that your action, under the Workplace Relations Act, would be a much easier action to maintain than one which is perhaps more nebulous under administrative review, to which Senator Cooney is referring. However, I do not think we could rule out an action of that sort.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether it would be administrative review either. Under this legislation, the only way the Senate has the ability to terminate the appointment of the clerk would be, as I read it, on the basis that the clerk has been guilty of misbehaviour. That is a threshold point. The way this reads, it may be that the Senate has to decide whether he or she has been guilty of misbehaviour—
—It might be an injustice.

—I accept that comment, Senator, but I would like at this stage to get some understanding of what clause 59 means and who makes the decision about proved misbehaviour. Presumably it would be the Senate, but how solid would that assessment be? Surely, a court—say the High Court—would look at those issues to see whether or not the Senate properly exercised its power under the statute.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is appropriate in the circumstances that the President attend and answer the question put by Senator Cooney. This is really not a government bill—it comes from the Presiding Officers. The question of how the Senate would find is really a question that should go to the President of the Senate. Perhaps we could move on and come back to this item, and give the President time to get to the chamber.

—I think that is an excellent suggestion. It indicates that the minister is fully aware of the proprieties of the matter: he represents the executive and the question needs to be referred to the President. I congratulate the minister and, of course, the person who asked the question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This was an issue that did exercise the minds of the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing who examined the Parliamentary Service Bill 1997 and related bill. There was a view at that time that it might be appropriate for the President of the Senate to join the minister in the chamber during the committee stage of the debate. I had thought that that might not be necessary as the debate may not have been controversial, and most of the amendments mirror what had occurred previously during our committee stage debate on the Public Service Bill 1997 . This is a point that opposition senators were keen to make during the committee stage debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The point that has been made by senators in the chamber about the appropriateness of Madam President being engaged in this committee stage debate, to the extent that has been suggested, is one that the opposition certainly shares. Both government and opposition members of the Senate Staffing and Appropriations Committee were unanimous in their view that this was an appropriate way of dealing with the committee stage debate, if matters that were controversial or required questioning of the presiding officers, which ordinarily would go to the minister at the table, were required.

I think we may not have to worry Madam President too much, because it might be the view that this could comfortably be put to the committee. I expect that amendment No. 44 will not find favour now as a result of some of the contributions that we have heard. There might be a need for the committee to continue this debate. But, Madam Chair, if you put the question, it may well be that we can move on. As I understand it, I think we are clear on what the will of the committee is. We can probably move on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to have a matter clarified: given that we have indicated that the equivalent of amendment No. 44 has been passed in another bill and is likely to be lost in this bill, are there any implications for there being a different vote on that same issue in two different bills?
—The answer is no.
—I will now put amendment No. 45.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can we just take it a bit slower? The President is now in the chamber. Before we take a vote on it, I understand that amendment No. 45 is the one which deals with clause 61.
—It was clause 60, I think, Senator.
—My apologies. It is clause 60, in relation to termination of appointment of the secretary to a department. Senator Faulkner, perhaps you could just run through amendment No. 45 briefly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

SPEECH.PARA: The only thing I need to be absolutely certain about is whether this particular clause of the bill applies to the clerks. We need some clear advice on that. TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table a copy of a letter which is written by the Clerk of the Senate, Mr Evans, to the President of the Senate, dated 24 October 1997.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition granted leave to the President to table a letter. As the President would be aware, perhaps more than most others in the chamber, there are normal courtesies involved in this. I take the view that those courtesies—`courtesies' is the wrong word to use—or the normal procedures that apply to this do not apply to a document that is tabled by the President. I do not think it is a requirement for the President—and I think she understands this, as the opposition does. In this circumstance, obviously leave is granted without having sighted the document in question. I think there are certain courtesies in this chamber, and I would like to explain to the Senate why leave was granted for the tabling of a document that had not been sighted by me, as the opposition shadow minister.
—Could I seek a point of clarification? In the last vote, was it amendments Nos 44 and 45 which were voted upon?
—No, amendment No. 44 was put separately, and that was not agreed to. Amendment No. 45 was then put, and that was agreed to.

—In the advice that the President has there, there seems to be nothing that goes to the issue of what part a court would play in putting into operation clause 59 and what part the Senate would have as its exclusive jurisdiction.
—I refer you to the third last paragraph of the letter that has just been tabled. I think that paragraph answers that query.

—That did not seem to define the issue of whether it is up to the Senate to decide if the clerk has been guilty of misbehaviour or is incapable because of physical or mental incapacity or whether that is a threshold point. I did not see that issue of the threshold point attended to in the advice.
—Senator Cooney, I think the Senate would have to be satisfied that one of the grounds has been established. Clause 59 provides for the process by which action may be taken.

—Say the clerk—and I will say `she' to make sure that it is not the present clerk—then wanted to challenge the Senate's finding. What is our understanding of what part a court could play in that? Could it look again to see whether or not there had been misbehaviour?
—I think the court would determine whether there had been sufficient evidence to justify a conclusion of misbehaviour.
—So the position under clause 59 is this: the clerk has an avenue to challenge a decision of the Senate.
—Yes, it would be challengeable on that ground.

—The usual phrase relating to the particular person—not the clerk but generally—has been `guilty of proved misbehaviour'. Was there any reason why the word `proved' was left out of this particular bill?

—Senator Cooney, I would refer you to the third last paragraph on the second page of the letter that has just been tabled. It was felt that the word `proved' did not really add anything and was not necessary for the bill itself.

—Does this mean that a party that had a majority in the Senate would be capable of dismissing the clerk on the basis that the majority declared him to have been guilty of misbehaviour without that term being defined?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I now have a copy of the letter that the President has tabled. On a very quick look, I think it is the same letter that was provided to me, and the Clerk acknowledges that that is the case. I appreciate that having been provided for the benefit of all senators.

SPEECH.PARA: This letter goes, I think, to a very important issue for the committee to give consideration to: the issue of misbehaviour as a ground for removal from office of a Clerk. As far as the opposition is concerned, we believe that there needs to be a capacity for the houses of parliament to remove a Clerk on grounds of gross incompetence. It seems to us that if a Clerk proves to be patently incapable of carrying out the duties of the office, that ought to be sufficient grounds for his or her removal, otherwise the relevant house department and, I believe, the institution of the parliament as a whole would suffer.
I did raise this issue with the Clerk of the Senate, pointing out that page 23 of the explanatory memorandum indicates:
The term "misbehaviour" covers any conduct indicating unfitness for office.

In fact, I did seek advice in a formal sense from the Clerk, and I believe that the letter that you have tabled is effectively a copy of that advice which was provided to me. I think what this effectively says is that the Clerk of the Senate is of the view—let me quote the letter directly:

. . . it is difficult to imagine any conduct which could be held to be gross incompetence which could not also be held to be misbehaviour. Gross incompetence would clearly render a person unfit to hold office, and would be culpable.

I think it is appropriate at this point of the committee stage debate to seek the view of Madam President, with whom I have raised this issue. It is also a matter that the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing gave some consideration to. The question I would like to ask, perhaps to the minister at the table as well, but effectively to the President of the Senate, is: is it your view that the term `misbehaviour' in clause 59(3(a) comprehends the concept of gross incompetence?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my view, and having had the benefit of this advice, that if there were a situation where it was felt by a majority of the Senate that there was gross incompetence, it is in fact a matter that is misbehaviour within section 59 of the act and could be dealt with and acted upon in accordance with the provisions of that section.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to the President's answer, can I ask, Madam President: would you or the minister agree to issue a revised explanatory memorandum which would make this explicit? This might be a matter on which you would need to consult Mr Speaker—I am not entirely sure of all the parliamentary niceties there. The substance of the question is whether you would be willing to issue a revised explanatory memorandum.

—I am advised that stating it in debate and dealing with it in the manner that we have has much the same effect. Certainly it is a matter that I have discussed with the Speaker, and his understanding of it is similar to mine, as I have just stated it: that gross incompetence is included under 59(3)(a).

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the opposition is driving at the fact that if that is meant to be included in `misbehaviour' there is no harm in including it by way of a specific subclause which refers to gross incompetence. Am I correct in understanding that line of argument from the opposition?

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —That obviously was the thrust of discussions I have had both with Madam President and the Clerk of the Senate. The issue goes to whether it is necessary to do that, Minister. Is it necessary to actually go that far? Given the nature of the commitments that the President has given, frankly, Minister, I am minded not to. I accept the advice that has been given to this committee by Madam President and which I know has been given after due consideration and exploration of the issues involved.

—I think that having stated that gross incompetence is misbehaviour it may be confusing to put in both words. I think a majority of the Senate agree that gross incompetence is misbehaviour in accordance with the advice and in accordance with the intention of the subclause that we are referring to, and it may be more confusing if we put it in separately.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —As what is said today on the record is extremely important, it is important, then, that the government places on record its understanding. I think it accords with the opposition's—that is, that Madam President has advised us and provided legal advice to the effect that gross incompetence could be included in the term `misbehaviour'. Therefore, if that is the advice, we would accept it as such, as I think the opposition is. It would then make it very clear from the record of proceedings today that the government and opposition were, indeed, agreed. It might be helpful to hear from other senators as to what they understand, but certainly it seems the opposition and government are of one mind on this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (30) Page 16 (after line 19), after clause 26, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 26A Compulsory moves between the Parliamentary Departments and between the Parliamentary Service and the Australian Public Service

PARA.TAB: (1) The Commissioner may, by direction in writing, move an excess Parliamentary Service employee to another Parliamentary Department or to an APS Agency, without anyone's consent.

(2) For the purposes of this section, a Parliamentary Service employee is an excess Parliamentary Service employee if, and only if, the Secretary has notified the Commissioner in writing that the employee is excess to the requirements of the Parliamentary Department or the Parliamentary Service.

SPEECH.PARA: There was no equivalent amendment to this moved to the Public Service Bill 1997 . Currently, redundant officers in the parliamentary departments are covered by the Public Service Act and the relevant clauses of the General Employment Conditions Award 1995. In effect, this means that they get a choice between accepting a redundancy package and seeking redeployment to another position anywhere in the APS. The current method for handling redeployees in the APS and the parliamentary departments is called the APS labour market adjustment program, which is part of the Public Service and Merit Protection Commission.

Details of redeployees are forwarded to the labour market adjustment program and they assist these individuals to find redeployment by providing redeployees with a first option for vacancies within the APS. Currently a handful of redeployees from parliamentary departments have accessed this service—about three in the last year—which reflects a low level of redundancies in these departments. The Parliamentary Service Bill 1997 removes the parliamentary departments from the APS and, therefore, cuts off the redeployment options of staff from the parliamentary departments.

This is a serious concern to those staff. The primary reason is that a parliamentary department staff member who now becomes redundant and wishes to be redeployed will be limited to redeployment within the parliamentary departments. This restricts the likelihood of redeployment because of the limited number of vacancies in the parliamentary departments. The effect of this limitation is to remove any effective choice in the redundancy process. Staff will, in reality, only have the option of redundancy.

Although only a handful of staff have exercised the redeployment option to date, there is significant potential for redundancies in the future. In particular, recommendation 2 of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing into the proposed amalgamation of the parliamentary departments delivered earlier this year says that:

The committee recommends that the Presiding Officers require each parliamentary department to identify annually items of expenditure where savings may be achieved, particularly by the rationalisation of functions common to two or more departments.

This recommendation is considered by most parliamentary departments to be a possible trigger for a significant number of redundancies. Numbers made redundant under this or any similar process will make redeployment an impossible option under the proposed arrangements. Because of this, staff in Parlia ment House would obviously like to retain the possibility of redeployment to the APS.
This is an important issue which has very genuine merit. I commend this amendment to the committee.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —As the government understands, this could relate to parliamentary service employees who have not hitherto been in the APS. Therefore, the commissioner could compulsorily move people who would be new to the APS. The advice I have is that that could be done with your amendment.

—Do you think I am wrong?
—Yes, because they are currently covered by the Public Service Act.
—My advice is that they will not be once the new public service is established. At the moment they are, but they will not be in future.

—You would have somebody joining the parliamentary service as an employee who could be brought into the APS via this provision. In a prospective sense, that is somewhat different.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —But it is the future that we are referring to. When someone comes in as an employee of the parliamentary service who has not hitherto enjoyed the benefit of the current legislation—they would not, because the current legislation would not be in force—they would then be able to be moved into the APS by virtue of this provision 26A. Can you say that your amendment would apply only to parliamentary service employees who are covered by the Public Service legislation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you proposing, Minister, that we try to find a form of words that embraces what you are suggesting? I do not think the current form of words does so at all.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think, with respect, that you have a problem. Although it covers your existing Public Service employees, it does not relate in the same way to future employees of the parliamentary service. For instance, if someone comes in from the private sector to work for the parliamentary service, they are employed in the parliamentary service as an employee. Under this provision they could then be compulsorily moved by the commissioner to an APS agency. That is how I understand it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —There might be a way to deal with this, if proposed clause 26A(2) were to read:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of this section, a Parliamentary Service employee is an excess Parliamentary Service employee if, and only if, that employee was covered by the Public Service Act 1922 at the time of entry into force of this act . . .

We would then continue with the existing words, `and the Secretary has notified the Commissioner', et cetera. I think that gets as close as I can do it on the run to what we are trying to achieve, Minister.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that wording addresses the problem that I have raised, but there is one which the President might want to address—that is, the question of the commissioner being able to compulsorily move people from the parliamentary service back into the APS or between departments, because you might have an officer working in the parliamentary service and the commissioner, for one reason or another, wants that person shifted into the APS. The Presiding Officer might not like that. That might be a problem. So you then have a conflict between the Presiding Officer and the commissioner. I think that question should be directed to the Presiding Officer.

—I acknowledge what the mover of the amendment is doing. As the minister has said, so far as it went, it was okay. But I, too, am a little concerned about the compulsory clothing that is being placed upon the commissioner under amendment No. 30. I wonder whether we could leave this amendment for a little while and tidy it up.

Such a determination may authorise consultation with nominated Senators or Members or with a nominated committee consisting of Senators or Members.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments tighten up the requirements for consultation with the Senate and the House of Representatives on the appointment of parliamentary clerks. The Democrats believe that the current wording is very unsatisfactory, requiring as it does for the President or the Speaker to simply consult with members of the respective chambers about the appointment. Technically, that could simply mean having a quick chat with two or three senators or members, perhaps even from the same party, and then proceeding with the appointment. I do not know if that is what the government intended, but we think this provision certainly needs clarification.

Our amendments require the President and the Speaker to consult with the Senate and the House of Representatives and give the Senate and the House the power to determine the form of the consultation. Such a determination may authorise consultation with nominated senators or members or with a nominated committee. The Democrats think that it is important for a majority of the Senate and the House to agree upon the formal consultation process in making these appointments rather than leaving it up to the Presiding Officers to determine that process. Our amendments still leave the basic power of appointment with the Presiding Officers, but make clear that the Senate and the House, not just a few members, are to be involved in that process.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

—The Greens (WA) will support the Democrats' amendments 8 to 10.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

—There is one thing missing here. I thought in this place that years of service might count for something. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 57, page 29 (lines 16 to 18), omit subclause (3).
