SPEECH.PARA: Amendments 1 and 2 on sheet 752 relate to clause 57, that is, the appointment of the Clerk of the Senate and Clerk of the House of Representatives. In the recent estimates hearings, the Clerk of the Senate stated in response to a question from Senator Cooney about the impact of a change to 10-year non-renewable terms for the clerks:

That is part of the long-term potential problem that I see. The problem that I identified with the 10-year non-renewable term for the clerks of the houses is that the independence of those positions may be compromised by that provision. To put it bluntly, a person appointed to that position at a young age, at the end of a 10‐year term, apart from the fact that they will have developed a great deal of expertise that will then be done away with—that is another issue, and you can argue that it facilitates other people coming along and developing their expertise and so on—is going to be looking for a job. If they accept a government position at the end of that 10-year term, that will lead people to wonder how independent that person has been when in the position of clerk of either house: has their advice over that period been influenced by the prospect of a government job at the end of their 10-year term? That is the problem which I see with the 10-year non-renewable term. That problem would be greatly exacerbated by some of the other proposals that were talked about such as a five‐year renewable term or a two‐year renewable term, something like that.

That is my concern and that of the Greens. It may only be about perceptions but that is unfortunately what politics is all about. If we are to have clerks who are truly independent and able to provide frank and fearless advice to all senators without any real or perceived influences, we must have the clerks appointed on the same basis at least as a magistrate or similar judicial position, that is, until retirement. I would like to think the Senate will support my amendment.

I can see that perhaps what is influencing people's judgment is the lack of tenure and the lack of certainty that the average worker has within the workplace in 1997 in Australia. I can see that, in relation to that, people might see that an appointment until retirement is an extraordinary thing in today's situation, but there are very good reasons for doing this—as I say, the reasons of independence. The fact that for so many other reasons there is great and growing uncertainty amongst the workplace is not a sufficient reason to imperil the independence of an area like the Senate. It is certainly not a good reason to do similar things, for instance, to the judiciary or to magistrates and so on.

If we were to go down this slope, given that we are supposed to be the major decision making venue in the country—although I would probably argue that corporations, especially international corporations, sometimes have more powers than parliaments—and that theoretically this is the highest decision making body within Australia, I think we must make sure that we have not only the reality but the perception that those who give advice to that body are independent and not under threat in the longer term.

I would argue that we should not just judge this against what is happening out in the wider society. We should look at it in terms of the reality of the necessity for professionalism and independence and the trust we all need in these very important officers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts's amendment No. 1 is identical to our amendment No. 11. We strongly support this amendment. We oppose subclause 57(3) because we believe it is very inappropriate to single out the parliamentary clerks by limiting their tenure in the job to 10 years. We regard this as a very fundamental interference in the independence of the clerk and an attempt, in effect, to nobble him or her.

SPEECH.PARA: There are provisions in the bill which set out the grounds under which the appointment of a clerk can be terminated. We have already talked about that at length. The Democrats can see no reason for the appointment of a clerk to be terminated purely and simply because they have been in the job for 10 years. I remind the Senate that our current Clerk has been in for almost that length of time and had this legislation been in place when he was appointed he would be retiring in February next year.

The fact is, as we all know, that neither the previous nor the current government care very much for independent commentary from the parliamentary clerks on matters of parliamentary process. We understand that the government wanted to fix a five‐year limit on these positions originally but has now secured opposition support for a 10-year limit. That is obviously better than five, but we do not believe the case has been made for any limit at all to be placed on these positions. I would be very interested to hear the President's case, which, as I say, I do not believe has so far been put.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the view of the Speaker and I that the term should be 10 years and not renewable. There was never any suggestion by either of us that there should be a five‐year renewable term. I would not agree to that because the mere concept of it being a renewable term puts the incumbent in a totally untenable position. It could only be a term for a fixed period, so there is no risk whatever of the clerk feeling that he or she is being influenced or under pressure. I do not agree that there is any difficulty with the clerk then applying for other positions in the Public Service or anywhere else, or that that in any way reflects on the previous term of office.

SPEECH.PARA: Senators should remember that governments change probably more frequently than clerks and that a clerk appointed by one government may be serving under two or more governments in the period of time that we are talking about, namely 10 years. There may be a totally different government in power at the time when he would then be looking for another position at the expiration of 10 years. It does provide a different career path for those younger in the service and generally would work to enhance the position and the position of the Senate.

I see there being absolutely no question of there being any attempt to interfere with the independence of the clerk—I know of nobody who would want to do that—and the 10‐year period seems an appropriate length of time. However, it should be non‐renewable so that there is no risk of there being any debate or issue then that would reflect on the independence of the clerk as it came up to the time of renewal.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think the government could put it any better than the President has. It opposes the amendment of the opposition. I think it is pointless to go into further debate on it; the position is quite clear.

—I have a question to Madam President. Is it not true that some clerks have been in office for 18 years, as I recall, and 12 years. A number have already gone beyond that 10‐year limit. Is there some consensus amongst the coalition government that there is a problem with the period being longer than 10 years? I am still not clear about why it is that 10 years is appropriate and, say, 15 is not, or why eight is not a more appropriate time. Why was the period of 10 years chosen, as opposed to some other time limit? How does it relate to the periods in office of previous clerks?

—(6.40 p.m)—There are clerks who have held the position for longer than that and clerks who have held the position for a shorter period than that. Ten years seemed, to the Speaker and me, to be a reasonable period of time—not too long, not too short.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition has made its position clear on the public record that we will be accepting this proposal that the clerks have tenure for a 10‐year non‐renewable period. We consider that this will provide adequate and appropriate protection of the necessary independence of the clerks. I want to say very clearly that we would not, and did not, support a shorter period. A 10‐year tenure constitutes very considerable security in our view in the contemporary industrial relations climate and it is directly comparable to the situation of the Auditor‐General.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not believe that the 10‐year period should be renewable. I think any suggestion of a renewable term for a clerk would only make the clerks susceptible to pressure from the government of the day, whose gift, of course, their continuation in office would be. That would be the difficulty as the end of their tenure approached. It would place the clerks in a very difficult position. I am not suggesting for one moment that any individual would be compromised by that, but we could not afford in the parliament to have that sort of situation.

We have heard the arguments that a 10‐year term would be unfair on a youthful clerk who might only be in their 40s, say, at the end of their term. As far as the opposition is concerned, you have to balance this with considerations that, if you have 10 years of satisfying and well‐remunerated work, that really is long enough for such a young clerk to be able to plan his or her next career move. I think that is very important and I hope deputy clerks and assistant clerks would acknowledge that the 10‐year term has an advantage of giving a youthful deputy or assistant clerk a chance at the top job. Why shouldn't, let us say, a deputy clerk of the calibre of the incumbent be able to aspire to the highest step on the clerical ladder? What is wrong with that?

This is a proposal that has merit, that does not compromise the clerks in any way—nor should they ever be compromised—and that protects their independence. It is proper that the government backed away from its proposal for five‐year renewable terms. That is one of the suggestions that happens around this place: it was floated but, at the end of the day, the arguments against it were overwhelming. I am pleased that the government has determined to come forward with what I think is a far more balanced and more reasonable proposition in relation to the tenure of the clerks.

For the reasons that I have outlined, the opposition will be supporting this proposal. We do believe it is a clause of the bill that does give an appropriate and adequate level of security. It gives appropriate protections to what we think is absolutely non‐negotiable and absolutely vital—the independence of the clerks of both houses of the Commonwealth parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the various contributors to the debate on these two amendments. I would like to point out to Senator Faulkner that I am not suggesting a renewable term; I am suggesting the kind of term—
—No, I said the government did.

—Yes, but I want to make it clear on the record that our amendment is not suggesting a renewable term; it is suggesting the same term that would be available to a magistrate. I think that we should at least, if it is considered that that kind of protection is necessary for a magistrate, be able to expect that level of independence and guarantee of professionalism in relation to the Senate. In fact, I would probably believe there should be more emphasise on those values in the Senate than there may be for a magistrate, although a magistrate's values are very important as well.

SPEECH.PARA: Will we see in the future the Labor Party lining up to give reduced fixed terms for magistrates? I hope not. Will we have arguments in the future about reduced terms for High Court judges? These things have been floated around and more and more governments ignore them. I was particularly interested to hear the view expressed in a review of the constitution that governments ignore the constitutional rules again and again and then have a real dig at the High Court for telling them so. Will we have a situation where, more and more, governments flout things like constitutions and then say, `Isn't this dreadful? We'll have to reduce the terms of High Court judges'? I think it is a dreadful and very dangerous way for us to be going.

I would like to also suggest that the arguments were not about the benefits of the individuals. Once again, to refer to Senator Faulkner's argument: it was not about whether it is necessarily fair to the individual as to whether they have a reasonable career path of a 10-year fixed term; it is about, when nearing the end of that term in a growing Public Service which is more and more politicised and more and more privatised and less accountable by the minute to the parliamentary system and to the parliament, whether or not we are going to have a situation where people in the last year or so of their tenure will be looking to see what their future may be. That is not something that is just about the welfare of the individual; it is about the reality of the independence of that person.

It would be quite difficult to go from a situation in the parliament into the private sector. The emphasis is on not just whether it is a fair thing for a person to have a 10-year tenure but whether that tenure influences, or may be perceived to influence, the behaviour of that person when they are nearing the end of their tenure, when they have understandable concerns about the next 10, 15, or even 20 years of their working life. Therefore, I indicate that the Greens (WA) and the Australian Democrats feel that this issue is important enough for us to divide when we put this to the vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to, and take on board, what Senator Margetts said. The position that will ultimately be taken is that there will be a 10‐year term. Perhaps one of the ways out of this is to appoint clerks when people become truly wise—when they pass 50 and get into their 60s and 70s. I think that a lot of good can come from this. It is like the old days when they talked about the elders and the wise men of the tribe. I can see that this legislation is going to lead back to that. There are too many people these days put in positions of power and influence when they are only in their 30s or their 40s.
—Youngsters.

—Youngsters. True wisdom comes when you get into your 60s and 70s. This could become a general rule—that all leadership within the community goes to those where wisdom truly rests. This will lead to a return to the traditional way of doing things—that is, where the elders of the community, where wisdom lies, are appointed to the proper positions.

—As a youthful and perhaps unwise person of only 33, I would like Senator Cooney to clarify this point. I understand that the current Clerk took up his position in his early 40s, when he had not yet attained the getting of wisdom. Do we need to put some sort of age barrier before people can take on these positions of responsibility?
—He had some pretty good tutors.

—I am sure I have some good tutors now that I am here at an even more youthful age than that. Perhaps we need to explore this principle further and examine whether there should be a weighting according to age or wisdom or whatever before people can attain such offices of significance.

—The present Clerk was wise beyond his years. That became obvious early on. He is an old head on young shoulders. I think that is exceptionable. Senator Bartlett, you will find that sticking by the general rule is the better of doing things and going to the wisdom that lies with the old is a better way out.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Margetts's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (46) Clause 62, page 32 (lines 15 and 16), omit "after receiving a report from the Commissioner", substitute "on the advice of the Remuneration Tribunal and are to be published in the Gazette ".
An equivalent amendment to this was moved to the Public Service Bill 1997 during the committee stage of the debate and agreed to.
Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: (12) Clause 62, page 32 (lines 15 and 16), omit "Presiding Officers after receiving a report from the Commissioner", substitute "Remuneration
Tribunal".

Our amendment mirrors the amendments moved by us to the Public Service Bill 1997 . It provides for the remuneration of the secretaries of the parliamentary departments and the clerks of the departments of the Senate and the House to be set by the Presiding Officers after receiving a report from the Remuneration Tribunal, instead of the commissioner as it currently appears in the bill.

We believe the independence of the clerks would be further undermined by a provision which enables the Presiding Officers to sit down with the Parliamentary Service Commissioner—who would almost certainly be the Public Service Commissioner—and fix the terms and conditions of the clerks. The involvement of the tribunal, an external body, brings a greater level of accountability and public scrutiny to the process.
Amendment not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Clause 74, page 42 (after line 12), at the end of the clause, add:

PARA.TAB: (5) A person who, at the commencing time, is simultaneously the Secretary of a Department established under subsection 53(2) and Acting Secretary of another Department established under that subsection may continue to act as Secretary of the other Department for a period not exceeding 90 days, after which the position of Secretary of the Department in which the person is Acting Secretary is deemed to be vacant.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment relates to the transitional provisions for current heads of parliamentary departments. My amendment adds a new subclause which limits the time a person may simultaneously hold the position of secretary of two parliamentary departments to 90 days, after which the position would be declared vacant.

I think it is important—particularly in relation to a specialist department such as the Parliamentary Library—that the secretary is independent and solely responsible for that department. In addition, it is important that the position of the Secretary to the Department of the Parliamentary Library be filled by a trained librarian who is a specialist in the field. The Library in the Australian parliament has, I understand, a reputation as one of the best libraries in the world and I am concerned that this reputation be maintained. I believe that it can be maintained if a trained librarian heads that department and that department alone for that reason. I commend the amendment to the committee.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —It does strike me, having had an opportunity to look at Senator Margetts' amendment, that this is very specific. I just wonder whether the President might care to inform the committee of the approach of the Presiding Officers in this circumstance and whether this amendment is necessary. Madam President, assuming this bill is given assent, could you contemplate a situation where a secretary to a department would be acting in another office for a period over 90 days? I think this is the situation we have got at the moment, as I understand it. We have an Acting Parliamentary Librarian. I think that is right, isn't it?
—Yes.

—As I understand it, we have an Acting Parliamentary Librarian and the person in that position is Mr Templeton, who actually heads the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff. So it is actually a situation we currently have on our plate at the moment. Some of this stuff is getting a bit specific, isn't it? Madam President, would it be your intention that you and the Speaker would allow this situation to occur? Would you be willing to give an assurance that, after the passage of this bill, you would not contemplate that sort of situation occurring for beyond a period of a couple of months?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —At the present time, the administration of the two departments is working quite well and there is no Parliamentary Librarian appointed. There is provision for that to happen if it were thought necessary to do so or it may continue as it is at the present time. It is a matter of evaluating.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no question but that the Library is functioning extremely well now with extremely professional and competent people in it. The acting head of the department has been in that position for some time and is head of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff as well. Part of this has been looked at in terms of amalgamations, new bills and things of that nature, and I think it is a matter to review once this goes through. I basically see no reason to be more specific than what is occurring at the present time, which is monitored constantly.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the President suggesting to the committee that we are likely to have an amalgamation of two parliamentary departments and that that is the way this issue might be solved? I just want to be clear on what she is saying.

—The amalgamation was discussed earlier this year. It is a matter that comes up from time to time. I know that amongst your own ranks there are some who are basically committed to it if the right formula could be found—which has not occurred as yet. It was felt that it was reasonable to continue this situation. It would be a pity to put somebody into a position and then, perhaps not long after that, to say that you no longer wanted that position. The system is working efficiently and well at the present time, and the Library certainly continues to maintain its reputation, standards and service, as it has over many years.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ellison, how does the government propose to handle this situation in the light of subclauses 74(2) and 74(3)?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Through you, Madam Chair, this really is a matter for the President. The Presiding Officers are the people to deal with this.

—In a situation where you have a person who is, in effect, in two positions at once—one an acting position and one a permanent position—what is the process, and what has been the process, of assessing whether or not it is working? What is the criteria? How has it been assessed to see whether that situation is working, particularly where the person is holding an acting position? What consultative process has taken place to ascertain whether that process is satisfactory?
—The Presiding Officers get reports each month from the Library and from the Parliamentary Reporting Service. It is a matter that we monitor on an ongoing basis.
—Who signs off those reports?
—The Speaker and the President.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a problem here. I addressed my question to the minister, and he answered it—and I am not saying that you answered it inappropriately, Minister; you duckshoved it, and I think you were probably entitled to duckshove it in this circumstance. Let me ask either the minister or the President a more specific question, so I can get it clear. Clause 74(2) says:

SPEECH.PARA: The person who held the office of Parliamentary Librarian immediately before the commencing time is taken to have been appointed under section 58 to the office of Secretary of the Department of the Parliament Library established by section 55, and to have been so appointed for a period of 5 years beginning at the commencing time.
Does that apply to the Acting Parliamentary Librarian. I think we need to be clear on that point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —At the present time no person is holding that position, so 74(2) does not operate at the present time. There is no‐one holding that position. It is a matter for the Presiding Officers and the relevant advisory committees to deal with, not the government.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment not agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —We now return to postponed opposition amendment No. 30.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I made a suggestion, and I do not know whether or not it has found favour with the committee. I take the committee to opposition amendment No. 30. If proposed clause 26A(1) were amended to read:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commissioner may, by direction in writing, after consultation with the relevant Presiding Officer, move an excess Parliamentary Service employee to another Parliamentary Department or to an APS Agency, without anyone's consent—
and if clause 26A(2) were amended to read:

For the purposes of this section, a Parliamentary Service employee is an excess Parliamentary Service employee if, and only if, that employee was covered by the Public Service Act 1922 at the time of entry into force of this Act, and the Secretary has notified the Commissioner in writing that the employee is excess to the requirements of the Parliamentary Department or the Parliamentary Service—

would that embrace the concerns that were expressed, at least by Senator Harradine and by Senator Ellison on behalf of the government? I think it does, but I seek their advice. If it does, I would seek by leave to amend the proposal that is before you, Madam Chair. However, I would like to hear from Senator Ellison and Senator Harradine on whether this finds favour with them and embraces the spirit of what they are suggesting to the committee, which was put with some force.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Having discussed this with the President, it is the government's view that this is a matter which does take something away from the Presiding Officers. It does detract from their ability to deal with employees in the parliamentary service. Even if you say that it is done in consultation, we really cannot see a need for it. The government opposes the amendment.
—In regard to proposed clause 26A(2), how would the words that are being suggested by Senator Faulkner be regarded by the Presiding Officer and the minister?

—I am not attracted to this amendment. I do not think it adds anything to what we are attempting to do. I certainly do not want to give the commissioner the power to move people around the parliament: from Senate to House of Representatives, from House of Representatives to Senate and that sort of thing. What I want to be absolutely certain of, and which is included, is that a person employed under the Parliamentary Service Bill 1997 is free to move to the Public Service, or someone from the Public Service is free to move to the parliamentary departments and retain their benefits and status in every way. I would be reluctant to see the commissioner have any power to direct, by writing, the movement of people about the departments or to put them into one place or another. It would seem to me to be totally inconsistent with the status of the parliament being independent of the executive, and other things as well. I would be disappointed if that went into the act.

—That places a hurdle which is pretty high to jump over. I appreciate the work that has been put into this by the Leader of the Opposition to try to get agreement but, obviously, there is no agreement. I had hoped there would be, but there is not. I will be voting against the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important issue, and it might be worth one final attempt to see if we could reach agreement. I wonder whether 26A(1) might be improved by the deletion of the words `by direction in writing,' so that it would read: `the commissioner may, after consultation with the relevant Presiding Officer, move an excess parliamentary service employee' et cetera, and then the words that I have already proposed in 26A(2). I propose to amend opposition amendment No. 30 before the chair in those terms. In other words, Section 26A(1) and 26A(2) would read:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The Commissioner may, after consultation with the relevant Presiding Officer, move an excess Parliamentary Service employee to another Parliamentary Department or to an APS Agency, without anyone's consent.

(2) For the purposes of this section, a Parliamentary Service employee is an excess Parliamentary Service employee if, and only if, that employee was covered by the Public Service Act 1922 at the time of entry into force of this Act, and the Secretary has notified the Commissioner in writing that the employee is excess to the requirements of the Parliamentary Department or the Parliamentary Service.
I ask if, by leave, the amendment before the chair could be amended in that form.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment that Senator Faulkner has proposed makes no difference to my attitude to this. Whether the commissioner tells someone in writing or verbally that they are to move from the Senate to the House of Representatives does not change anything. I believe it is the Presiding Officers who ought to be able to determine who the staff are in each of the two parliamentary departments and deal with them in the proper way. If there is somebody who is no longer required, there are provisions for how that should be dealt with. But I would be very reluctant indeed to see the status of the Presiding Officers, with respect to the employment in the parliamentary departments, shifted to another person in that fashion. I would urge the chamber to reject the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government's position is the same. The proposed amendment has the same effect: it invites the possibility of a conflict between the commissioner and the Presiding Officer, and that in itself is undesirable. I concur with the other arguments put by the President.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —(7.20 p.m.)—I hear what Madam President and the minister are saying. Now that I understand the basis of their concerns with this amendment, I think they can be dealt with. I am going to suggest a form of words that, given the contributions they have both made, I am quite confident they will be comfortable with—or, at least, the arguments that have been presented will, to my mind, not apply. It seems to me that clause 26A(1) could read:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commissioner may, with the agreement of the relevant Presiding Officer, move an excess Parliamentary Service employee to another Parliamentary Department or to an APS Agency without anyone's consent.
I would ask, again by leave, that the amendment be amended accordingly before it is put to the committee.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this is worse than it was before, and it is getting progressively worse as we go on. It is contradictory within itself. Why not leave it to the Presiding Officers to deal with staff of the parliamentary departments, if you are going to say the commissioner can only do it with the consent of the Presiding Officers and then, at the end of it, `without anyone's consent'? I think you are getting into a much worse situation than where we started.

SPEECH.PARA: I would urge the Senate to defeat the amendment, as has been amended a couple of times, and leave the act as it is. I do not believe that anybody outside of the parliamentary departments ought to have the power to shift staff about. If the Presiding Officers can do it, why do you need the commissioner involved? I fail to understand what you are getting at. I think what you have now is contradictory within itself, and it is not in the best interests of the parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the President needs to understand that it is the commissioner who is running the redeployment program in the APS. What I am proposing here takes into account the concerns that the President and the minister have. Nevertheless, I have a very serious concern here about the interests of the employees. I think that ought to be a primary concern for this committee too.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that, in terms of logical internal consistency, we can improve again 26A(1) by removing the words `without anyone's consent'. So if this clause read, `The Commissioner may, with the agreement of the relevant Presiding Officer, move an excess Parliamentary Service employee to another Parliamentary Department or to an APS agency.' I find it impossible to believe that that could not be acceptable to all concerned. The amendment in that form is what I would like to press. It is in the same form as I outlined to the committee before, but I acknowledge that the words `without anyone's consent' would need to be deleted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that the commissioner does have the running on the redeployment area in the APS. I am interested to hear what the Presiding Officer has to say in response to what Senator Faulkner has to say, because I am somewhat confused after debating these bills for hours. I am a little bit confused, given the three amendments to the clause thus far.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I still reject this. The commissioner of the parliamentary departments may not be the same person as the commissioner of the Public Service. I think it is more likely that at all times it would be, but then you would be saying that the parliamentary commissioner can shift people around within the parliament or can shift somebody from the parliament into the Public Service. I think we are creating a situation that is fraught with difficulty and is not solving any of the sorts of problems we want to solve.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course it is a matter of giving proper support and security to people employed under the Parliamentary Service Act. There are other provisions that deal with it. This amendment just gets the executive or some other person involved in shifting staff members within the parliamentary departments, or a commissioner, who perhaps is not the Public Service Commissioner, having the power to place people under the Public Service Act. If they are two different people, I would think the Public Service Commissioner would take great exception to that as well. I do not see that we are getting anywhere that is useful or of value. I think it is not in the best interests of the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask a few questions for clarification. Is it so, that someone who has been declared in excess is declared so by the Presiding Officer? Is it possible for that employee to then move into another parliamentary department, having been declared in excess? Who makes that decision under the current act without this amendment?

—Some of that would have to be answered by Senator Faulkner because it is his proposal. At the present time, by agreement within the departments, people can move around the building. If somebody is surplus or is not fitting in somewhere, it is possible to shift them within the departments at the present time. The Presiding Officers do that, of course, in consultation with the secretaries to the departments. I think it would be a pity to bring in an outside person to get involved in this sort of thing. There are other mechanisms for protecting staff as they should be protected.
—I ask Senator Faulkner to give us a case study or an example of how his amendment would work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the best thing for Senator Allison to give consideration to is clause 27 of the Public Service Bill 1997 itself—compulsory moves between agencies. These are the government's proposals in clause 27:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The Commissioner may, by direction in writing, move an excess APS employee to another Agency, without anyone's consent.

(2) For the purposes of this section, an APS employee is an excess APS employee if, and only if, the Agency Head has notified the Commissioner in writing that the employee is excess to the requirements of the Agency.

This is similar to that clause. This is very much in the interests of retaining existing rights that current parliamentary service employees have. That is what it is about. I think it is utterly irrelevant whether the Public Service Commissioner and the Parliamentary Services Commissioner are one and the same person. It is absolutely irrelevant; of no consequence whatsoever. I think the President is right: that in all likelihood—I think most of us have accepted this—that person is going to be one and the same. So what? What possible implication is there if that is not the case? I simply do not think the argument stands. I am trying to hear what Madam President says and to respond accordingly. The way I have proposed 26A(1) now, it reads:
The Commissioner may, with the agreement of the relevant Presiding Officer, move an excess Parliamentary Service employee to another Parliamentary Department or to an APS Agency.
it is a very important provision in terms of the rights of existing parliamentary service employees. I think this committee has to have some regard to that.

We have a particular responsibility in relation to parliamentary service employees and, I appreciate, so do the Presiding Officers. This is now a proposal much modified, much changed, evolved through the process of committee debate, that is worthy of support. I would not be proposing it if I was in any doubt at all that this compromised the Presiding Officers in any way. I do not believe it does and I strongly commend it to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I take on board what the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate said. The fact of the matter is that the secretary must have notified the commissioner in writing that the employee is excess to the requirements of the parliamentary department or the parliamentary service. That notification goes to the Parliamentary Service Commissioner who, as has been indicated, will most likely be the Public Service Commissioner. That commissioner will then search around to see how that excess parliamentary service employee can be moved to the satisfaction of that employee and be guaranteed to be to the satisfaction of the Presiding Officer.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate has indicated that with his third amendment the commissioner cannot move the excess parliamentary service employee between parliamentary departments or, indeed, to an APS agency unless with the agreement of the Presiding Officer. I feel that that now protects the functions of the secretary and of the clerk, and also is a practical means of ensuring that the mobility policies of the Parliamentary Service Commissioner—he or she is also the Public Service Commissioner—are covered.

BREAK.PARA: All right, we have got an excess parliamentary service employee. What are we going to do? The commissioner says to the Clerk of the Senate, `Look, there's a vacancy here. That person could most appropriately go there. What do you think about it?' That is fine within the parliamentary departments: he cannot do without the agreement of the Clerk, and that is it. In fact, we are almost giving veto power to the clerks as to where the Public Service Commissioner, who happens also to be the Parliamentary Service Commissioner, can place that particular excess Public Service employee in APS agencies. I think it is an amendment with which I can now agree. As far as I can see, it deserves the support of the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there is an issue here as to whether or not we want the situation of the parliament to be a one‐way street. I think we are all aware of the fact that perfectly competent, skilled and knowledgeable people come into the parliamentary system and, for various reasons, are in excess of the requirements of the parliament. It might be because of the peculiar hours, the stresses and the kind of work that is required. They may be perfectly competent in all sorts of areas within the Public Service, but they are not necessarily suited to the parliamentary process, they are the last person chosen or whatever. Therefore, I think it is a very reasonable suggestion that there be some option for them and some degree of duty of care on the part of the Presiding Officers to find—the word is `may', not `must'—a suitable location within the Public Service.

SPEECH.PARA: That may make it less traumatic for all the changes that occur. Also, I believe, it will help the parliamentary situation improve. If the situation is that where a person is in excess to requirements and the options are sacking them or putting them in a position to which they are clearly not suited, I would have thought it is better to find or, if possible, transfer that person to an area within the Public Service where they may be perfectly happy and suited, rather than trying to put a square peg in a round hole. I support Senator Faulkner's amended amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will be voting against the third reading of the Public Service Bill 1997 . We accept and welcome the fact that the bill has been significantly improved by the many amendments accepted by the Senate during the committee stage. As a consequence of those amendments, employees of the Australian Public Service will now enjoy a much greater level of protection of their rights and conditions than was intended by the government.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite those amendments, the Democrats believe the bill remains fundamentally flawed in four key respects. Firstly, the rejection of the Democrats amendments relating to public services which are contracted out, we think, leaves the bill silent on the quality and accountability of contracted services. The Democrats cannot accept that. We do not accept the minister's argument that this bill is not the appropriate place for these amendments.

When the government first announced its plans for these public service reforms, we were told in no uncertain terms by the then minister, Mr Peter Reith, that these reforms were not just about Public Service employment; we were told that the reforms were about improving the quality of public services. The Democrats do not believe the quality of service is a matter which stops at the door of the Australian Public Service.

If public services are to be contracted out to private corporations, community organisations or some other body, the Democrats believe the government has a responsibility to ensure that those services are also quality services. We believe that the government has a responsibility to ensure that those services are delivered in an effective, efficient and accountable manner.

The government's obligations to the taxpayers of Australia do not come to an end simply because a particular service is being delivered by a private organisation. What is more, the APS retains—or certainly should retain—monitoring and supervisory responsibilities. But this bill does not tell APS employees that they should apply the same values, standards and requirements to contracted services as they apply to in‐house services. The bill does not oblige the Public Service Commissioner to even remotely concern him or herself with how the APS should approach public services which it contracts out.

At a time when governments are increasingly trying to avoid responsibility for contracted services, the bill's silence on this point is unacceptable to the Democrats. Secondly, the failure of Democrats and opposition amend ments relating to workplace diversity means that the bill simply does not go far enough in guaranteeing employment equity within the Australian Public Service.

Reflecting on the government's belief that equal employment opportunity requirements are too prescriptive, the bill does little to compel the APS to take action to eliminate discrimination against women and other disadvantaged groups. While there is an obligation on agency heads to establish a workplace diversity program, there are no details set out in the bill as to how such a program will be implemented. What is more, the Democrats believe the draft directions from the Public Service Commissioner on this point are also inadequate.

While the APS values now require the APS to promote equity in employment, the values still refer to the APS providing a workplace that recognises the diverse background of APS employees which, I suggest, is somewhat meaningless and quite different from reflecting `the diverse nature of the community served by the APS', as put by the opposition in one of its amendments and rejected by the government and Senator Harradine.

The failure of our amendments dealing with the monitoring and reporting of equity issues also considerably weakens the bill. We share the concerns of the Womens Electoral Lobby, as put to the JCPA, that there is real potential for increased gender bias within the APS as a consequence of these reforms. As such, there is an even greater need for a strong APS commitment to employment equity. The Democrats believe the bill fails to ensure the APS will make such a commitment.

Thirdly, the failure of the Democrats whistleblower amendments means the bill falls a long way short of offering adequate protection to Public Service whistleblowers. The government and the opposition continue to give lip‐service to the idea of separate whistleblower legislation but have failed to take the opportunity when it is here before them to build proper protections into the Public Service Bill 1997 .

As my colleague Senator Murray pointed out, his proposed changes to the bill could have been repealed easily at a later date once separate legislation was introduced. As it is, the bill will now contain only minimum protection for whistleblowers and significantly limit the circumstances in which their actions will attract that protection. This is unacceptable to the Democrats.

Finally, we simply cannot support a bill in which the appointment, termination and fixing of the remuneration of departmental secretaries remains solely and exclusively within the gift of the Prime Minister. Under this bill, it is the Prime Minister who can now appoint a secretary without reference to anyone else; it is the Prime Minister who can now terminate the appointment of a secretary at any time without reference to anyone else; it is the Prime Minister who now determines the remuneration, terms and conditions of departmental secretaries.

If that does not make the Australian Public Service the servant of not just the government of the day but the executive of the day, then I do not know what does. In effect, not only does the employment of a secretary depend entirely upon the will of the Prime Minister, but so, too, does their income and terms and conditions under which they were employed. This is precisely what Sir Lenox Hewitt was talking about when he told the JCPA that these reforms represented—and I quote:

. . . the intention to change, indeed to destroy, the Australian Public Service and to convert it into a series of appointments at pleasure—at the whim, in the case of secretaries, of the Prime Minister . . .
The Democrats believe these changes do represent a significant shift in both the operation and perception of the Australian Public Service.

Of course, the APS serves the government of the day; it provides advice to the government and it implements the policies and programs of the government. But the APS has always had a role which extends beyond that. It has had a wider role in implementing the legislation passed by the parliament in assisting the parliament in scrutinising how taxpayers' funds are spent and in serving the Australian public. In other words, serving the government of the day is just one of the functions of the APS. The APS is not owned by the government, it is not owned by the Prime Minister, it is owned and paid for by the Australian community. This bill seeks to change that. It seeks to turn the Australian Public Service into the creature of the government of the day.

Senator Ray came in here today during this debate and spoke very eloquently about the politicisation of the APS by the Howard government. He neglected, of course, to point out the significant contribution made by the previous Labor government in this regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just itching to get his hands on government.

—Indeed. If he was genuine in his concerns, then he and the Labor Party should also vote against this bill on the basis that it will result in an even greater politicisation of the APS, an even greater loss of the accountability of the APS and a further reduction in the capacity of the APS to serve the community and the parliament as well as the government.

SPEECH.PARA: But, of course, the Labor Party can see the benefits of this legislation to themselves should they be returned to government. They are not too unhappy with the idea of a Labor Prime Minister flexing his or her muscles over the departmental heads. They are not too concerned about the APS being in the pocket of the government of the day if it is a Labor government and a Labor pocket.

I do acknowledge that the opposition, with the Democrats' support, have acted to significantly improve the bill, but their inability to go that step further signals that they, too, see the APS as belonging to the government and not to the public. The Democrats do not share that view and we will not support a bill which puts that view into practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Allison, are the Democrats going to vote against the third reading of the four bills or just one or two? I need some clarification before I put the question.
—Just the Public Service Bill.
—What about the consequential amendments to it?

—Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I think it is reasonable for you to ask the senator what she is going to do, but she has indicated to the Senate what she intends to do. I think it is a matter on which the Senate should vote. I understand why you asked her, quite properly, because you have to put the questions accordingly. But I think we should get on with it.

—The question is that the Parliamentary Service Bill 1997 and the Parliamentary Service (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 be read a third time.
—Madam Deputy President, could the Democrats' names be recorded as voting against the two bills.

If the government was more committed to understanding the process of consultation, this bill's passage would have been a lot smoother and it would have passed with a great deal more confidence than is currently the case. SPEECH.PARA: It has also been difficult to get from industry groups information on the matters being debated. I would like to acknowledge the efforts of farmers from New South Wales and Western Australia as well as from the Victorian grain industry task force. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I rise in the adjournment debate to provide an update on the economic progress that is now under way in Newcastle and the Hunter region.
—Hear, hear!

—Thank you, Senator McGauran, for your support. A lot has happened in the Newcastle and the Hunter since 29 April this year when BHP announced its decision to downsize its steel making facilities. The BHP announcement foreshadowed the loss at that time of 2,500 jobs by the year 1999. The estimated loss on top of this was a further 4,000 positions downstream from the production process. BHP was, on the other hand, centring its steel wire making process in Newcastle, creating an additional 800 jobs. But still there was a major net downsizing of the work force as a result of this process.

SPEECH.PARA: What I wanted to report to the Senate tonight is that the very negative feeling that this generated in the Hunter at this time has now given way to a more positive outlook as the Hunter economy repositions itself and begins to forge ahead. The Newcastle Herald reported this news in glowing terms on 14 November this year. It said:
The Hunter Valley is the home to 220 forthcoming and potential economic developments worth more than $8.5 billion—
I repeat that: $8.5 billion—
with the potential to generate 60,000 jobs.
Tonight I want to report in particular on the reason for this optimism and also on the potential growth in the Hunter region.

I think the genesis of this goes back to the very successful visit to the Hunter Valley in July by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) which actually changed the whole climate and atmosphere from one of gloom to one of hope and optimism. His two‐day visit in July marked a turning point. It was symbolic but it was actually more than that. What he did during this time was promote a very optimistic vision for the city when he met with business leaders, civic leaders and members of the community over a period of two days.

The Prime Minister marshalled very strong local union and community support for his plan to use a whole range of initiatives federally and also in conjunction with the state and with BHP to pool a series of separate projects and two major projects which are to be announced in the next few weeks. The federal subcommittee of cabinet came to the Hunter. Quite a few ministers moved through the area and announced at that time an additional $19.5 million.

The effect of this has been to assist in the creation of a climate of optimism in the Hunter. Now a private study has given us some great hope for the future in what has been generated as a result of this changing climate. The study was presented at a jobs summit in Newcastle last Friday and has confirmed in hard evidence that the Hunter region is `going for growth'. The study was compiled by a local businessman and publisher, Mr Lex Thomas. The Hunter Economic Development Corporation has backed the study's findings. A spokesman for the HEDC is quoted in the Newcastle Herald as saying:
. . . it was a comprehensive and encouraging appraisal of the region's economic potential.

The Thomas study illustrates the sheer magnitude of the job creation that is now under way in the Newcastle and the Hunter. There are 223 individual projects under way. The projected value is a staggering $8.5 billion. Thirty thousand new jobs are to be created during the construction phase. Using the conservative multiplier of 2.5, those 10,500 jobs would create another 26,000 places. Therefore, the potential new employment for the Hunter is 66,000 jobs coming on stream at a time when BHP is downsizing by only 2,500 jobs. If you look at the balance between what is going from the Hunter and what is coming to the Hunter in a range of very exciting new industries, you see there is a great hope and future for this region.

Let me cover some of the specifics of the projects. There are 15 projects worth $100 million or more. Typical of these bigger projects is the $1 billion British Aerospace lead‐in fighter construction and maintenance project at Williamtown RAAF base. The Prime Minister recently announced assistance for the National Power project of two power stations in the Hunter, at Redbank near Singleton, worth $600 million. The federal government, in terms of assistance in relation to the replaced infrastructure bond scheme, is putting in $30 million. It was this that was the catalyst for this particular $600 million worth of investments.

The study identifies four other categories of projects, against a dollar value, ready to go into the Hunter. In the $20 million to $99 million category there are 26 projects, valued in total at $1.2 billion, including a number of mines that were announced by our minister for good news up here in the Senate, Senator Parer. He came up to the Hunter and announced more good news up there with the opening and proposed development of a range of new mines in the coal industry. In the $5 million to $19 million range there are 49 projects valued at $450 million in total. There are 91 projects in the $1 million to $5 million value range, in total $183 million, and another 41 smaller ventures worth in total $30 million.

In a whole range of business activity in the Hunter—huge projects, medium sized pro jects, small projects—the region is very clearly experiencing a boom. This is in mining, engineering, aerospace, tourism and the power industry sector. Following the understandable despair that was left after BHP's announcement of the downsizing of its steel plant after 80 years, the region is climbing back with a vengeance. I commend these positive developments for the people of the Hunter. I particularly would like to thank the Prime Minister for his role in turning the mood around and helping to generate these new projects for the Hunter. It has been a pleasure for me tonight to inform the Senate of these new developments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Like many Australians I have been frustrated by the failed pursuit of the Alan Bond millions. In early 1994, Federal Police began investigating possible offences committed by Alan Bond whilst in bankruptcy and Bond's apparent failure to fully disclose to his trustee all of his assets and possessions. The trustee, Mr Robert Ramsay, was highly dissatisfied with the level of cooperation of Bond, who claimed he could not remember certain significant transactions but on the other hand remembered precise details in gifting $33 million in cash and assets to various family members and trusts in the two years prior to his 1991 bankruptcy.

SPEECH.PARA: By way of example, Bond claimed he was suffering memory loss and could not recall the exact location or details of ownership of several major artworks, including the 1782 portrait of Captain James Cook by John Webber. This portrait left Australia on 6 January 1990. In March 1996 Federal Police seized the portrait, a valuable piece of our history, along with several other major artworks, in the United Kingdom, with the assistance of Britain's Serious Fraud Office.

I am advised that Bond's denial about these transactions has since been exposed by Bond Corporation liquidator, Mr Richard England, as `a sham intended to disguise a fraudulent scheme'. I am further advised that Mr England claims Bond family interests `maliciously conspired and combined amongst themselves' to defraud the company and recently com menced civil action against Bond family members to recover certain paintings and the proceeds of others sold by Bond family interests. I am advised that the bulk of the moneys were shown to have been paid to various Liechtenstein bank accounts.

In 1994, Mr Ramsay released a series of confidential reports to creditors detailing the involvement of Bond's Swiss `para‐banker', Mr Jurg Bollag. In September of 1994, via the then Attorney‐General, Mr Lavarch, the AFP made the first in a series of requests to the Swiss authorities to execute search warrants upon a number of Swiss banks and the home of Jurg Bollag. In the same month a number of search warrants were executed against Bond, his family members, and certain business associates around Australia. The information obtained under these warrants was finally released to Mr Ramsay after an extensive legal battle, but only hours before creditors were to vote on a deed of composition put forward by Bond to discharge his bankruptcy. It proved too late for the information to be of any good purpose.

I am advised that documents recovered by the AFP have revealed a number of significant transactions involving millions of dollars spirited into and out of the country by Mr Bond during his bankruptcy, none of which has ever been disclosed to his trustee. These transactions apparently confirmed Mr Ramsay's 1994 knowledge of Bond's dealings in a number of offshore entities, particularly those in Liechtenstein, which are at the very heart of the AFP investigation.

In agreeing to the 1995 settlement with his creditors, Mr Bond signed a warranty stating he had disclosed all his assets. Mr Bond intentionally and covertly misled his creditors and he still refuses to deliver up the tens of millions taken from the Australian public. It appears self‐evident now that Alan Bond deceitfully withheld material information about his personal assets from his trustee in bankruptcy.

In 1996, Bond began serving the first of two jail terms, one for the La Promenade art fraud. Later, in 1997, Bond pleaded guilty to his role in stripping $1.2 billion from Bell Resources. It was revealed during preliminary hearings that at least $66 million was siphoned to the family company Dallhold, the conduit by which Bond managed to personally benefit from his corporate philandering. None of this money has ever been recovered. It is still missing and at large, like so many valuable assets, after many years of investigation.

The AFP investigation is now four years old and has not yet delivered any charges. Thousands of hours of investigative work and many millions of dollars have been spent investigating Bond. It seems Mr Bond has had available to him these missing millions and has consequently been able to mount a sufficiently funded legal challenge to every possible threat of prosecution. Why any lawyer would be prepared to profit from such missing millions is beyond understanding. Federal Court Justice Ron Merkel, in dismissing a recent application by Bond and his banker, Jurg Bollag, said it was audacious and a serious misuse and abuse of the litigation process. This abuse continues this very day as Bond continues to fight orders of the Supreme Court of South Australia in an action where Bond is sought to be examined in that jurisdiction.

A number of applications for special leave to appeal to the High Court of Australia have since been lodged by lawyers acting for Bond who now also wish to challenge the length of his sentence. Such an abuse of the legal process is a sad indictment upon our legal system which allows wealthy individuals to mount a number of successive appeals not available to ordinary Australian citizens. This is especially unpalatable when the wealth has been acquired, as has been proved beyond reasonable doubt in the Bond case, from corporate victims.

The AFP suffered a series of budget cuts in 1993-94 and many resources are now unavailable to the AFP in its fight against drug importation, organised crime and other crimes. We must ensure that the allocation of funds available to our crime fighting agencies is money well spent. We must guard against a repeat of the corporate excesses of the 1980s and we must have effective legislation to combat our white‐collar criminals like Mr Bond. In recognising the efforts made by successive governments, I now ask the present Attorney-General (Mr Williams) what is to become of the Bond matters. Will the Federal Police investigation lead to charges and, in turn, produce successful convictions against Bond and others who have assisted his crimes against the Australian people?

A number of our corporate criminals have not been brought to justice in the Australian courts. For instance, Mr Skase and Mr Goldberg are still at large. There is also the lengthy case by the Australian Securities Commission against former Bond Corporation director, Mr Tony Oates, whose case for extradition has been before the Polish authorities on a number of successive occasions, so far without achieving a result. The next consideration of this matter is on 27 January 1998. Let us ensure our legislative processes are ever vigilant against the likes of Bond and Skase so, as we move towards the next century, the Australian people will have faith in the ability and priority of government to bring those to justice who would otherwise seek to damage our reputation as an honest and fair country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferris, Sen Jeannie

TALK.START.PARA: —Parliament can sometimes be a place where myths and legends begin or are perpetrated, where folklore can become fact and where facts can be blurred in the later detail. Tonight I would like to examine some of the myths and legends that have come to surround the former government's Native Title Act 1993. We must never forget that the Native Title Act which this nation now has was not Labor's original grand plan to implement the High Court's 1992 Mabo decision. It was merely the compromise that ultimately came out of the backroom deals made in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: The real plan of the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating—his ideal solution to the challenge created by the Mabo decision—was embodied in the Native Title Bill 1993 introduced into the House of Representatives. In fact, so important did the former Prime Minister consider this bill to be that he swept aside the responsible minister of the day, Mr Tickner, to personally introduce the bill. He did so on 16 November 1993. His speech reveals the personal dreams and the extent to which he personally was involved in its formulation. In fact, his speech emphasised the fact, describing the introduction of his legislation that day as `a milestone'. He said his plan would represent a new beginning for indigenous Australians.

Let us have a look at what the former Prime Minister wanted the bill to deliver. One of the great myths that has been created by the swirl of modern spin doctors is that it was never Mr Keating's original intention to extinguish native title. In fact, the plan is clearly explained in the explanatory memorandum. Fancy this. Under the heading `Extinguishment of native title by validation of some acts' is this enlightening statement:

The validation of past acts and grants will only extinguish native title where there has been what the Bill terms a category A past act . . . that is, a grant of freehold or the grant of a commercial, agricultural, pastoral or residential lease . . . or the construction of a public work.

There it is. Labor's original native title plan clearly demonstrates that it was their intention to extinguish a significant amount of native title, including, explicitly, pastoral leases. Bucket loads of extinguishment you might say. Let us not be fooled by the codes at work here. Does it matter if you say `validation', because, in this case, it would have resulted in native title rights being substantially reduced in any case. Just to be sure that everybody understood, the Prime Minister backed up his speech on ABC radio when he said:
What it—
his grand plan—
will mean is that native title will be extinguished on pastoral leases, that is not to the extent of any inconsistency, but extinguished.
The explanatory memorandum spelt it out clearly. It said:
The Mabo decision clearly indicated that governments are able to affect and indeed extinguish Native Title.

So we learn not the myth but the reality. From the explanatory memorandum in which the former Prime Minister was so proudly involved, that extinguishment of native title is entirely consistent with Mabo and would in no way represent an overturning of the Mabo decision. There it is as plain as day. Of course, as we all know, that bill passed through the House of Representatives without amendment.

But in its passage over the Great Hall to the scrutiny of the states house, the house of review, the myth of a `new deal for black and white Australia', to use Mr Keating's words, was put to rest. His grand plan began to undergo a metamorphosis. It was subjected to considerable change and to substantial compromise. In the end, the captain of the team did not get the plan he wanted. He got the Native Title Act 1993, which, though still bearing his imprint, was light years away from what he really wanted and from what he introduced that day in 1993.

But the legend remains. Just this past week, the former Prime Minister emerged from the shadows to perpetrate it yet again. In doing so, he chose to describe the coalition's native title plan as racist. In fact, he said:

Now if there's a piece of Commonwealth law which allows the States, or anyone else, to do their dirty work and to deny people . . . their common law title . . . it's racially discriminatory and therefore it's racist.

How kind his memory is and how mythical his recall. This is the fellow who, before the myth was perpetrated, introduced a bill which proclaimed very proudly that the Mabo decision clearly indicated that governments are able to affect and indeed extinguish native title. A myth began and a legend was perpetrated. But the truth is revealed by the veracity of the Hansard . As we consider how well this bill delivered for this nation, the truth and the reality of Mr Keating's dream must not be forgotten by those who have the opportunity to remember the truth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of tax questions this afternoon were directed to the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), including one from Senator Bishop on the fringe benefits tax. It is quite evident that the Labor senators asking those questions did not really fully understand the import of the questions which had been obviously prepared for them. They also did not appreciate the background of the Labor Party in its development of the fringe benefits tax scheme during the 13 years of its disastrous regime.

SPEECH.PARA: For a moment, for the benefit of senators, I will go a little into history. It was the Labor Party that fundamentally changed the law regarding fringe benefits tax. It moved the responsibility from taxing the employee to taxing the employer. The tax is paid regardless of the profitability of the employer. After 13 years of Labor mismanagement, which was also evident in the fringe benefits tax regime, we moved from, as I said, taxing the employee to taxing the employer. Initially it started as a tax on salary related type payments by the employer. Progressively, that net was widened and widened. The Labor Party also progressively raised the amount of revenue from fringe benefits. At the same time, it increased the cost of compliance substantially on the employer. In many cases, we had fringe benefits compliance costs being significantly higher for some firms, particularly small firms, than the tax they paid.

The impact of the FBT in some situations was disastrous nationally and on the states and local communities. Many of Labor's fringe benefits taxes on employer provided car parking, for example, worked contrary to local government's good community planning measures, which encouraged employers to provide on-site parking. When this fringe benefits tax on employee parking came along, the employers shoved the employees' cars out onto the streets.

The Labor Party also initiated changes that have today opened up unlimited opportunities for rorting, particularly by a number of state governments and their agencies and charitable organisations. The Labor Party also initiated changes to remote area taxation which have played havoc for so many small mining towns, particularly to the north. Many of them have been wrecked, especially those traditionally regarded as company towns. To such an extent, because of the FBT, we now have large mining organisations that fly their employees in from major metropolitan cen tres. For example, the Argyle company flies its people in from Perth on a weekly or fortnightly basis to their Argyle mine in the Northern Territory. So it has completely changed the features of, and community spirit in, many small mining towns. Such has been the havoc wreaked by this fringe benefits tax.

Since the change of government, the new Liberal‐National Party government has made a number of significant changes. We still have a long way to go. I will enumerate a number of the changes we have made. We have raised the threshold for minor items. We have changed the regime on car parking for small businesses. We have abolished the fringe benefits tax on taxi travel and the like. We have exempted record keeping from the fringe benefits where those benefits have a taxable value of $5,000 or less, which is very significant.

Businesses which elect to take advantage of such an option provided by the Liberal‐National Party coalition will pay fringe benefits on the benefits established in the base year. This record keeping exemption will provide a reduction in compliance costs for many small fringe benefit tax payers, which is estimated to be close to 75 per cent of all enterprises paying FBT who do not make a material change in the amount or type of benefits provided each year. It is anticipated that more than 50,000 Australian businesses will be relieved from this form of onerous record keeping.

Senator Bishop's question this afternoon raised the issue of benefits provided by third parties—say, to a business employee. One of the problems of extending fringe benefits to benefits provided by a third party is that it is often difficult for the employer to be aware of such practices—including the provision of meals by third parties. Although the meal issue has been somewhat simplified in recent years from what it was previously, I believe perhaps the simple solution, except in isolated circumstances, is to scrap both the income tax deductibility and the fringe benefits tax on meals.

I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which summarises the Commissioner of Taxation's view on the application of the entertainment provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act and the fringe benefits tax consequences of common situations involving the provision of food and drink. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In conclusion, I would like to refer to the report Getting it right for the millennium released last week by Mr Jon Hutchison, its architect, and the federal Minister for Sport and Tourism, Mr Andrew Thomson. The report will provide a framework for the government's national tourism strategy and it lays a foundation for tourism beyond the Sydney Olympics to 2005. One of the measures included in the report's recommendations is a fringe benefits tax exemption for meals. I wholeheartedly support this measure as part of a vital reform which I believe will be of great benefit not only to the tourism industry but to Australian businesses generally and ultimately to all Australians.

BREAK.PARA: I ask everybody listening to this speech to be very conscious of the very detrimental role the provisions of the fringe benefits tax have had on the national outlook in Australia and the problems they have caused for our mining industry and the small mining towns. The Labor Party tax opened up the opportunity for tax rorting by a number of state governments, their agencies and also charitable institutions. The tax has also caused problems for small business, plus there has been the very high cost of compliance. I commend the Liberal‐National Party on their changes, particularly the changes in relation to fringe benefits that have had a very significant impact on reducing compliance costs for small businesses. I thank the Senate.
