QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 29 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the Sydney Noise Insulation Project, a package consisting of home acquisitions for residents living in the area affected by above 40 Australian Noise Exposure Forecast (ANEF) levels; noise treatment for schools, churches and hospitals for homes in the 30 to 40 ANEF range; and noise treatment for homes in the 30 to 40 ANEF range;
(1) What is the status of the project.

(2) What percentage of eligible schools, churches, hospitals and homes have been treated for noise (please provide a map of the site coverage, in accordance with the maps distributed by the Sydney Noise Insulation Project when it first commenced operation).
(3) What is the total amount of money the Government has spent to date, including a breakdown on each of the categories listed in (2).
(4) How much has the Government allocated for the continuation of the project.
(5) When does the Minister expect the project to be completed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Consistent with the announcement by the previous Minister for Transport on 29 May 1997, changes have been made to the Sydney Airport Noise Amelioration program to reflect the changes to aircraft noise exposure flowing from implementation of the Long Term Operating Plan.
This has involved a reprioritisation of the program to focus insulation on areas east and west of the airport while those to the north have been reduced.

Pending the production of an ANEF based on actual operating experience with the plan, areas of eligibility have been determined on the basis of an Australian Noise Exposure Concept (prepared in association with the Long Term Operating Plan). This represents the current best assessment of aircraft noise exposure associated with flight paths to be used under the plan. Invitations have been sent to home owners to the west and east of the airport likely to be within a future 30 ANEF. Invitations that have already been sent to households to the north of the airport, up to Stanmore Road, will be honoured.
Insulation will be offered to public buildings, such as schools, pre‐schools, hospitals, and health care facilities and churches which are likely to be within the future 25 ANEF contour.

(2) Work has been completed on 17 schools and colleges, 19 pre schools and child care centres (funding for the replacement of a further 2 has been offered to Marrickville Council), one nursing home and is under way at Newington College. Work has also been completed on approximately 1400 homes out of the 3300 eligible under the reprioritised scheme. Public buildings newly eligible for insulation under the reprioritised scheme, subject to verification of eligibility criteria, include 7 schools, 8 pre schools and child care centres, 5 hospitals and health care facilities and 22 churches. Five churches to the north of the airport eligible under the previous program remain eligible. Maps have been lodged with the Table Office showing the areas eligible under the reprioritise program. * Attachments 1 to 4 for residential insulation assistance and * Attachments 5 to 9 for eligible public buildings.

(3) As at 2 October 1997, a total of $151.8m had been spent on the program comprising $37.4 on acquisition and demolition of properties in the 40 ANEF zone, $40.9m on the insulation of schools, $3.2m on child care centres, $0.4m on health care facilities $54.4 on residential insulation and $15.5m on project management.
(4) The total expenditure this financial year is expected to be of the order of $60m. The forward estimates currently include an amount of $164.5m.

(5) The program is a voluntary one and progress depends to a large degree on the speed with which home owners and owners of eligible public buildings take up the Commonwealth's offer of insulation assistance and the details concerning the works can be agreed. However, based on past experience, the program is likely to continue in operation for at least 2 more years.
* Copies of all attachments are available from the Senate Table Office

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 21 October 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the lighthouse precinct on South Bruny Island, within the recently‐proclaimed national park:
(1) Can the Minister give an assurance that the lighthouse precinct, including historic structures and associated maritime history, will not be privatised.
(2) Will the Commonwealth hand the precinct to the Tasmanian Parks and Wildlife Service for incorporation into the new national park.
(3) Who is currently responsible for maintaining the access road to the lighthouse and what arrangements have been made to continue the maintenance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commonwealth has offered a number of surplus lighthouse properties, including Cape Bruny, to the Tasmanian Government. The Tasmanian Government, subject to a number of conditions, has agreed to accept these properties.

(2) A condition of the transfer requires the State to manage the property in a way that will protect its heritage and conservation values. The property must be reserved under the Crown Lands Act (Tas) 1976 or dedicated under the National Parks and Wildlife Act (Tas) 1970 within two years after the settlement date.

(3) That part of the road that is on property presently owned by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) is maintained by the Authority to a level sufficient for its purposes. The remaining 18 kms of the road is within lands owned by the State and managed by the Tasmanian Department of Environment. A part of the offer for transfer of the lighthouse properties is a financial contribution by AMSA towards the costs of upgrading the road within the Labillardiere Peninsula State Reserve. Future maintenance of the road is a matter for decision of the Tasmanian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 20 October 1997:

BREAK.PARA: (1) (a) Are forests in the Portland Forest Management Area (FMA) of western Victoria, especially the Cobboboonee and Narrawong State Forests, habitats for rare and threatened species, including the Yellowbellied Glider, Powerful Owl, Yellow-tailed Black Cockatoo and Redtailed Black Cockatoo; (b) are these species regarded as rare or threatened by the Commonwealth; (c) which species are listed under the Commonwealth Endangered Species (Protection) Act; and (d) are any other species occurring in these forests listed under the Act.
(2) What is the role and significance of State forests in the Portland FMA to the conservation and survival of these species.

(3) Does the Minister consider that the current management of these forests for timber production, including the ringbarking of habitat trees, threatens the survival of any of these species at a local, regional or national scale; if not, why not.
(4) What action will be taken, pending preparation of a regional forest agreement for western Victoria, to ensure that logging does not further threaten these species.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: 1(a) Based on currently available information, the forests of the Portland Forest Management Area (FMA) are likely to provide habitats for a number of rare and threatened fauna species, including the Red-tailed Black Cockatoo and Powerful Owl.

1 (b, c) Of the species mentioned, only the Red-tailed Black Cockatoo is listed under the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992 (ESP Act)—its status is endangered. The Powerful Owl is listed as threatened under Victoria's Flora and Fauna Guarantee Act 1988 (FFG Act) but is not on the schedules to the ESP Act. While the Yellow-bellied Glider and Yellow-tailed Black Cockatoo both occur in the Portland FMA, neither is considered to be threatened under the ESP or FFG Acts.

1 (d) Other species likely to occur in forests of the Portland FMA which are listed under the ESP Act include the Spot-tailed Quoll (vulnerable), Heath Mouse (endangered), Striped Legless Lizard (vulnerable), and possibly the Swift Parrot (vulnerable). As part of the CRA/RFA process, proposals are currently being developed to undertake surveys for both flora and fauna in the West RFA region, which includes the Portland FMA. These surveys will provide valuable information on the range and status of these and other species, including species occurring in the Cobboboonee and Narrawong State Forests.

(2) All areas of native forest contribute to the conservation and survival of forest-dependant species. Flora and fauna surveys to be undertaken as part of the CRA/RFA process will provide valuable information as to the relative conservation significance of different areas of native forest in the Portland FMA.

(3) No. Areas of native forest in the Portland FMA are currently subject to an Interim Forest Agreement between the Commonwealth and Victoria. I am satisfied that under this agreement, current management of these forests for timber production will not foreclose options for the conservation and survival of rare and threatened species pending the completion of an RFA for western Victoria.

(4) A range of existing mechanisms provides protection for rare and threatened species in the Portland FMA. Of the five species listed under the ESP Act that are considered likely to occur in the Portland FMA, draft recovery plans exist for the Red-tailed Black Cockatoo, the Striped Legless Lizard and the Swift Parrot. All five species have Action Statements either in place or in preparation under the FFG Act. In addition, the Victorian Code of Forest Practices for Timber Production requires that local prescriptions be put in place to provide for the protection of all known records of rare and threatened species. I am confident that these measures will ensure the survival of rare and threatened species in the Portland FMA pending completion of an RFA for Western Victoria.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 31 October 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was $700,000 allocated in the 1997‐98 Budget to the department to promote gene technology to the public.
(2) Over what period will the allocation be spent.
(3) Will the department use all or part of this money on a series of forums or meetings; if so, what is the purpose of these forums or meetings.
(4) What role, if any, will the members and secretariat of the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee Secretariat (GMAC) play at these forums or meetings.
(5) Is any gene technology promotion by GMAC personnel compatible with their role as regulators and assessors.
(6) Will proponents and critics in the gene technology debate be invited to participate in forums or meetings.
(7) Will the department give any of these monies to interested parties for other educational or promotional projects; if so, how much.
(8) Does the Government promote a diversity of opinions and views on the introduction of gene technology.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) $700,000 was allocated to seek public views on gene technology regulation and to provide balanced information on gene technology to members of the public so that they can make informed choices. It will not be used to promote gene technology.
(2) Two years.

(3) The main mechanism for obtaining public views on gene technology regulation will be an invitation for written submissions from interest groups and individual members of the community. The need for public forums will be considered following a review of written submissions.
(4) The role of GMAC secretariat members, if any, in public forums would be limited to providing information on gene technology and its regulation.

(5) The provision of information on gene technology is an important function of the GMAC secretariat. The secretariat does not promote gene technology. Members of the Committee are free to support or oppose gene technology as they wish.
(6) See answer to (3) above.

(7) Most of the Budget allocation will be used for educational programs and some of this may be used for educational programs undertaken in cooperation with industry, consumer and environmental groups. Funding will not be available for programs intended to promote or oppose gene technology.
(8) See answer to (1) above.
